webTitle: How to.... tell when a project is going badly

fields.headline: How to.... tell when a project is going badly
fields.trailText: 1: Observe the demeanour of the project organiser. It is not a good sign if the boss is hysterical or anguished. Sir Herman Ouseley's resignation this year from the Commission for Racial Equality was surprisingly emotional, following the spectacular failure of the CRE's Global Diversity Congress. The conference was pulled by the Home Office a month before it was due to happen. When Ouseley stood down, he suggested that his job was impossibly pressured - a clear indication that he was struggling.
fields.body:
1: Observe the demeanour of the project organiser. It is not a good sign if the boss is hysterical or anguished. Sir Herman Ouseley's resignation this year from the Commission for Racial Equality was surprisingly emotional, following the spectacular failure of the CRE's Global Diversity Congress. The conference was pulled by the Home Office a month before it was due to happen. When Ouseley stood down, he suggested that his job was impossibly pressured - a clear indication that he was struggling.

2: Consider packing your bags if the head honcho starts publicly blaming the team. They are admitting they have lost control. A decisive moment in John Major's premiership was when he called some of his cabinet colleagues 'bastards' - an acknowledgement that the party was in a state of civil war. Bosses undermine their position if they vent irritations in public.

3: Accept that the project could be doomed if too many people try to direct it or if there is a succession of heads. 'There should be one creative intelligence behind a project, with the power to see it through,' says project manager Hazel. The Millennium Dome suffered from having too many chiefs. By contrast, managers of the hugely successful Tate Modern project had a clear and consistent vision - resulting in a million visitors in less than two months.

4: Recognise that the project is likely to drift downhill if there is a climate of fear. If staff are terrified about making a mistake, they will take a conservative approach and let their creative talents languish. Sycophants will rise to the top if a team is discouraged from giving frank opinions. Some commentators believe New Labour is now starting to flounder as the leaders find it more difficult to cope with criticism.

5: Check that the basic requirements for success are in place. The collapse of the Global Diversity Congress was attributed to a range of factors including: 'Cashflow... a lack of clarity about roles and poor separation of duties; the inexperience of key staff; and a lack of systems or failure to apply correctly the systems that did exist.' A danger sign - common in dotcoms - is lavish spending. If bosses regularly offer afternoon champagne, they are indicating that they have money to burn. Even if you do not take advantage of their weak financial controls, someone else probably will.

webTitle: How far can Big Brother firm go?

fields.headline: How far can Big Brother firm go?
fields.standfirst: I work in a call centre where my colleagues and I are becoming worried that we are under surveillance. All telephone conversations are taped, and bosses can see how long we are on the phone for and how long each conversation lasts. How far can they go - and what can we do about it?
fields.trailText: I work in a call centre where my colleagues and I are becoming worried that we are under surveillance. All telephone conversations are taped, and bosses can see how long we are on the phone for and how long each conversation lasts. How far can they go - and what can we do about it?
fields.body:
Employers who want to keep an eye on their staff have huge opportunities open to them - especially if the business is a hi-tech one. Monitoring is increasingly used - through phones, the internet and CCTV. Some bank workers are worried that CCTV is used more to control them than to identify robbers. Telephone technology means sales staff and other workers can be watched closely - particularly the length and number of calls, keying rate and even time off to go to the toilet.

Banking union Unifi has just produced a report on surveillance. On the internet, it says: 'The employer can easily ascertain what sites have been accessed and what messages have been sent or received.' But when the new Data Protection Act comes into force in October, employees will have the right to know what data is held, why it is held and who has access to it. However, the onus is on staff to request the information. The Human Rights Act, also coming into force in October, will bolster an individual's rights to privacy.

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Design your dreams into a new home

fields.headline: Design your dreams into a new home
fields.standfirst: Off-plan buyers get a greater say, writes  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: People buying new apartments and houses can now extract extra value in the form of additional fixtures and fittings, a choice of layout in some rooms, and, in some cases, even a say in the overall design.
fields.body:
It is hard to feel sorry for property developers squeezed by a closely fought market where buyers benefit from fierce competition for newly built homes.

People buying new apartments and houses can now extract extra value in the form of additional fixtures and fittings, a choice of layout in some rooms, and, in some cases, even a say in the overall design.

Only 31 per cent of potential buyers preferred new homes to older ones, according to an opinion poll carried out for upmarket estate agent Strutt and Parker. Busy younger professionals wanted low-maintenance modern homes, and they are the group most likely to ben efit by negotiating extras in return for deposits put down before completion.

Property company Metropolis is developing the Madison, a complex of 39 one-and two-bedroom apartments at Borough in south London, ranging in price from £200,000 to £400,000. It will not be complete until next year, but people committing themselves now will have a choice of six different kitchen and bathroom designs.

'This kind of choice is unheard of at this level of the market,' claims Metropolis' Howard Crocker. 'Buyers are usually faced with a standard kitchen, one colour of tile and wooden flooring, whether they like it or not. By creating our own in-house designs we aim to break with the traditional style of developing.'

Michael and Judith Lerner got even more when they chose a detached five-bedroom house nine months before completion.

They were allowed to attending progress meetings with developer Banner Homes as builders worked on the house in Stanmore, north London. 'We bought the house before the foundations were even laid and it proved a great opportunity to watch our house grow,' said Mrs Lerner. 'Buying early gave us the advantage of having a great input.'

Banner and the Lerners entered into what the company called a 'build contract' which allowed the buyers to have a bigger say than any of its previous customers.

'We were basically happy with the building plans, although we changed some minor things - the position of a door and the size of one room, things like that,' says Michael Lerner, a chartered accountant.

'But we had a much bigger say with the types of furniture to be fitted, and aspects like floors and finishings. We tried to stick within the original Banner budget, and used the suppliers they had agreements with, but we chose different colours and different pieces to suit our tastes. We benefited because it was a bespoke property. If we hadn't got involved, we simply would have moved in and lived with what was there. We wouldn't have been able to afford to have changed things. But we're really delighted now.'

But some property experts fear more choice for buyers to display their individuality could harm their homes' resale value by narrowing their appeal.

'My advice is to avoid changing interior designs like the plague,' says Ed Lewis, a director of FPD Savills. 'Most building contracts are negotiated in such a way that developers don't have the flexibility to make late changes easily. And if you order 80 kitchens en bloc and then want a different one for a single customer, you may lose your economies of scale.

Even so, Lewis acknowledges that extra choice may help win advance sales. Worryingly, he says some homes look better on paper than when they are finished.

There's no doubting the good looks of St Michael's, a former public school at Limpsfield, Surrey, which has been converted into luxurious flats priced at between £400,000 and £500,000, plus one larger home selling for much more.

The developers, Charlwood Homes, have offered buyers of the first half of them a choice of carpets, wallpapers and tiles. 'It's been a nightmare for the site foreman, but we believe the buyers should have everything they want,' says Charlwood chairman Roger Sparks.

'If you're paying a lot of money for a place to live you deserve absolutely everything to be perfect.'

Contacts

Metropolis 020 7323 6991.
Banner 01628 536200.
FPD Savills 020 7730 0822.
St Michaels 01732 789700.

Dream home

Denham Place, Buckinghamshire, has impressive views over its formal gardens, plus beautiful parkland and woodland. Handy for London, it is situated within the M25. The Grade 1-listed country house includes 55 acres and five cottages for approximately £6.5 million.

Real world

Bury St Edmunds in Suffolk has a busy, twice-weekly market, a zoo and a theatre.

A two-bedroom house in a Victorian terrace sells for up to £100,000, depending on its distance from the town centre. Three-bedroom semis to the west generally fetch about £140,000. Larger homes rarely come on the market, says local estate agent Ray Call. He believes they must be passed down generations.

webTitle: Tell me the old, old story

fields.headline: Tell me the old, old story
fields.standfirst: People over 50 find it harder to get jobs. Why? Employers talk frankly to Nick Gillies  and  Neasa MacErlean  about the last legal bastion of bias
fields.trailText: People over 50 find it harder to get jobs. Why? Employers talk frankly to Nick Gillies and Neasa MacErlean about the last legal bastion of bias
fields.body:
Ageism is one of the least explored facets of working life. We all know it is harder to get a job when you are older, but we do not really know why. Few employers will publicly admit to ageism, so The Observer asked a range of people involved in recruitment about their attitudes to older people.

'Young PR girls are enormously enthusiastic and will go running around like loonies to put in the extra mile,' says David, 50, a public relations consultant. 'Older employees don't seem to put themselves out as much. Occasionally I go to an educational function in the evening, and it is very noticeable that most of the audience is very young. It's probably a family thing. We want to get back to our families, but the young girls will combine work and social lives, and go out for a drink later.'

Anna, a 26-year-old PR consultant, is a good example of this attitude. She works in a company staffed mainly by women of her own age. She has friends who are becoming managing directors in other consultancies by the age of 30. But when they are older they might fall out of the labour market for a while: 'Most of us don't see ourselves as being in a nine-to-five job for the rest of our lives. There are so many options, such as travelling abroad.'

Frank Eve, 51, product strategy director of internet mortgage company E-loan, has a different, and more worrying, take on the difference between older and younger employees: 'The older you are, the more difficult it is to accept and adapt to change.'

Perhaps this is true. Learning has always been associated with youth - learning to drive, learning a new language. Although many older people surf the web, people who buy financial services through the internet are most likely to be in their thirties.

When Eve got his first job, his father congratulated him on the excellent pension scheme he was joining - which shows how different priorities were for that generation. Today, Eve is the oldest of the 50-strong team at E-loan, but he insists the company is not ageist: 'It is very important for a dotcom that people fit culturally. This is not an ageist thing, but a state of mind.'

Very few older people applied for work at its Redhill offices - perhaps selecting themselves out of a hi-tech business. Eve and his fellow directors set no age requirements, but do want people who adapt to change. Eve believes the proportion of older people in the workplace is set to grow: 'People coming through now will be more flexible in their approach to employment - more motivated by opportunity than by security.'

Michael, a company director, has just taken on a secretary nearly 15 years older than himself. Although he is clearly not ageist - insisting that he looks for people who want to continue learning, regardless of their age - he still notices age issues. 'I don't like it when people send in CVs without their ages on them. I do notice. I think that maybe they are embarrassed by their age.'

In an interview, he may be more worried by an older person who is still hopping from job to job every two years; a twentysomething doing the same may just have yet to put down roots. 'We might delve more deeply into their motivation. Most employers still want people who will stay at least two years. In an interview, older applicants have to present themselves as flexible and willing to learn.'

Losing touch with new developments can happen at all levels. One healthcare specialist bemoans the way surgeons over 50 are more likely to lag behind younger colleagues in their handling of new technology. A report in the Government's Labour Market Trends magazine in July 1998 highlighted a watershed: 'The age of 50 appears to be a turning point after which people find it more difficult to return to the labour force if they become unemployed or leave work for other reasons.'

They are more likely to suffer poor health: 17 per cent of men aged 45 to 49 suffer from long-term health problems, says the same report, compared with 27 per cent of men aged 60 to 64. The over-fifties are more likely to see redundancy as a way of taking early retirement. They put less effort into finding another job, and use 'fewer methods of job search'.

The incidence of ageism varies hugely from sector to sector, and between the employed and self-employed. The notoriously ageist IT industry will often pay 'a huge amount of money' to older self-employed consultants whom they would never consider putting on the payroll, says Louise Smith of JM recruitment consultants.

Ageism is 'rife' in banking, says Richard Lynch of the finance union Unifi. Between 5 and 6 per cent of bank workers are over 50, he says. Philip Marks, director of financial markets at Jonathan Wren recruitment consultants, says it is very hard for older people to get staff jobs: 'We're always told that older people can't handle the technology and can't keep up with the hours. Employers often say they are investing in training and want someone with a long-term career.'

Strangely, the high street banks were all founders of the Employers' Forum on Age, and they all say they want a workforce with a wide span of ages. But by getting rid of older workers in redundancy programmes, they saved a lot of money. In this hierarchical world, older workers had built up plenty of long-service increments and were more expensive to employ. The pension costs of older workers are much higher in the traditional 'final salary' schemes that banks used to run.

A cynic might say the banks joined the forum to head off legislation on ageism by suggesting that they were solving the problem internally. If this was their plan, it worked. The Labour Party, once committed to outlawing ageism, introduced a voluntary code of practice when it came to power. This was 'a damp squib' in terms of effectiveness, says employment solicitor James Davies of Lewis Silkin. While there are Government commissions to fight racism, sexism and discrimination against the disabled, there is no such body to tackle age prejudice.

Whatever happens, ageism will not go altogether. 'Middle-aged men do like to have young good-looking girls around,' says David the PR. 'I don't say this factor has clinched any £100,000 deals, but it may work subconsciously.'

'George', a politician nearing 50, laughs at the suggestion that he would employ a researcher of about his own age: 'Politicians are quite insecure. It suits them to have younger people who they can dominate. It would be an unusually self-confident politician who would employ a researcher of the same age - someone who could contradict them.'

fields.headline: Nice motor. Dodgy brand
fields.standfirst:
Rover must again become a marque of distinction, writes Simon Caulkin
Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: When Phoenix trumped Alchemy to buy Rover from BMW for the princely sum of £10, there was a tidal swell of public approval. Alchemy, remember, planned to transmute the company into MG Cars, turning out mainly MGs and Rover 75s. Phoenix, on the other hand, was committed to pulling from the ashes of old Rover a new volume car producer, albeit making only around 200,000 cars a year.
fields.body:
When Phoenix trumped Alchemy to buy Rover from BMW for the princely sum of £10, there was a tidal swell of public approval. Alchemy, remember, planned to transmute the company into MG Cars, turning out mainly MGs and Rover 75s. Phoenix, on the other hand, was committed to pulling from the ashes of old Rover a new volume car producer, albeit making only around 200,000 cars a year.

Several months in, however, the resurrection project is proving hard work. With production stagnant, Rover still faces the mountainous task of transferring the 75 production line from Cowley, which BMW retains, to Longbridge.

But Rover's real problem is not producing cars - it is selling them. The issue is the brand.

There is much irony here. BMW is considered one of the world's savviest marketers. But while the Stuttgart firm spent many millions solving what it saw as product quality issues, it should arguably have been sending in its brandmeisters rather than its engineers. Look at Rover's sales performance. After the spectacular surge in April, when price cutting took the firm's market share to 13.5 per cent, the highest for years, in May it slumped to 4 per cent, much nearer the long-term underlying trend.

The figures are telling. The hard truth is that in April, consumers weren't buying Rovers out of a renewed love affair with the marque, nor even out of patriotism. They were buying them because they were cheap. In effect, says Thomas Bain of advertising agency Mountain View, they were purchasing BMW engineering at market-stall prices - nice for bargain-conscious car buyers, but a nightmare for the manufacturer.

'The market tells you the value of the brand by the price,' says Bain. 'It's the most important measurement.' In this case the verdict was damning: to the consumer the value of a Rover 75 is £15,000 or £16,000, irrespective of the fact that there is £29,000-worth of engineering inside it.

VW faces a similar situation with Skoda. These days, all cars have to be functional and reliable. Fundamentally, VW, Audi and Skoda, like Rover and BMW, are pretty similar under the skin. But the brands don't all have the same value (which is why Skoda may currently be the best value marque on the road). 'The battle isn't about the cars or their intrinsic quality - it's about what goes on between people's ears,' insists Bain. In Rover, 'BMW thought it was buying a strong brand - but it badly underestimated the extent to which it had lost the trust of the British public,' he says. 'It never figured out how to regain it.'

The danger for Phoenix is that the boat it finds itself in, although British-made this time, is as leaky as the previous German design. New Rover has made volume-driven promises about employment and the nature of the firm. But because of the weakness of the brand, to get the volume it has to discount heavily; and it is then hit by the second whammy of a further devaluation of the brand.

Really strong brands are hard to knock down - look at Apple, whose magic has remained untarnished throughout the long soap opera of its previous management excesses. Resurrecting a dodgy brand, however, is a different matter entirely. It certainly can't be done by fancy lifestyle advertising. This is fine when basic reliability and trustworthiness have been accepted by the consumer, but not where the goods themselves are perceived as damaged.

So what road ahead for Rover? One unlikely clue comes from export markets. Surprising as it may seem, Rover is chic on the Continent. In Paris, Milan, Munich and even Lisbon it has a cachet that clearly separates it from rivals, and is as different from its dowdy image in its home market as a Rolls is from a Lada.

Crucially, that cachet has to do with Britishness. Bain tells the story of an Italian businessman who (with a wobble or two in the Eighties) has always bought Jaguars. When his latest model arrived, he proudly flung open a door to show it to a visitor. 'Smell it!' he commanded, pointing to the leather and the wood. 'If German cars are taut and efficient, Italian ones exhibitionist and French individualistic, British cars are sumptuous!'

One option for Rover would be to give up pretensions to volume - at least initially - and play the 'British' card. Admitting that a UK-owned company is simply not able to produce volume cars as well and cheaply as other firms would be hard politically and a bitter pill for the West Midlands. But some observers believe a dose of realism could liberate the wounded Rover brand from this obsession. Then it would be free to think about its other, unbelievably neglected, assets: names such as Triumph, Austin-Healey and, yes, MG, which are known wherever people are interested in cars.

'All big successful companies leave niches for others,' says Bain. Indeed, their success is the biggest danger for their own brands - how far can you stretch the Mercedes or BMW names before they become irrevocably banal?

With consumers all around the world trading up and looking for difference, there is a respectable argument that going for niches is, far from an admission of defeat, the strategy for tomorrow. Funnily enough, of course, that was exactly where Alchemy came in. Brand chemistry rather than raking through old ashes may yet prove to be Rover's way forward.

webTitle: British bosses top of world misery league

fields.headline: British bosses top of world misery league
fields.standfirst:
Flabby, heavy drinking managers unhappier than Chinese and east Europeans, psychologist's study reveals
Special report: what is Britain?
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: British professionals are the most depressed and unhealthy group of managers in the world, according to a study carried out across the globe by academic psychologists.
fields.body:
British professionals are the most depressed and unhealthy group of managers in the world, according to a study carried out across the globe by academic psychologists.

Identified by their heavy drinking, poor diet, mental and physical flabbiness and - perhaps worst of all - sense of humour failure, there are a greater proportion of unhappy people in these islands than there are in countries such as Romania, Bulgaria, Taiwan and China.

The league table, prepared under the guidance of Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology at the Manchester School of Management at Umist (the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology), puts British managers bottom of the first world league table on physical health and job satisfaction, with only Bulgaria doing worse in the mental health section.

According to Cooper, the results are the early warning sign of broken families, unsustainable relationships and vicious bullying in decreasingly productive workplaces.

Although workers in the United States have many of the same problems as British managers, such as job insecurity, they do better in the tables, partly, says Cooper, because the US has developed stronger communities. Israel, in the top three for all measures of workplace happiness, has a well-established culture of flexible working balanced by an equally strong focus on family life, said Cooper.

'We have undergone enormous change. We were the country with the largest number of privatisations in the world in the 1980s. We Americanised quicker than any other country. From the shop floor to the top floor we are no longer secure ... we have fewer people doing more work and that applies to managers in particular.'

As well as having the longest working hours in Europe, Britain also has the highest divorce rate, along with Denmark. 'Communities have broken up,' said Cooper. 'We got on our bikes in the 1980s to follow jobs and that especially applies to managers who have lost their natural counsellors and support networks.'

Unless the relentless drive to squeeze more from fewer people is halted, business will suffer, believes Cooper. 'This study should be a warning sign. We are at the point where we need to stop and reflect on how we might restructure to be more productive. We have to work smarter instead of longer given that we have got to get more from fewer people in order to compete.

'People and businesses need to examine whether they can work some of the time from home. An entirely office-centred culture is patently unhealthy. Sitting on the M25 is not good for you.'

Along with overload has come a rise in office bullying. Managers who cannot cope become autocratic.

This is one of the signs that should act as a 'wake-up' call to companies, according to Alyssa Armstrong, head of corporate well-being services at Bupa, the private healthcare company which commissioned the comparisons.

Other signs are long-term sick leave increasing and high staff turnover. 'People are reluctant to say anything,' she admits. 'They hide the signs at first. You can be irritable and be drinking more yet still maintain a professional front at first. They don't want anybody to think they are wimps.

'The people I work with in companies ranging from regulatory bodies to PR agencies will only talk openly when they know their bosses will not find out.'

The Institute of Management's research manager, Karen Charlesworth, said middle-ranking executives got the worst deal of all. 'We find that they are under pressure from above and from below. Their directors want information and their juniors want advice. They say the three biggest causes of stress are deadlines, interruptions and lack of support. The trick is to learn how to say no, but nicely.'

 'I am at the end of my tether ... I have no life. We are like zombies '
Daniel Davids, 30, deputy manager in the retail sector:

'I have become so ill that I am leaving because they will not allow me any time out. I used to work 70-hour weeks in my last job and I loved it. I thought I could handle anything. The problem is when the company demands more and more from you and makes you feel as if you are not capable when you cannot deliver. I am at the end of my tether.

'You get to the point when you start believing that you are no good ... you just work longer and end up achieving less.

'I get up at 5am every day to get in to work by 8am. I don't eat a proper breakfast and I rarely eat a decent lunch. I get home at 9pm and all I'm fit for is a shower. I eat a bowl of cereal or soup. I have no life. We are like zombies at the weekend.

'The worst thing is, you start thinking the abnormal is normal.'

 'We have no time to think. It's sheer volume of work that creates the pressure'
Sarah Cook, 55, senior manager for a health trust:

'I love my job but the pressure has got worse and worse because we have been forced into organisational change so often. We are going to be dissolved as a body in March so I am trying to manage that process as well as maintaining the day-to-day running.

'My day starts at 5.30am and I get to work at 8am. After I've done the emails the days are pretty much back-to-back meetings which somehow I have to combine with being a visible manager, walking around and being approachable. There are demands from above and from below. People are frightened they will lose their jobs.

'We have no time to think or plan. It is the sheer volume of work that creates the pressure. I manage my stress by going to the gym, but the number of bottles of red wine I get through has gone up dramatically. All my colleagues say the same.'

webTitle: Log on to big deals from little lenders

fields.headline: Log on to big deals from little lenders
fields.standfirst: The  internet is allowing obscure mutuals to slay the mortgage giants.  Neasa MacErlean  reports
fields.trailText: The internet is allowing obscure mutuals to slay the mortgage giants. Neasa MacErlean reports.
fields.body:
If you want a good mortgage deal, consider one of the smaller building societies. Names such as the Derbyshire, the Market Harbor ough and the Stafford Railway are starting to crop up regularly in best buy tables.

When the Bradford & Bingley, the second-biggest soci ety, becomes a bank on 4 December, the number of societies will fall to 67. But many of those remaining are making a strong case for mutuality through their mortgage and savings deals.

The Bradford & Bingley has been widely criticised for sacrificing lower charges for members in the interests of future shareholders. Its standard variable rate mortgage, for instance, is now 7.64 per cent - significantly more than the 7.29 per cent charged by the Nationwide, the largest building society.

But if you really want a keen rate, try the Stafford Railway's rate of 6.99 per cent. On a £60,000 mortgage, you would be nearly £400 a year better off than with the B&B.

Stafford Railway, the 56th largest society, was formed in 1877 by a group of railway workers. It has assets of just £69 million, making it one fourteen-hundredth the size of Halifax Bank, the UK's largest lender with assets of £93 billion.

Stafford Railway director Peter Blocksidge says: 'We've always lent nationally. But the business that we got outside the area tended to come from people with Stafford connections - children of people who had a mortgage in the area. In more recent times, we've had greater exposure to newspapers and magazines.'

And, of course, the internet: the society has been a popular choice for people choosing a mortgage using the new website, E-loan. This site, launched in the new year, allows homebuyers to give their requirements, and get a list of deals that would best match them. Stafford Railway - which offers just one mortgage deal, its simple, no fees, 6.99 per cent variable rate - is listed frequently.

E-loan director Frank Eve says: 'If it wasn't for the site, consumers wouldn't know about this sort of smaller society at all. The site allows smaller societies to have internet capabilities.'

Many smaller societies already have their own websites, but these will not be visited much if the public has not heard of them.

Adviser London & Country Mortgages says business has been shifting towards small societies in the last three to four months. Spokesman Patrick Bunton said: 'Some of these relative tiddlers have become more competitive. Perhaps they think that they have got to get their message across better to survive. We are recommending them on a very frequent basis.'

In a best-buy table produced this month, London & Country listed 15 lenders, covering discounts, caps, flexible loans, fixed rates and trackers. A third were smaller societies.

The Chesham, for instance, was picked out for its 5.75 per cent two-year cap, rated the best on the market. The Chesham - formed in 1854 and the oldest society - has assets of £154m and three branches in prosperous Buckinghamshire. It was doing well, but decided two years ago to seek business nationally.

'The internet opens new doors for us,' says spokesman David House. 'From a standing start about 18 months ago, 30 per cent of our business is now generated outside the local area. We can demonstrate the benefits of mutuality. Something very important to us is good service. You have to be able to manage the service. You can get flooded with applications when you appear in a best-buy table.'

Other names regularly recommended by London & Country include the Universal, based in Newcastle, and regionally based societies such as the Cheshire, Derbyshire and Nottingham. Bunton says that their service is usually extremely good - and fast: 'If there are only two branches, the decision-makers are very close to the business. The culture tends to be much more customer-focused.'

Few of London & Country's clients are put off from taking a loan with a small society. Building societies are well-regulated and, after all, they are lending you the money rather than you depositing yours with them. E-loan believes the smaller societies can be extremely innovative. A small but dynamic society lending just £20m a year can easily monitor its new deals, make any changes needed and launch a loan aimed at only 100 homebuyers. Big lenders are far less nimble.

Many small societies realise what the internet can do for them. The Cheshire - highlighted by London & Country for its five-year fix, pegged at 6.45 per cent - plans to allow online mortgage applications within a couple of months. 'The internet is making it easy for customers to do business with us,' says director Frank Harrington. 'It has let smaller organisations do business on a wider basis.'

So perhaps it's 'so long Bradford & Bingley, hello Cheshire and Chesham'.

webTitle: Mutuality's alive - it just needs nurturing

fields.headline: Mutuality's alive - it just needs nurturing
fields.trailText: Standard Life's victory over carpetbagger Fred Woollard earlier this month might have been interpreted as a new dawn for mutuality. Despite some of the largest ever potential windfalls, policy holders voted to keep the insurer off the stock market. But events of the last week prove there was no real victory.
fields.body:
Standard Life's victory over carpetbagger Fred Woollard earlier this month might have been interpreted as a new dawn for mutuality. Despite some of the largest ever potential windfalls on offer - even allowing for the dispute between Standard Life and Woollard over the exact amounts - policyholders voted to keep the insurer off the stock market. But events of the last week prove there was no real victory.

Bradford & Bingley members voted overwhelmingly to let the organisation convert, releasing relatively modest windfalls. Equitable Life, a household name and once one of the most respected institutions in the investment business, put itself up for sale after being told by the House of Lords that it must honour pledges to pay guaranteed minimum pensions (see page 17). Scottish Provident, meanwhile, started a beauty parade to choose a buyer.

So last week's score in the conversion-versus-mutuality debate is three-nil, and in the insurance industry Standard Life is destined for corporate eccentricity in maintaining its status.

Being a mutual organisation is not itself a recipe for success. The absence of shareholders can release funds to enhance returns for customers, but if management is lukewarm about its status - as in Bradford & Bingley's case, where the case for mutuality was never put as forcefully as at Nationwide - or if it is forced to pay for a past misjudgment - as in Equitable's case - nothing can redeem the organisation.

Mutuality, as a form of corporate ownership, must pay its way. Among building societies, several organisations are attempting, with considerable success, to ensure that it does. Nationwide now regularly appears in best-buy tables, and the internet is proving to be a friend, rather than foe, to smaller societies who can use it as a cheap way to market their top-value products nationally (see page 6).

Last week, Skipton became the first society to pay a one-off cash bonus. It faced accusations of bribery to deter carpetbaggers, but faced with a windfall of its own, distributing it to members seems entirely fair.

Standard Life is launching a new bond, its first new product since the demutualisation battle, which looks as though it will outshine rivals for the returns on offer. (Standard Life's new with- profits bond will be reviewed in Cash next week.) This is one demonstration of how mutuality can pay but Standard Life, sniffy until now about the idea of giving one-off bonuses, should look closely at Skipton's move.

Mutuality is not dead, but it needs nourishment from the management of those organisations that are owned by their customers.

A niggle about Skipton's windfall distribution: there is some doubt about how the payments to borrowers will be taxed. Savers' payments will be taxed - if they are liable for tax. Skipton says 'less than a majority' will cough up because they have Tessas, Isas or are non- tax-payers - but it hopes borrowers will pay no tax.

This is what it is hoping, but Skipton is not certain that borrowers will pay no tax. It is arguing that the money is a form of interest discount. The society has kept the Inland Revenue informed of its plan, and its view, but the Inland Revenue famously refuses, always, to say yea or nay to any particular scheme until it has been put in place.

So there must be a risk its inspectors will get to work on Skipton borrowers' wind falls. It would be a pity if tax meddling makes it difficult for building societies to pay bonuses of this type. This is especially true given that windfalls on flotations have, for most people, been tax- free because they were dealt with under capital gains tax rules, which are kind to savers and borrowers of modest means.

Nationwide now regularly appears in best-buy tables, and the internet is proving to be a friend, rather than foe, to smaller societies who can use it as a cheap way to market their top-value products nationally (see page 6). Last week, Skipton became the first society to pay a one-off cash bonus. It faced accusations of bribery to deter carpetbaggers, but faced with a windfall of its own, distributing it to members seems entirely fair. Standard Life is launching a new bond, its first new product since the demutualisation battle, which looks as though it will outshine rivals for the returns on offer. (Standard Life's new with- profits bond will be reviewed in Cash next week.) This is one demonstration of how mutuality can pay but Standard Life, sniffy until now about the idea of giving one-off bonuses, should look closely at Skipton's move. Mutuality is not dead, but it needs nourishment from the management of those organisations that are owned by their customers. A niggle about Skipton's windfall distribution: there is some doubt about how the payments to borrowers will be taxed. Savers' payments will be taxed - if they are liable for tax. Skipton says 'less than a majority' will cough up because they have Tessas, Isas or are non- tax-payers - but it hopes borrowers will pay no tax. This is what it is hoping, but Skipton is not certain that borrowers will pay no tax. It is arguing that the money is a form of interest discount. The society has kept the Inland Revenue informed of its plan, and its view, but the Inland Revenue famously refuses, always, to say yea or nay to any particular scheme until it has been put in place. So there must be a risk its inspectors will get to work on Skipton borrowers' wind falls. It would be a pity if tax meddling makes it difficult for building societies to pay bonuses of this type. This is especially true given that windfalls on flotations have, for most people, been tax- free because they were dealt with under capital gains tax rules, which are kind to savers and borrowers of modest means.

webTitle: A Portrait of the Artists as Young Men, Gilbert and George (1972)

fields.headline: A Portrait of the Artists as Young Men, Gilbert and George (1972)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artists: Gilbert Proesch (born Italy, 1943) and George Passmore (born Devon, 1942), who met as students at St Martin’s College of Art in 1967, formed themselves into the entity Gilbert and George, set up an office in Fournier Street, Spitalfields, east London, offering their services as “living sculptures” making “Art For All”, and have carried on making art together, being art together, still living in Fournier Street and, in their recent photoworks, appearing naked in oceans of blood and urine.

Distinguishing features: This is a very funny work of art. The title suggests all the bursting passions associated with youth: anger, energy, ambition, libido. But we don’t get any of that. Instead, this black-and-white video, which runs on a continuous loop, gives us a study in stasis. It begins with a title card bearing their royal-looking crest, as if this was the start of an old Gainsborough Studios film. The “action” begins. Gilbert and George pose, weakly and lifelessly. They just stand there, in bespoke suits and tight collars, moving ever so slightly, their faces impassive, their hair flattened. George feebly smokes a cigarette.

Of all Gilbert and George’s works, this is the one that most acutely raises the question of whether their works are “portraits”, in the sense of representations of a person that tell us who they are and what they are like. Does this artwork contain any personal information, or is the washed-out, superlit image a mask concealing nothing?

Gilbert and George have become celebrities on such a scale that it is sometimes hard to see their work at all. They are jokers, storytellers and the patron saints of contemporary British art. Like Andy Warhol before them, Gilbert and George present a flat, unemphatic image to the world and somehow, because of this emptiness, they become charged with meanings from the wider culture. Their art is porous to social history. Indeed, the best way to understand this artwork may be in relation to pop music.

The year in which this video was made, 1972, was the peak of Glam in pop culture and this is a Glam work of art. The ultra-stylised poses of Gilbert and George are those of self-con scious decadents, infinitely refined aesthetes, just like the image created by Roxy Music or David Bowie. Even the deeply shadowed, whited-out look of this video, which according to the artists’ instructions must be shown with the contrast unnaturally high, is the same blank aesthetic we see in the portrait of Lou Reed on the cover of his 1972 album Transformer.

The title of this work seems to be a joke. James Joyce’s A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man is a study of the development of an artist, of the experiences that make a sensibility. Gilbert and George on the other hand deny they ever “developed” at all. They simply became Gilbert and George one day in a convulsive change, instant and absolute. “We have never seen a young artist”, they said in an early manifesto.

A Portrait of The Artists as Young Men is about masquerade, play-acting, about becoming something other that what you were told you were. Gilbert and George assert the right not just to reinvent themselves but to resemble an alien life form. They are not hiding behind masks but assert that they are the mask, the “sculpture”. To be an artist for them is to be a kind of monster, a new species in the world. Like their contemporaries in pop, they liberate themselves by erasing the usual marks of human identity.

Inspirations and influences: This could be seen as a parody of the very minimalist, very serious, artists’ film of the 60s, exemplified by Michael Snow’s Wavelength (1967), in which the camera zooms in slowly on a patch of wall. Gilbert and George take the deliberate tedium of minimalist film and make it a joke. In this they have a lot in common with conceptual artists such as John Baldessari and William Wegman, who used badly made video art to mock art’s claim to seriousness.

Today, young artists are returning to this cruder, funnier age of video. An artist whose works resemble this piece is Hilary Lloyd, who makes video portraits of apparently passive, vacuous young people.

Where is it? Tate Modern, Bankside, London SE1 (020-7887 8000).

fields.headline: Asking all the right questions
fields.standfirst: Philosopher Stephen Law tells Mel Steel why children are natural thinkers
fields.trailText: Philosopher Stephen Law tells Mel Steel why children are natural thinkers
fields.body:
"I've always been struck by how philosophically minded children are," says Stephen Law. "They ask questions and they get an answer, and behind that answer they find another question to ask, and it doesn't take long before they're starting to question some of our most basic and fundamental beliefs. If you repeatedly ask 'Why?', it's not long before you're really hitting philosophical bedrock."

The thought of dealing with philosophical bedrock at bedtime might be many parents' idea of hell; but philosophy lecturer Law believes in getting them while they're young. His first book, The Philosophy Files, goes straight to the heart of some of the most vexed questions there are to ask: What's real? Where do right and wrong come from? How do I know the world isn't virtual? Should I eat meat? And not forgetting: Does God exist?

Accessible, entertaining, and plentifully illustrated by Daniel Postgate, the only question it doesn't tackle head on is why nobody's written a book like it before. Unlike Jostein Gaarder's Sophie's World or Alain de Botton's The Consolations of Philosophy, this is no dinner-party roll call of the great and the dead. It's philosophy in action rather than philosophy in aspic.

What Law shares with Gaarder and de Botton, though, is the irresistable impulse to popularise. "Which is considered to be career suicide," he says. "At least that's what I've been told. But then I'm not particularly ambitious in the sense of working my way up the academic ladder. I mean, the average philosophical journal article is read by a total of eight people. And while I do write journal articles, I don't think that's going to change the world, really. Whereas a book can, in some subtle but important way, change people's lives. And I do passionately believe that it's important that people think about these big questions in the course of their everyday lives. Moral questions, especially. It's slightly depressing, I think, if you live in a society where people don't."

He's been interested in the big questions for as long as he can remember, he says; but it took him a while to figure out that repeatedly asking "Why?" might actually amount to a legitimate occupation. Academia wasn't alien to him - he grew up in Cambridge, and his father had a doctorate in sociology - but he messed up at school, thought he'd blown any chance of further study, and had no idea that philosophy existed as a subject in its own right.

The first time he embarked on A-levels, he says, he was asked to leave - "basically because I was lazy and good for nothing. I don't blame them at all". A year or so later he tried another subject combination at another college, but found himself too irritated by the exam-oriented mentality of the syllabus to see it through. "You weren't allowed to do anything other than regurgitate," he says, "when what I really wanted to do was ask the questions."

So, after a couple of brief spells as a sand-blaster and damp-proofer, he settled into four years as a postman in Girton, just outside Cambridge. He was the only one on the job who never got a Christmas tip. "I wasn't a very accurate postman," he concedes now. "In fact I was a very bad postman. Possibly the worst postman Girton ever had."

But those four years gave him a lot of time to think, and to read. Left to his own devices, he consumed books. "One book would lead me to another, and then another, until eventually I ended up reading nothing but philosophy books. And I suddenly realised that that's what I'd always wanted to do - but that I'd never known what it was called."

He was 23: just old enough to qualify as a mature student, which meant that he didn't need A-levels after all. So he ditched the post office, bummed around India for a few months, and - "like a miracle" - was accepted to read philosophy at London's City University. Some of the papers he'd written for himself in the course of his reading helped persuade them that he was serious about doing a degree. Very serious, in fact. He got a gratifying first, went on to secure the coveted BPhil at Trinity College, Oxford, and then netted himself a prestigious junior research fellowship at Queen's, before taking up a teaching post at London University's Heythrop College four years ago.

It's precisely the maverick combination of passion, rigour, patience and sedition that makes Law such an engaging writer and teacher. But it's only now, reaping handsome praise for The Philosophy Files, that he's finally given up worrying that he might not be clever enough, posh enough or cynical enough to be a proper academic. "I did go through a major crisis of confidence at Oxford," he says. "I felt that I didn't fit into that mould particularly, and for a while I just couldn't produce any papers at all. But the fact is, I'm doing what I'm doing now because I enjoy it. It's good fun. I don't care any more what people think about me."

Now 39, he's delighted that the book he has been conjuring in his head for so many years - a real philosophy book for kids, which students and adults could enjoy too - finally exists. A kind of career suicide note with knobs on, complete with cartoons and dayglo cover.

"I wanted it to be an adventure in thinking of the sort I wish someone had written for me when I was younger," he says. "I would never have appreciated someone giving me a textbook which explained what Descartes had to say about this or what Plato said about that. But if someone had actually engaged me in my own language and on my own terms, talking about questions in the way that I wanted to talk about them at that age, then I would have lapped it up."

fields.headline: Comic tales
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on the latest in the Preacher series
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on the latest in the Preacher series
fields.body:
Preacher: All Hell's a-Coming
Garth Ennis, Steve Dillon and John McCrea
(Titan Books, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Volume 8 of the series now, and it still continues to surprise. Less of the supernatural, comic-book stuff, and more of what film people would call the back-story. It is too good, though, to be made into a film. What is clever about it is the way it seems to be absolutely consistent with what has happened before: either Ennis and Dillon worked this all out a long time ago, or they have very busy and productive plotting sessions.

We find out the nasty junkie past of one of the characters (Cassidy, the alcoholic Irish vampire); and how Tulip got to be so good with a gun. Here she is finally reunited with Jesse Custer, the preacher with the cornball name and the voice of God. (He only uses it once in this volume, calling up a chat show in order to ask the pundits what it is they really want.)

The characters continue to be chipped away at: Custer lost his eye in the previous volume, having it sucked out of its socket by God. We lose pretty much all the sympathy we had for Cassidy, and Starr, the most powerful man in the world, having lost not only an eye, all his hair and a leg, now loses his genitals to an attack dog. "My cock is in the bitch's mouth," he says, "and not in a good way."

Steve Dillon and Garth Ennis don't give interviews, so let me speculate for them: about 10 years ago, Dillon, if I recall correctly, started up Deadline, a grown-up, regular comic riding on the back of the success of The Watchmen, Batman: The Dark Knight Returns, and all those other graphic novels that were supposed to signal the birth of a new, respectable art form. You got the feeling that Deadline was bought by about 12 people, but they hung on for a couple of years; it became obvious how hard it was simply to fill the pages with decent stuff. (The dreadful Tank Girl film was incompetently adapted from its star strip.)

One character, Hugo Tate, ended by emigrating to the States; I wonder if this gave Dillon an idea. You can imagine the Deadline experience - caring about intelligence and originality in a medium unusually resistant to both - depressing anyone; so Preacher represents a spiritual, if not an actual, relocation, a chance to wipe the slate clean. One recurring theme is how wonderful America is, what a great place it is to make a new start - romantic hogwash at direct variance with the facts, particularly if you are not white.

Still. It's a comic book, so you don't have to take it all that seriously if you don't want to; and to see such pie-eyed innocence, and indeed patriotic faith, in any narrative medium these days, particularly in this one, is itself something of a novelty. That said, the volume closes with a flash-back episode so outrageously anti-French that would land Ennis and co in some trouble were the slur directed at any other nationality.

Anyway, Ennis and Dillon have mastered the medium. They make almost all the other contenders look like amateurs, although the 2000AD stable continues, most of the time, to deliver the goods. How the Preacher series will end - one is led to presume a big, messy showdown with God - is something I very much look forward to seeing. But it is with the human stories that it works best.

(The dreadful Tank Girl film was incompetently adapted from its star strip.) One character, Hugo Tate, ended by emigrating to the States; I wonder if this gave Dillon an idea. You can imagine the Deadline experience - caring about intelligence and originality in a medium unusually resistant to both - depressing anyone; so Preacher represents a spiritual, if not an actual, relocation, a chance to wipe the slate clean. One recurring theme is how wonderful America is, what a great place it is to make a new start - romantic hogwash at direct variance with the facts, particularly if you are not white. Still. It's a comic book, so you don't have to take it all that seriously if you don't want to; and to see such pie-eyed innocence, and indeed patriotic faith, in any narrative medium these days, particularly in this one, is itself something of a novelty. That said, the volume closes with a flash-back episode so outrageously anti-French that would land Ennis and co in some trouble were the slur directed at any other nationality. Anyway, Ennis and Dillon have mastered the medium. They make almost all the other contenders look like amateurs, although the 2000AD stable continues, most of the time, to deliver the goods. How the Preacher series will end - one is led to presume a big, messy showdown with God - is something I very much look forward to seeing. But it is with the human stories that it works best.

webTitle: Guardian review: Kill Your Darlings by Terence Blacker

fields.headline: Author of his misfortunes
fields.standfirst: Writers are no heroes, as Terence Blacker reveals in Kill Your Darlings
fields.trailText: Writers are no heroes, as Terence Blacker reveals in Kill Your Darlings
fields.body:
Kill Your Darlings
Terence Blacker
Weidenfeld, £12.99, 292pp
Buy it at BOL

Chain-smoking doctors, melancholy comedians and profligate bankers: we have a certain fond sympathy for those who covertly fail to live up to the public images of their professions. For writers, and particularly writers of fiction, we might expect preternatural qualities of observation, description and empathy, possibly combined with a lofty disregard for mundane matters and the pleasures of the flesh. The truth, if we believe Terence Blacker's portrayal of a novelist about to drop off the edge of the literary map, is far less savoury.

Gregory Keays sits gloomily in his study amid a welter of abandoned projects, painfully aware that the glory days of the early 80s - when his acclaimed novel Forever Young gained him a place on Granta's celebrated list of the Best of Young British Novelists - are far behind him. Nowadays, he has trouble getting past chapter three, and it seems clear that A/The/Until (his experimental novel), Mind the Gap (his London novel) and Glitter (his "tawdry attempt at 1980s populism") will never see the light of day, let alone the Amazon Top 100.

Next on the stocks is the aptly named Insignificance , but more pressing hack work - compiling a book of Literary Lists ("Top Five Peculiar Erotic Habits of the Great Writers" and suchlike highbrow trivia), conducting interviews for The Professional Writer and teaching a class of scribbling hopefuls at the local adult education college - always seems to impede his progress. Even daily writing workouts and affirmations ("Today I am a sailor crossing the mighty swell of an ocean") are unable to persuade the slumbering beast of Keays's talent to awake from its sleep.

What luck, then, when one of Gregory's students reveals not only a rare and precocious talent but also a homosexual crush on his teacher and suicidal tendencies. The ensuing plot involves plagiarism, intervention from the underworld in the form of criminal turned media darling Brian "Pussy" McWilliam and the promise of the unexpected rehabilitation of Gregory's career (much to the derision of his inordinately successful interior designer wife and morose teenage son). It is by turns fantastic, caperish, comic and, we are meant to believe, ultimately tragic.

These developments, however, slightly obscure Blacker's other purpose, which is to anatomise literary celebrity, exemplifying the nature of embittered rivalry by paying special attention to the phenomenon of "Everywriter" Martin Amis. Mart plays himself on these pages, turning up to afflict our hero with performance anxiety at a urinal, bedding the same publicity girl that Gregory seduces in the Excelsior Lincoln (just about vague enough to keep the lawyers at bay) and, most heinously, writing all Gregory's books before he himself has the chance.

When Amis reads affectingly from his forthcoming memoir at a literary festival, a horrified Gregory realises that, once again, he has escaped a career cul-de-sac ("He had become a chronicler of the human heart. Fuck. Fucking Martin had done it again"). However hard you try, there is no ignoring Amis.

All of this would have too much of the fanciful in-joke about it, were it not that Blacker's analysis is cruelly spot-on. For the third-rate, pitiably blocked writer who craves critical approbation, a stable of glamorous friends and lovers and massive advances, Amis probably is a kind of benchmark, with the glossy-mag profiles, complicated love life, teeth, snooker, fags and tennis providing much-needed local colour in the drab, pedestrian world of the below-par wordsmith. Rivalry, after all, is all the more poignant when one party is unaware of it.

As a study in self-delusion, Kill Your Darlings is effective, sharing some similarities with Iris Murdoch's tale of writerly pomposity and portentousness, The Black Prince. Its main flaw, perhaps, is that Blacker mugs too much for the camera in a sub-Craig Brownish sort of way, leaving the reader with the feeling that this was originally a comic sketch that got out of hand. That said, it's always worth pointing out that should you ever need a lesson in self-awareness, humility, graciousness and the importance of putting others before yourself, it would be wise to consult an armed robber or a tax consultant before ringing your favourite author.

fields.headline: Difficult legacies
fields.standfirst: Becky Clarke  on Portugal's former African colonies
fields.trailText: Becky Clarke on Portugal's former African colonies
fields.body:
The voices from former Portuguese colonies in Africa, Angola and Mozambique draw on a common heritage: the language of Portugal. But today's Lusophone African writers share a number of characteristics besides language. Many, for instance, have been instrumental in championing the plight of the marginalised masses. And besides having continually to skirt around constant surveillance by the authorities, writers in Lusophone Africa have had to confront the themes of the damaging effects of war, famine and economic mismanagement. The infrastructure for the printing and book publishing industries in Africa is, meanwhile, virtually non-existent.

However, some Lusophone African writers, in particular Mia Couto and Pepetela, have been able to build on support and encouragement from publishing houses in Portugal to create the beginnings of a global reputation. Other writers from Portuguese Africa, such as the Angolan Sousa Jamba (author of the acclaimed novels Patriots and A Lonely Devil), have found success by writing in English.

Couto, born in Mozambique in 1955, is considered the most prominent of the younger generation of writers in Portuguese-speaking Africa. In his novels and short stories, translated into various languages, Couto passionately and sensitively describes everyday life in poverty-stricken Mozambique. In O Ultimo Voo Do Flamingo (The Last Flight of the Flamingo), his latest novel, published by Caminho last month, Couto delivers yet another piece of ingenious literature - gripping and mysterious, yet never without humour. Couto's other books in translation include Voices Made Night, Every Man is a Race and Under the Frangipani Tree (out in English next year).

Talent comes aplenty in Mozambique, and these days it comes young, too. Born in Maputo in 1967, Nelson Saute is considered a rising star. Picked up by Lisbon-based publishers Dom Quixote on the strength of his book of short stories O Apostolo da Desgraca (The Apostle of Misfortune), he has just completed his first novel.

Pepetela, born in Angola in 1941, is the second author alongside Couto whom anyone interested in Lusophone African literature cannot ignore. His new book, scheduled for publication in Portugal later this year, describes the Lupi - "some strange creatures in the mountains". The Lupi are vegetarians who lead a calm life discovering nature. One day a purple pleasant-smelling liquid bubbles from a source in the ground. Little by little, the wise men discover its diverse capacities. Everything changes for the Lupi. Will they be able to resist? This is a real African fable with genuine modern application.

Another talented writer in the Portuguese African diaspora is Emmanuel Rui, born in Huambo in Angola. A novelist, songwriter, poet and columnist, Rui is renowned for his uncompromising stance. His forthcoming title Noticias do Huambo (News from Huambo) is due for publication in 2001. Rui's heroes are very often children and women fighting for survival.

One of the liveliest publishers of work from Lusophone Africa is the Porto-based Campo das Letras. Last year Campo published Arnaldo Santos's first novel A Casa Velha das Margens (The Old House on the Bank), the story of an Angolan immigrant's lonely studies in Lisbon during the 19th century and of the alienation he experiences on his return to Angola. This story, and the publisher's efforts to bring it to a wider audience, make for a resonant example of the richness and difficulty of the cultural heritage shared by Portugal and its former colonies.

 Becky Clarke is an editor for the Heinemann African Writers Series.

webTitle: The land where everyone's a poet

fields.headline: The land where everyone's a poet
fields.standfirst: Liz Calder  celebrates Brazil's hidden talents
fields.trailText: Liz Calder celebrates Brazil's hidden talents
fields.body:
Unless you have been locked in a darkened cupboard since January, you can hardly have missed the explosion of Brazilian music, theatre, dance, art and film which has marked the celebrations for Brazil's 500 years of history as a nation. Yet among this torrent of creative energy there has been only one literary event. One of the reasons for this is that very few Brazilian books have been translated into English, while the impact of those that have is slight. Yet there is a storehouse of literary riches there; indeed, the country has produced some of the greatest writers of all time.

In Brazil the word for poet is sometimes used as a term of endearment, as in "How are you, my poet", although the person addressed may never have written so much as a couplet. Yet there is a long line of magnificent real poets, from Manuel Bandeira and Carlos Drummond de Andrade to Vinicius de Moraes and João Cabral de Melo Neto, who are up there in public esteem with Pele (well, almost).

However, there are two writers who tower above the rest; neither was a poet. The first of these is Machado de Assis (1839-1908), who is held by many to be not only Brazil's greatest writer but on a par with Henry James, Flaubert and Hardy. While his enchantingly digressive style, sly humour and merciless exposure of hypocrisy and pretentiousness have endeared him to Susan Sontag, Salman Rushdie and Louis de Bernières, among many others, his own work stems directly from Tristram Shandy.

Of mixed race, epileptic, an orphan, half-educted and myopic, Machado never left Rio de Janeiro, but worked as a civil servant while writing an enormous amount of every kind of literature. His output included four masterpieces of fiction, Don Casmurro, Philosopher or Dog?, Counselor Ayres' Memorial and, perhaps the most captivating, Epitaph of a Small Winner. The first chapter contains the jaunty announcement: "I am a deceased writer not in the sense of one who has written and is now deceased, but in the sense of one who has died and is now writing." Shades of Will Self? Elizabeth Hardwick declared that "in the sureness of pace, the ingratiating swerve, Machado is peerless", and that he shares with Borges that "wonderful musky perfume of the library". But no dust.

The other literary giant is Euclides de Cunha, whose epic Rebellion in the Backlands has been compared to the Seven Pillars of Wisdom. It tells of the year-long resistance of the backlands people to a brutal army campaign against the religious mystic Antonio Consolheiro and his followers in the interior of the state of Bahia. It is filled with drama, humanity and spiritual wisdom, together with dazzling descriptions of people and place. Picador has it in the excellent Travel Classics series.

At a different level, but recognised as outstanding writers internationally, are Graciliano Ramos, whose cinematographic version of Barren Light can be seen at the NFT at the moment, João Guimãres Rosa, the Brazilian equivalent of James Joyce, and Clarice Lispector, who is often compared to Virginia Woolf and Katherine Mansfield. Two other names can be mentioned in the same breath: Mario de Andrade, author of Macunaima, and Lima Barreto, author of The Patriot.

The two writers best known outside Brazil are Jorge Amado, the hugely popular chronicler of life in Salvador in Bahia (Gabriela, Clove and Cinnamon and Dona Flor and her two Husbands), and Paula Coelho, a worldwide bestseller. Other superb writers available in English are the darkly brilliant novelist Rubem Fonseca and the master of the short story Dalton Trevisan, plus Darcy Ribeiro, João Ubaldo Ribeiro, João Gilberto Noll, Chico Buarque, Ana Miranda and Patrícia Melo. Many more are not available but should be: Raduan Nassar, Moacyr Scliar, Milton Hartoum and Bernardo Carvalho foremost among them.

It is surely now time for more publishers to step forward and bring these and many other writers to the attention of the English reading public, so that we can share more of this extraordinary country's riches than its music and its football.

 Liz Calder is publishing director of Bloomsbury.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Regret without sentimentality makes for an arresting read, Dance Night, The Resurrection Club and Flight Paths Of The Emperor
fields.body:
The Harvest
Christopher Hart
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

The anguish of Lewis Pike, hero of this intense debut, is a welcome slap in the face to the flimsy anxieties of modern urban literature. From the opening paragraph, as he tracks Pike laying mole traps in a wintery field, Hart maps out a strikingly brutal world. We see Pike, an unemployed 17-year-old, at home in the paths and fields that his grandparents followed - but his place in a countryside populated by incomers charmed by farm labourers' cottages and country customs is doomed. Hart's portrait of rural tragedy respects its link to Hardy, but leavens the solemnity with touches of comedy. Regret without sentimentality makes The Harvest an arresting read.

Dance Night
Dawn Powell
(Steerforth, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Lamptown, Ohio, is the distillation of small-town dreams of escape and the bitterness that festers in those who stay put. First published in 1930, Powell's novel portrays a factory town populated by young women, who hope that the passing freight trains will unload a husband and a chance to reach the big city. Morry, son of the owner of the Bon Ton Hat Shop, and Jen, an orphan adopted by saloon-keeper Bill Delaney, watch the whisperings and regrets of the town's inhabitants while plotting their own ways out. It is a timeless story, and the motifs of trains rushing past, dance-hall dreams and females longing for romance is delicately realised, in prose that has not aged.

The Resurrection Club
Christopher Wallace
(Flamingo, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Wallace's attack on the hype of the Edinburgh festival, the vacuity of PR and performance art is a deliciously wicked, clever entertainment that adds its own comic-horror layer to the Burke and Hare tradition. Pablo Dextrus has created the ultimate must-see show, "Proscribed", place and time to be revealed only to those who scan the small ads and return a questionnaire. Through memos from Edinburgh lawyers, the recollections of a PR consultant and an interview given by audience-member Daniel Lowes, we discover how Dextrus's Situationist event gets out of control. Wallace keeps his satire darkly gripping.

Flight Paths Of The Emperor
Steven Heighton
(Granta, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

"A man away from home has no neighbours" is the title of one of these 14 stories: it provides a unifying theme for a collection that deals with the cultural and historical collision between North America and Japan, but suggests that the two will remain unreconciled. Loosely structured around a Canadian teacher at an Osaka language school, the book also includes the poignant tale of an American father taking his child back to her mother's birthplace in Japan, and stories of internment and war. Heighton's writing is rich in detail and deals with the spectres of Hiroshima and Pearl Harbour while keeping the essence of good story-telling.

webTitle: Guardian Review: The Crossing by Luís Cardoso

fields.headline: Sonnets and Mausers
fields.standfirst: Timothy Mo  on East Timor's struggle for independence
fields.trailText: Timothy Mo on East Timor's struggle for independence
fields.body:
The Crossing: A Story of East Timor
Luís Cardoso, trans Margaret Jull Costa
Granta, £9.99, 155pp
Buy it at BOL

In the last, and then apparently forlorn, years of the East Timorese resistance against the Indonesian army, the Falintil guerrillas survived on superlative bushcraft. With only two cartridges in their pouches and the last meal a memory of days, they had to. An Australian journalist who was smuggled into the mountains to interview Xanana Gusmao recollects his bodyguards freezing as a patrol went by. Taking his eyes off his guides for a second, he found them invisible when he looked again, before descrying them as so many creepers twisted round tree trunks or snakes gone to ground.

One passage in this beautifully written memoir finds Luís Cardoso's new companions, Mali Mau and Domingos, trying some mountain magic in the wilderness of suburban Lisbon. They have come from a building site and are complete strangers to the intellectual young Cardoso, but they recognised his island features at once. There has been a downpour; they are lost. "Rain-fila," ejaculates Mali Mau (a trick the land plays on intruders to make them lose their way).

There is only one thing for it: they strip off quite naked and put on all their clothes back-to-front. It works, sort of. The waiting bus-driver, "armed with a stick in case anything even stranger should happen", refrains from asking "for a pass with a matching back-to-front photo", and drops them at their lodging, a five-storey, elevator-less tenement echoing with the strains of a Brazilian TV soap and populated by waifs and strays (six to four beds) from the disintegrated Lusophone empire.

The East Timorese resistance was always as much a war of media sleight of hand, of words and wiles, as it was of bullets and bravery. All the leaders were ex-seminarians from the hill at Dare, in love with poetry and the latest ideas from Europe. Nicolau Lobato, the legendary Timorese general, killed in 1978, was the son of the catechism teacher Master Narciso from the same town, Soibada, as Cardoso"s father. (Cardoso senior was a rural paramedic, not above administering himself a shot of penicillin in the buttocks.)

Cardoso remembers the heroic Lobato (fictionalised in my own 1991 novel, The Redundancy of Courage, as Osvaldo Oliveira) as "severe, introverted"; he "dressed almost monastically, read voraciously and wrote in a firm hand with a fountain pen... he always walked through Dili with a book under his arm... apparently deep in thought as if he had found an internal oasis and had decided to stay there." This noble, ruthless and also ambitious man would be tortured to death by the Indonesians.

"Xanana" (Jose Alexandre) Gusmao, the charismatic soldier-politician who picked up the torch from Lobato and still holds it, is remembered by Cardoso spread-eagled on the ground at peacetime soccer matches: a seminarian goalkeeper "too busy making up sonnets to actually stop any goals". A decade later, Gusmao will write a sonnet to his Mauser, a 1914 vintage bolt-action rifle much favoured by the Falintil over Nato-era automatic weapons: its effective range of more than 1,000 metres conferred a greater chance of survival on the firer.

The Crossing takes us from Cardoso's early childhood in East Timor (those pages redolent with the fragrance of sandalwood on the Dili dock) to early manhood and the intoxication of Afros, Cuban heels and Marx, and then the severance of exile, with the mournful notes of fado hanging in the back-alleys of Lisbon.

Cardoso is not a political seer but the genuine article, a true creative writer - usually a beautiful but useless thing, but in the context of Timor a potent shaper of cultural identity and a reconciler. He has been well served by his translator, who has kept the Lusophone flavour in idiomatic English, and by Jill Joliffe, whose introduction is a fine piece of literary exegesis.

This book joins the plethora of literature on East Timor. Much of it is excellent, including the journalism. Jose Ramos-Horta, the former Fretilin foreign minister in exile (like Cardoso, he survived because he was caught overseas when the Javanese invaded in 1975), has himself published memoirs, but Jose - whom I bought an oyster supper in Sydney in 1991 - will not be offended if I say his forte is as a political analyst, not, like Cardoso, as a prose stylist.

And what an analyst. I've never seen this recorded anywhere, but it deserves to be: at the height of the Suharto economic boom, with the iron heel of the military on the entire archipelago, Xanana captured that very month, Jose predicted to me over the Chardonnay and shells that his country would win its independence "in the next ten years". He said Falintil could not hope to win a military victory on the ground, only to keep the flame alive. Timorese independence would come as the result of a general Indonesian economic collapse - "you can't have all that corruption and not have a disaster in the end". It all came true.
