fields.headline: Voyages from Lisbon
fields.standfirst: The empire strikes back with a wave of Portuguese literature from around the world
fields.trailText: The empire strikes back with a wave of Portuguese literature from around the world
fields.byline: Gary Pulsifer  and  Daniela de Groote
fields.body:
Last month's Lisbon Book Fair came as something of a shock. Used as we were to the sprawling trade book fairs of Frankfurt, London and Book Expo in the US, the Lisbon fair - held outdoors in the Eduardo VII park with its yellow huts and blossoming jacaranda trees - was a world apart from the usual hustle and commercial hype. Our visit was funded by the Portuguese Arts Trust, a London-based organisation engaged in raising the profile of Portuguese arts in Britain, and our goal was to find out as much as possible about the current post-colonial, post-Salazar literary scene there.

Not many people, perhaps, would view Portuguese as one of the major world languages. Yet it is spoken in Brazil, India (in Goa), East Timor and the African countries of Mozambique, Guinea Bissau, Angola and Cape Verde, following in the steps of Portuguese explorers and colonials. This legacy stretches as far as Macau, recently handed back to the Chinese authorities. It was here, so the legend at least goes, that the great poet of Portuguese navigation Camões is said to have written part of his wonderful epic The Lusiads. First published in 1572, this is one of the greatest poems of the Renaissance, mythologising a number of Portuguese voyages, including the story of Vasco da Gama's journey to India.

As was the case in English with Rushdie and others in the 1980s, the empire is now "striking back" with a late efflorescence of literature from the former colonies. Many of these were handed back - with indecent and clumsy haste - only after the fall of the Salazar dictatorship in 1974. Today, over 200m of the world's population speak Portuguese, and the numbers are rising - so it is a language and a culture to be reckoned with.

Arcadia, our own young publishing house, had yet to publish anything Portuguese, although we had dipped our toes into Portuguese waters by publishing the American novelist Richard Zimler's historical thriller The Last Kabbalist of Lisbon, a worldwide bestseller that first appeared in Portuguese. (Although written in English, it was initially turned down in the US and the UK; an adventurous Lisbon publisher, Quetzal, first took it on and turned it into a success in Portugal.)

The three weeks of the fair are vital for Portuguese publishers and their authors. José Saramago, the grand old man of Portuguese letters and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1998, was there, as were a wave of younger writers such as José Eduardo Agualusa, an Angolan prize-winning novelist now based in Rio; Pepetela, another Angolan writer, whose book O Desejo de Kianda will be published by Heinemann in their African Writers series; and Mia Couto, from Mozambique, one of the more widely translated and read of Africans writing in Portuguese. Serpent's Tail will publish his novel Under the Frangipani Tree next spring.

While Portuguese literature is slowly becoming more widely published in English - especially by independent houses such as Bloomsbury, Carcanet and Peter Owen - and also in French (Portugal was the main theme of this year's Salon du Livre, the Paris Book Fair), foreign fiction is still far more widely translated into Portuguese than vice versa. But there are other types of cross-cultural fertilisation.

Two of Arcadia's authors, Richard Zimler and the Dutch novelist Tessa de Loo, live in Portugal, as does Robert Wilson, author of A Small Death in Lisbon. After Lisbon we went to Porto, where we had dinner one evening with novelist and Chatwin biographer Nicholas Shakespeare (John Malkovich was filming Shakespeare's novel The Vision of Elena Silves there); shortly after our trip, Shena Mackay was in Lisbon for the publication of her novel The Orchard on Fire.

On the indigenous scene, established publishers are bringing out a wealth of Portuguese writing. At the fair we had an impromptu meeting with the editorial director of Dom Quixote, whose star authors include Lídia Jorge, Portugal's best-known woman writer (also published in the US), and Mário Claudio, a prize-winning novelist, essayist and poet from Porto, whose most recent novel Ursamaior details a notorious real-life killing.

Two publishers are housed in the Barrio Alto, a maze of narrow streets and small tiled houses. Contexto Editora is the publisher of Rita Ferro, whose bestselling fiction has been compared to the films of Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar, and of Paulo Castilho, currently the Portuguese ambassador to Sweden, whose novel Fora de Horas has won three major literary prizes. Livros Cotovia, a fine top-quality literary house, has on its list Pedro Paixao, whose quirky short stories deal with love and the pain of separation.

Like Campo das Letras, Edições ASA, Portugal's leading literary house, is based in Porto. Managing director Manuel Alberto Valente singles out the writer José Riço Direitinho as "one of the most serious and promising Portuguese writers for some time". His award-winning book Breviáro das Más Inclinações has been published in several European languages.

Other prominent houses include Relogio d'Agua Editores and Editorial Caminho, publisher of the Cape Verdean writer Germano Almeida, whose Os Dois Irmaos describes the killing of one brother by another. A final sum in the literary equation is the important role of the translator in making foreign fiction known in Britain. So it seems fitting to hail Margaret Jull Costa, who has just been awarded the Weidenfeld Translation Prize 2000 for her translation of Saramago's All the Names (Harvill).

We came away with a far better understanding of Portuguese literature - and a desire to publish some of this vibrant writing ourselves. Meanwhile, look out for two new publications, The Crossing by East Timorese writer Luís Cardoso and The Tragedy of the Street of Flowers by Eça de Queirós, published next month (Dedalus). A new edition of de Queirós's English Letters will be published by Carcanet in November: he was consul in England from the late 1870s. In its Aspects of Portugal series, Carcanet also publishes a wide range of classic texts, including work by Camões and the other doyen of Portuguese poetry, Fernando Pessoa (1888-1935).

A strange, fascinating character, Pessoa wrote in radically different styles under a wide variety of names. Whether modernist, psychological (multiple personalities) or even occult, his literary masks looked backwards to a romantic tradition and forward to today's era of richly proliferating Portuguese identities worldwide. As Cyril Connolly wrote: "Pessoa hived off separate personalities like swarms of bees... I have sought for his shade in those Edwardian cafés in Lisbon which he haunted, for he was Lisbon's Cavafy or Verlaine."

 Readers who would like to learn more about contemporary Portuguese writing should request a copy of the magazine Exchanging Words, available from the Portuguese Arts Trust, tel 020-8748 0884

fields.headline: The Water Tower
fields.trailText:
If a drilling rig clanked inland
and made a stand
in some corner of a barley field...
fields.body:
If a drilling rig clanked inland
and made a stand
in some corner of a barley field -

its elephant legs

and pendulous cable-guts
cleaned up and bleached and thinned

by the massage of a summer wind

to four stocky struts,
its platform also stripped

to a whitewashed cell

with eyes turned everywhere at once -
if such a thing were possible

or worth imagining,
this water tower would be the best result.
Or maybe it dropped in from outer space.

Or then again maybe
its white and height are really like
a lighthouse that the sea

shrank back from then forgot.

That doesn't matter any more.
What does is how,

some forty years ago and recently

arrived to settle hereabouts,

I made this tower the furthest

fixed point of a walk

and stood where I am now,
four-square inside the circle

of its influence, and thought

these fields of silver-whiskered barley,

dog-rose hedges, gravel lanes

ash- and beech-tree spinnies

where the roe-deer live their secret lives,

would never seem so nearly

elements which made a grand design

if not for this: incomprehensible

and silent at the heart of things.

Except the silence broke.

It's over there! that's what I heard -

a joke against the ear

as if a bird had spoken, or the air

rubbed hard enough against itself

to squeak - a joke

I put to rest by saying carefully:

there must be men at work

inside the tower. It's over there!

The same words tumbled down again,

by which I understood I must be due

for home,

so barely heard them as I made my way

along those gravel lanes.

These gravel lanes, I mean -

the same today as then, although

I'm killing time in just a visit now,

not life at home

and what was over there

I reached and passed

and moved away from years ago,

and still can't see - as like the wind

parading through the barley

while I leave the shadow of the tower

and finish here

as anything: a single cat's paw

dabbing gingerly one minute,

then a solid blow

which batters down the heads so far

I think they won't recover.

 Commissioned by the BBC as part of Poetry Proms, a new series broadcast on Radio 3 during the interval of every Wednesday's Prom.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Who would build a city like LA in an earthquake zone? plus Catastrophe
fields.body:
Ecology of Fear
Mike Davis
(Picador, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

Part the first: manifold real reasons why it was an insane idea to build any conurbation, let alone frail-framed, wood-walled, mega Los Angeles, in a tectonically unstable, totally inflammable region that alternates between drought and the flashiest of floods. (See also refs to twisters, chupucabra goat-eating vampires, and the 100 million mice that ate the oil town of Taft in 1926.) Part the second, and even better: an analysis of LA's destruction - or Blade Runner-ish disintegration - as gleefully imagined in more than a century of pulp fiction and movies: the tally includes 49 nukings, 28 earthquakes, and one obliteration each claimed by the Devil and Bermuda Grass. Dryly fab.

Catastrophe
David Keys
(Arrow, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

Explanation of the (presumed) AD535 Krakatoa/Sunda Straits volcanic eruption, the dust debris from which may - and may is the operative verb - have so deflected sunlight as to have darkened, dried and dearthed the Earth for a decade. Immediate result, as witnessed in chronicles and bio-archeological finds: world-wide collapse. The central American city-state of Teotihuacan fell apart like post-riot LA; steppe Avars drove out other nomads across Europe; Rome, weakened by plague, was overthrown, Arabia was primed for Islam. Final byproduct: world as we know it. Plausible in argument, epic in scope, flabbily written.

fields.headline: Big in SF
fields.trailText: Jon Courtenay Grimwood rounds up the latest releases
fields.body:
Newly created worlds have always been one of the big attractions of SF, but recognisable locations twisted out of shape can be just as effective, as Michael Moorcock proves with King of the City (Scribner, £16.99). The sequel to his Whitbread-shortlisted Mother London, this acerbic utopia presents a B-movie urban noir in which rock star/paparazzi photographer Dennis Dover mudlarks as a child in the Thames and as an adult trawls seedy London pubs where elderly gangsters kill time before retiring to the suburbs, unable to compete with corruption from the Square Mile.

Every famous name from the past 50 years is in here, historical characters rubbing shoulders with fictitious ones as real politicians destroy fictional lives and the Thatcherite cocaine excesses of the 80s give way to nu Labour and the tightly spun hypocrisy of the 90s. This is Moorcock at his funniest, wittiest and most deadly - with a furious rant about exactly what is wrong with London, Britain, America and the planet (and a few pertinent suggestions as to the cure).

Travel Arrangements (Gollancz, £9.99), the new collection of short stories from ex-New Worlds writer M John Harrison, presents an England where the dead offer you cups of tea, Soho couples wear axes in their heads as a fashion statement, investment bankers gather in trees like birds and the roads are deserted enough for lonely men to race cars down the M4 because the rest of society is inside, wired directly into pixel-perfect computer games.

Fragments of overheard conversation add an element of the bizarre to prose that is already coldly clean and resolutely clinical. Nothing makes sense, but then nothing is meant to. Reading Travel Arrangements is like eating poisoned chocolate.

Narrative precision and intelligence are not words usually associated with fantasy, but then China Miéville's Perdido Street Station (Macmillan, £16.99) is no run-of-the-mill fantasy novel. Set in the sprawling city of New Crobuzon, with its weird mix of weirder races, the plot revolves around disgraced academic Isaac Dan der Grimnebulin, all-round slob and unified field theorist, whose affair with artist Lin breaks several social taboos, largely because Lin has an insect for a head.

Having accidentally released a flock of rapacious killer butterflies on the city, Grimnebulin has to hunt them down with the help of a sibylline dimension-jumping spider obsessed with adding new samples to its scissor collection. For once, comparisons with Gormenghast are justified, not least in Miéville's refusal to make his characters heroic. The end has its own bleak honesty, totally at odds with most of this genre.

Buy King of the City at BOL

fields.bodyText: Newly created worlds have always been one of the big attractions of SF, but recognisable locations twisted out of shape can be just as effective, as Michael Moorcock proves with King of the City (Scribner, £16.99). The sequel to his Whitbread-shortlisted Mother London, this acerbic utopia presents a B-movie urban noir in which rock star/paparazzi photographer Dennis Dover mudlarks as a child in the Thames and as an adult trawls seedy London pubs where elderly gangsters kill time before retiring to the suburbs, unable to compete with corruption from the Square Mile. Every famous name from the past 50 years is in here, historical characters rubbing shoulders with fictitious ones as real politicians destroy fictional lives and the Thatcherite cocaine excesses of the 80s give way to nu Labour and the tightly spun hypocrisy of the 90s. This is Moorcock at his funniest, wittiest and most deadly - with a furious rant about exactly what is wrong with London, Britain, America and the planet (and a few pertinent suggestions as to the cure). Travel Arrangements (Gollancz, £9.99), the new collection of short stories from ex-New Worlds writer M John Harrison, presents an England where the dead offer you cups of tea, Soho couples wear axes in their heads as a fashion statement, investment bankers gather in trees like birds and the roads are deserted enough for lonely men to race cars down the M4 because the rest of society is inside, wired directly into pixel-perfect computer games. Fragments of overheard conversation add an element of the bizarre to prose that is already coldly clean and resolutely clinical. Nothing makes sense, but then nothing is meant to. Reading Travel Arrangements is like eating poisoned chocolate. Narrative precision and intelligence are not words usually associated with fantasy, but then China Miéville's Perdido Street Station (Macmillan, £16.99) is no run-of-the-mill fantasy novel. Set in the sprawling city of New Crobuzon, with its weird mix of weirder races, the plot revolves around disgraced academic Isaac Dan der Grimnebulin, all-round slob and unified field theorist, whose affair with artist Lin breaks several social taboos, largely because Lin has an insect for a head. Having accidentally released a flock of rapacious killer butterflies on the city, Grimnebulin has to hunt them down with the help of a sibylline dimension-jumping spider obsessed with adding new samples to its scissor collection. For once, comparisons with Gormenghast are justified, not least in Miéville's refusal to make his characters heroic. The end has its own bleak honesty, totally at odds with most of this genre. webTitle: Review: Dreaming of Strangers by Matt Thorne

fields.headline: Money for old rope
fields.standfirst: Helen Falconer  is rather dismayed by Matt Thorne's Dreaming of Strangers
fields.trailText: Helen Falconer is rather dismayed by Matt Thorne's Dreaming of Strangers
fields.body:
Dreaming of Strangers
Matt Thorne
Weidenfeld, £9.99, 243pp
Buy it at BOL

The author of this book is only 25, yet he's already published two novels (Tourist and Eight Minutes Idle) to cries of "Astonishing!" (Mail on Sunday), "Marvellous!" (The Times), "Glorious!" (Daily Telegraph). He's been shortlisted for the Encore Award, and his second novel has been optioned by FilmFour.

So why on earth has wonder boy dished up this appalling pile of garbage? I speak as one who has read all sorts of B-list literature, including much in the pleasant formulaic genre that Thorne is trying to rip off - girl-wants-to-meet-boy-and-discusses-it-endlessly-with-her-friends-in-pubs-and-cafés. Yet Dreaming of Strangers is undoubtedly, and I would say objectively, the worst novel I have ever come across.

The intriguing question is: why has he done it? I think I know. Being an acquisitive chap, he's noted that the above-mentioned genre - almost invariably written by women for women - generates massive sales. Then he's skimmed a few and decided it's money for old rope. He's bashed one out (how long did it take, Matt? A week?) and is now sitting back waiting for the millions to roll in. It's clear that he considers women readers so thick that they will read absolute trash providing it's about relationships.

Well, if they read this in any numbers I'll eat every single published copy of this review. I won't bore you with the plot, but let me give you a taste of what I mean. On page 188, Scarlett finally asks Becca to describe her affair with Chris. Becca replies: "Really, Scarlett, I'm going to disappoint you. You know how other girls can describe all kinds of details without getting embarrassed?" "Yeah." "Well, I'm not like that."

Dear oh dear - a novel about relationships in which the main girl doesn't like to talk about it! It's like being sold a murder novel without the murder. Nor is head-to-head analysis the only thing missing. We aren't told what characters look like, what colour their hair is, how tall they are, what they wear - no, that's unfair, Scarlett is once mentioned as looking "especially attractive today, wearing a flattering white top and a long skirt". And 28 pages from the end of the novel we are tossed a brief description of Becca from another character: "brown hair, medium height, pretty".

I know sex scenes are difficult, but surely the climactic one on the last page warranted slightly more effort than: "Chris and Becca made love twice that night, before and after a 2am trip to the supermarket. After the second time, Becca dropped off while Chris remained awake." We don't even get to know what they bought there.

Thorne has a lazy trick which he thinks covers up this startling dearth of detail: his characters constantly refer to the situations they're in as resembling specific film scenarios. I suppose he's hoping that if the reader doesn't know the film mentioned (he doesn't bother to describe the scenarios) then they'll blame their failure of understanding not on his impoverished writing but on their own uncool lack of knowledge. Fortunately almost every film quoted is mainstream (Sleepless in Seattle, When Harry met Sally), so I was just about able to follow the action.

I recommend that next time around this author should stop trying to pull a fast one and write about something worthwhile.

 Helen Falconer's first novel, Primrose Hill, is published by Faber.

webTitle: Guardian review: Democracy in Europe by Larry Siedentop

fields.headline: Disunited states
fields.standfirst: Robert Jackson takes issue with the assumptions on which Larry Siedentop has built Democracy in Europe
fields.trailText: Robert Jackson takes issue with the assumptions on which Larry Siedentop has built Democracy in Europe
fields.body:
Democracy in Europe
Larry Siedentop
Allen Lane, £18.99, 272pp
Buy it at BOL

The argument of Larry Siedentop's charming but superficial book is that because Europe is a state in the making, it deserves better than the "impoverished" constitutional debate it has been getting. His conclusion is that the right basis for the European Union should be "liberal constitutionalism", something like the United States' pattern. It would be better, he says, than any of the three models available in Europe: the French one, which is about "power"; the German one, which is about "authority"; and the British one, itiated by its "informality" and "idiosyncracy".

But is the European Union, in fact, a state in the making? Siedentop's fundamental mistake is to take for granted that what is emerging in Europe is a version of nation-state government. His explanation of why we should consider the EU as such a thing is embarrassingly thin - confined to a single page.

The book asserts that debate about the EU's constitution is "impoverished", but Siedentop's explanation - too much "economics", not enough "citizenship" - misses the obvious reason. The would-be European state is simply unreal. Siedentop does not mention the judgment of the German Constitutional Court on the Maastricht Treaty, which argued that it was questionable whether an alternative European democracy was possible in the absence of a European "demos" - a population which could act together.

The constitutional debates surrounding German federalism, the French Fifth Republic and the Spanish transition to a decentralised constitutional monarchy - none of them discussed by Siedentop - can hardly be said to be "impoverished". But then, Germany, France, Spain and Britain are real countries with real peoples and Europe is not.

What Siedentop describes as "the rapid accumulation of power in Brussels" is not about making a new state. It is almost entirely related to a single project, now largely complete, of removing legal barriers to the free movement within the Union of goods, services and people. First, this project is largely a negative one - the removal of barriers. Second, with the possible exception of the creation of a single money, the powers accumulated in Brussels are all of the third or second order of political significance - trade, agriculture, business regulation. And third, real power in the "integration" process (monetary union and the European Central Bank excepted) remains with the member states.

Europe's legitimacy, in short, is derived strictly from the legitimacy of the member states. That it will remain so seems confirmed by the response to Joschka Fischer's recent proposal for a European federal constitution - hostility or deafening silence from all quarters excepting President Chirac, who proposes as an alternative the intensification of the special relationship between the French and German states.

But will the creation of Emu lead to the creation of a European state? Siedentop assumes that it will - and many agree: both the integrationists, who believe that a single money cannot survive without an "economic government", and the anti-integrationists, especially in Britain, who fear that this is true.

But both may be wrong. Beyond the elementary rules of the common currency's Stability Pact - ceilings on public deficits and public borrowing - the success of Emu does not depend upon the same level of direct taxes in member countries and a system of transferring resources from rich to poor. History may well come to see Emu not as the decisive step towards European "federalism", but merely as the final step in the creation of the European single market.

But that makes Emu nothing more than the Gold Standard in modern dress. And if, meanwhile, most of what "Brussels" does is pretty small beer and the member states are always in the driving seat, what remains of Siedentop's emerging European state, crying out for its James Madisons, Alexander Hamiltons and Thomas Jeffersons? Precious little.

Having said all this, it is quite probable that, over the next few years, we will find ourselves called upon to agree to something which some may well call a European constitution. The "competences" of the different levels of European government will be fixed. The treaties will be tidied up. All this will be greeted with fanfares in some quarters and loathing in others. But the likely "European constitution" will just be a decking out in "European" clothes of what already exists. Meanwhile, the sinews of the European Union will be slackened by enlargement to 25 states, bringing with it another 100m "European citizens".

Running through Siedentop's analysis is the conviction that institutions build cultures. But what if the relation runs the other way - what if it is actually cultures that build institutions? Might not Siedentop's "idealism" then lead to the creation of institutions that are rejected by the cultures they purport to rebuild, or remain empty because they outstrip the reality of those cultures?

There is, however, little danger of this. "Europe" will remain what it always has been - a projection of the interests and concerns of its member states. Whether because they lack "idealism" or because they have had too much bitter experience of its dangers, there is, praise be, no sign of a people's revolt in Europe demanding that it become anything more.

 Robert Jackson is Conservative MP for Wantage.

webTitle: Guardian review: Tuff by Paul Beatty

fields.headline: Poetry in the projects
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi  acclaims Tuff - a tale of street politics from Paul Beatty, the bard of hip-hop
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi acclaims Tuff - a tale of street politics from Paul Beatty, the bard of hip-hop
fields.body:
Tuff
Paul Beatty
Secker & Warburg, £10, 259pp
Buy it at BOL

Paul Beatty won his first Grand Slam spoken-word contest in New York in 1990 and was hailed as "hip-hop's poet laureate". His relentlessly funny debut novel, The White Boy Shuffle (1996) - about the coming of age of "street stupid" Gunnar Kaufman, who is forced to wise up when he moves with his mother from suburban Santa Monica to "the hood" - fuelled his reputation as the bard of hip-hop.

Yet there is no label Beatty would wear without chafing against it. His new novel's hero, Winston "Tuffy" Foshay, explodes: "'Hip-hop community'? What the fuck is that?... Where the hell is the opera community? The heavy-metal community? How the hell you define people by the kind of music they listen to?" Even more telling is another character's definition: "Young urban African-Americans - preferably bald-headed." The neat, ironic swipe at facile reductionism reveals the subversive skill of Beatty's punch.

Winston is a 24-stone "player-king" to a hapless gang in Spanish Harlem, a new father and the "neighbourhood superpower" in a barrio where, on warm weekend nights, "bodies turned up in the streets like worms on sidewalks after an afternoon shower". But having escaped death in a Brooklyn drug den by fainting, he leaves with a gun, a pet goldfish and the resolve to "turn his life around" - to "break the cycle". Although his habitual expression is so full of "East Harlem inscrutable cool" that "even he doesn't know what he's thinking", Winston runs for local office. While voters first assume his posters are for a rap group called City Council, his growing "grassroots campaign in a community with no grass" earns him press acclaim as "the hip-hop populist".

It is Winston's honesty, his lack of self-pity or braggadocio ("no shame in my game"), that wins votes. His wife Yolanda muses on what makes him attractive: "He was comfortable with who he was and who he wasn't... He didn't embellish or rationalise his exploits, talking in pipe-dream slang about him and the crew 'coming up'."

While there is not much plot (though one strand entails a madcap plan by Winston's crew to rob a bank), much of the novel's energy derives from its satire, which skewers subjects from Mayor Giuliani's anti-crime drive and the faddish search for African-American "mentors" to self-help manuals on "problems unique to black-on-black love".

While Winston's campaign is funded by his Japanese-American "second mother" Inez, a 60s revolutionary on the lookout for "the next Malcolm X", many other targets are embodied in the cast: Winston's ex-Panther Beat poet father Clifford and his "draft-dodging, dashiki-wearing" peers; Spencer Throckmorton, "lapsed Negro", rabbi and dreadlocked "coconut" who mentors Winston in a "Big Brother programme"; Charles "Whitey" O'Koren, the neighbourhood wigger; and Fariq, the "enterprising shyster" on crutches - anti-semite, homophobe and the "epicentre of Afro-centrism".

The language, too, has verve and bite. While the milieu is reflected in the casual sprinkling of "niggers", "motherfuckers", "bitches" and "hos" as well as in the grammar ("Tuff gots to deal", "You might has well got shot"), for Winston, "language was an extension of his soul. And if his speech... was wrong, then his thoughts were wrong." The author glides between registers - a girl gives Winston the once-over by "tilting her head at the obtuse angle one uses to make sense of an abstract museum piece".

Tuff is full of acute observations. Young men block the sidewalk, each a "hooded druid bundled in an overstuffed down jacket", while traffic trying to dodge a ranting drunk is "like a column of Tiananmen Square tanks". Winston's baby is found "latching onto his ankle like a koala bear to a eucalyptus tree", or "doing the suspect lean against the television screen, hand on the tube, legs apart, eye-to-eye with an R&B diva". Beatty consummately evokes the theatrical menace of Winston's gait: he "slowed his pace to a chain-gang plod. The appropriate amount of bounce was applied to his diddy-bop, just enough spring in his step to rock his torso and head in an autistic half-beat. His shoulders rolled so that his arms paddled stiffly through the humid air like oars to a cruising Phoenician warship."

The author's eye for cant and condescension is also acute, from the well-off white girlfriend who "went straight plantation Gone With The Wind on a brother" to the third-party politicians who woo Winston, grandly conceding that "ordinary people" can govern themselves. Beatty draws Winston as nobody's fool; no "hip-hop populist" and in fact more mature than his mentor Spencer, who needs Winston for his newspaper write-ups on the "ghetto" more than Winston needs him. "This ain't no zoo... the safari over now." In his tentative heroism, Winston recalls another fictional street seer, Walter Mosley's Socrates Fortlow. As Spencer realises: "He was more afraid of Winston than for him. Afraid of his reputation. Afraid of his latent intellect. Afraid of being judged - and being judged fairly."

Beatty's tender regard for his main characters at times teeters towards sentimentality. Yet in its clear sympathies and wrenching satire, Tuff offers a riposte to a world where "street" style sells and Puff Daddy does Vogue shoots, but subway riders clutch their belongings at the sight of anyone resembling Winston. Both solemn and very funny, it insistently finds poetry in the projects, dignity on the street.

fields.headline: The slow train
fields.trailText: The Loafer reinvents European culture on the Literature Express... with the aid of a stiff drink or two
fields.body:
 The Loafer was in Berlin last weekend to greet the Literature Express. With 107 writers from 43 European countries on board, the train had travelled west to east across Europe on a six-week 7,000-km journey from Lisbon to St Petersburg, calling in at 19 cities for readings and receptions, before doubling back to Berlin, where the idea originated.

 18:39 saw the prompt arrival of the "rolling youth hostel", as Christopher Stölz, cultural minister for Berlin, called it. The travel-weary writers were cheered as they disembarked. Later, at the reception party, Stölz pointed out that it was the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille. "No borders of imagination!" he enthused. "Just an inexhaustible intellectual richness!" Which precipitated a mad rush for the free wine and finger food. Most agreed that the Dada show made more sense.

 The on-board stories began to emerge. Mice in the hotel in St Petersburg. A laptop stolen in Madrid. The Armenian writer David Muradian was said to buy a different brand of cigarettes each day so that the box, when placed in his top pocket, would complement his extravagant ties. In Kaliningrad a few of the travellers were handed kittens as they stepped off the train and told that, as writers, they were surely sensitive enough to look after them.

 Everyone wanted to know if Europe seemed bigger or smaller as a result of the journey. Writers from the west said they had been fascinated by eastern Europe - "the impact of communism", etc - while writers from the east just looked bemused. When a football match was organised, scribes from the former Yugoslavia took one look at the knock-kneed opposition and decided to stick together. German writer Felicitas Hoppe, on the other hand, saw European disparities in everyday details: different toilet flushes, locks which go the opposite way.

 Drink, of course, seldom left the agenda. Ukrainian poet and novelist Jurij Andruchowytsch envisaged three European zones: from Lisbon to Brussels, the wine zone; from Brussels to Berlin, beer territory; and then travelling east, ever afterwards, the land of vodka. Meanwhile, a gaggle of German wits invented a new genre: Tapirismus, a sort of rhyming nonsense verse. Later on they read some, which was about as funny as boiled cabbage.

 The showcase event, Saturday evening's "Worldsound Poetry Night", took place in Potsdamer Platz, the gleaming symbol of Berlin's new commercial centre. In a narrow street between towering buildings of brick and glass, a bright white stage housed readings by the travelling writers. They weren't the most important people there, however. A velvet-roped enclosure for the real Euro VIPs (whose fingers clutched either fountain pens or cigars) was patrolled by men with large heads and dark suits, proving that a bruiser's a bruiser in any language.

 Ben Okri, as usual urging everyone to renew their capacity to love and be loved, read from his book Mental Fight, a slightly painful process involving a heart-wrenching half hour of rolled Rs, sibilant Ss and plenty of faith, suffering and happiness.

 How did the writers feel at the end of their trip, with so many precious egos meeting in the buffet car? Croatian Dubravka Ugreiae called the experience "a lesson in humility"; one novelist (Slovenian? Estonian?) was said to have sold over 15m books. Many spoke of the links between translation and transportation, the freighting of words from one country to another. Some seemed to think this was a process which urgently needed further subsidy.

 Others saw the trip as a test of personal adaptability. The writers had to contend with abrupt changes of diet and currency (not much sign of the euro in their small change) as well as disorienting shifts in language and place. "Cultural couriers" were on board to help with language problems. And so far as conversation went, "pidgin euro" predominated - a kind of simplified English with a few, er, foreign phrases thrown in.

 During the closing speeches, the director of Berlin's Academy of Arts, György Konrád, remarked that "a collective train ride conjures up images of war, camps and false ideologies", but now we are facing "the challenge of reinventing European culture... If you want a union, you must be willing to slip inside the skin of other Europeans through their books." And the Loafer, with a glass each of wine, beer and vodka, willingly drank to that at least.

webTitle: Guardian review: Mary Wollstonecraft by Janet Todd

fields.headline: Quite contrary
fields.standfirst: The full force of Mary Wollstonecraft's achievement emerges from Janet Todd's biography
fields.trailText: The full force of Mary Wollstonecraft's achievement emerges from Janet Todd's biography
fields.body:
Mary Wollstonecraft: A Revolutionary Life
Janet Todd
Weidenfeld, £25, 510pp
Buy it at BOL

When, in October 1790, Edmund Burke published his Reflections on the Revolution in France, a great sigh of wonder went up from the rich and powerful in Britain as they flocked to read such an eloquent excuse for their fears and prejudices. 35,000 copies were sold almost at once. This was a huge number on any criterion - except that of Thomas Paine's historic answer to Burke, The Rights of Man, which sold at least 2m.

Paine was beaten to the post by an anonymous author who was obviously even more offended by Burke's sonorous snobbery. Only 28 days after the Reflections hit the streets, a furious little book entitled A Vindication of the Rights of Men was produced by the republican publisher Joseph Johnson. It sold so well that Johnson brought out another edition three weeks later. This time the author was revealed as Mary Wollstonecraft, 31, who had written several progressive stories and booklets for Johnson but had not yet tried her hand at political polemic. The revelation of the author's name led to predictable outrage. Horace Walpole, for instance, denounced her as a "hyena in petticoats".

The hyena had not finished yowling. In January 1792, Johnson brought out another book by Wollstonecraft. This was A Vindication of the Rights of Women, which became a feminist textbook for 200 years and more. Despite its slightly bossy style - which owed a lot to the author's training as a governess - the new book infuriated important men almost as rapidly as it absorbed Johnson's growing female readership.

Not all the angry men were reactionaries. William Godwin, whose Political Justice (1793) was very fortunate to escape prosecution for sedition, denounced the Vindication as "deficient in method and arrangement". Godwin met Wollstonecraft at literary dinner parties and was irritated by her strong views - and especially by her strong expression of them.

In her works and in her conversation, Wollstonecraft directed her fire at received notions, particularly the complementary nature of men and women - he the leader, in Janet Todd's words, "rational, ambitious and strong"; she the led, "emotional, intuitive and tender". Mary favoured equality and independence for women. "I do not wish women to have power over men," she observed, "but over themselves."

Her rebellious spirit reacted in opposite ways to most of her contemporaries. In December 1792, as English exiles flocked out of France to escape the Revolution's turn to the left, she settled as a lone woman in Paris. Her enthusiasm for the Revolution was tested to the full by the persecution and execution of most of her Girondist friends. Todd tells us that Wollstonecraft preferred "moderate republican bourgeois" to "street" revolutionaries, but she never joined what she called "the shallow herd who throw an odium on immutable principles because the mere instruments of the revolution were too sharp".

Another of Wollstonecraft's earlier views was then put to the test. In the Vindication she had urged that passion should be controlled by reason, and had deprecated men and women who became slaves to their sexual passions. These views went side by side with her sexual abstinence. Her early crush on the painter Henry Fuseli was not consummated, but in revolutionary France she engaged in a passionate love affair with a self-styled American "captain" called Gilbert Imlay.

All her inhibitions were swept away by this relationship, which resulted in a little girl, Fanny. The affair lasted for a few glorious months until Imlay, pleading business priorities, abandoned Mary and Fanny. In his romantic biographical adventure, Footsteps (1985), Richard Holmes pleads that Imlay "stands undefended before the bar of history", and points out that Imlay, by falsely announcing that he was married to Mary, probably saved her life. But to Todd, Imlay was a "speculator", in business and in love.

At any rate, his abrupt departure and his refusal to respond to endless pleas to return ruined Wollstonecraft's life. Eventually she followed him to England and agreed to his fantastic proposition that she should travel, with a Parisian maid and her baby, to Scandinavia on a hunt for a ship full of French silver which Imlay believed had been stolen from him.

This extraordinary mission - travelling in deep despondency, over dangerous seas and by any rickety transport she could hire, to some of the most remote towns and villages in Europe - makes up the most astonishing part of this biography. Throughout her long "symphonies of pain" Wollstonecraft never abandoned her beliefs or gave up hope of a better world. Through her return to England, her final dismissal by Imlay, her thwarted suicide leap from Putney Bridge, her marriage to William Godwin and her utterly sad (and utterly avoidable) death in childbirth, she clung firmly to her principles. "I am content to be wretched," she sighed, "but I will not be contemptible."

This is not a hagiography. Wollstonecraft's unpredictable and often contradictory behaviour is not ignored or excused. But although she is once accused, grotesquely, of "sounding like Burke in his Reflections", neither is she short-changed. The full force of her achievement emerges more strongly from stern criticism; as does the fact that her life was, above all else, a revolutionary one.

My only gripe is that the book is too long. Great academic biographers should have more pity on their readers. I would cheerfully have swapped at least 100 pages of Mary's dreary family for a short summary of her posthumous reputation. There is, for instance, only one reference in all these 500 pages to Shelley, who married Mary's daughter and was all his life inspired by her views. His longest poem, "The Revolt of Islam", is dedicated to his wife, but the dedication throbs with admiration and affection for the mother-in-law he never met:

They say that thou wert lovely from thy birth,

Of glorious parents thou aspiring child.

I wonder not - for One then left this earth

Whose life was like a setting planet mild,

Which clothed thee in the radiance undefiled

Of its departing glory; still her fame

Shines on thee, through the tempests dark and wild

Which shake these latter days.

fields.headline: Lemmy never travels without...
fields.trailText: Trousers | Books | A polar bear's tooth with a Motorhead logo carved on it
fields.body:
A necessity: Trousers. You are lost without them. A change of trousers and a spare pair of underwear is all I need.

A luxury: Books, especially non-fiction and Len Deighton.

A memento: A polar bear's tooth with a Motorhead logo carved on it, a present from a fan.

If only: A credit card with unlimited spending ability.

 Motorhead headline The Guildford Live Music Festival on July 28. Their latest single, God Save the Queen, is out on July 31

fields.headline: Travel software
fields.trailText: Maps and guides you can load on your palmtop computer.
fields.body:
What is it? Maps and guides you can load on your palmtop computer.

And then? You don't have to carry all those dead trees around with you.

Books, you mean? Yes. Ever weighed how much paper you take on holiday?

But papers's not scary. Nor is this stuff. The street and route finders plan your journey in seconds and guide you through it, mile by mile.

What, on your tiny screen? Yes: you can change the map scale from, say, an image covering most of East Anglia, down to 1km sq. You can avoid certain areas or choose a scenic route, via South Wales for example.

And it really works? Yes, and there's a version you can connect to a GPS device so that the screen will show you where you are in the world.

What else can you get? Not a lot at the moment: dictionaries, the Michelin Red Guide, Lonely Planet city guides. There's more on the way for the next generation of mobile phones.

What's the downside? Three or four applications would fill an average palmtop's memory. Some are quite pricey compared with books.

How pricey? £49.99 each for Street Planner and Route Planner Millennium, £34.99 for the Michelin Red Guide - all from Palmtop Software 020-7794 9500 for stockists - £29.99 for four Lonely Planet city guides, available in shops from September.

How do you load the programmes? From a CD via your PC, into which you plug the palmtop. To get Lonely Planet guides now, download them from www.citysync.com at $19.99 per city (you have to pay in US dollars).

So what's the alternative? A small mobile library; ask a policeman.

What would cynics say? By the time you've learned how to use it and loaded the software, you could have had a long weekend in Amsterdam, with those tatty old books to keep you company.

fields.headline: On line entertainment
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor trawls through angling sites, and finds a dearth of fishermen but very little evidence of fisherwomen.
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor trawls through angling sites, and finds a dearth of fishermen but very little evidence of fisherwomen.
fields.body:
Plenty of fishing information is available on the net, but it is not always of the highest quality - and much valuable bandwidth is taken up with colourful pictures of fishermen showing off the size of their catch.

I apologise for the use of the term "fisherman" throughout these reviews; the truth is that I did not find a single fisherwoman on any of these sites. Any contradictory evidence would be welcome.

Angling in Iceland
Brief but alluring prose and pictures that celebrate the "pollution-free" Atlantic and river salmon fishing in Iceland. Exporting the fish can sometimes be difficult, but parts of Iceland offer a special taxidermy service for visiting fishermen.

GORP
"Now somewhere in the black mountain hills of Dakota, there live a lot of trout just waiting to be caught." Leave your scruples about declining fish stocks behind and think about a fishing holiday in the States, where the fish are fat, plentiful and willing. GORP is a vast and well-presented resource of advice and tips, with a strong regional guide and lively writing.

World Wide Fishing
Featuring the longest pull-down menus I've ever encountered on a website, World Wide Fishing may be sorely in need of a search engine but it does list a vast number of holiday resorts all over the world for freshwater, saltwater and fly fishing. Don't be deceived. Most of the "individual" pages are in fact almost identical, and the reports on each resort are rather sparse.

Norwegian Salmon Fishing
Norgold is a Lancashire company which organises stays on the River Namsen in central Norway. Dates and prices are unfortunately absent, but the accommodation and fishing both appear to be very impressive.

Fishing in Scotland database
A small but useful site with good contacts for fishermen visiting Scotland and a searchable list of holiday companies.

Fishing.co.uk
This already impressive site is due to relaunch in the autumn, and is currently searching for fishermen who would be willing to pose naked for a "Grab Your Tackle" calendar to celebrate the occasion. Women are not invited to apply, but might be welcome, too.

The rest of the site is comprehensive and entertaining, with special sections on fishing holidays and accommodation - although it is unclear whether the companies featured have paid to be on the site or are simply there because Fishing.co.uk endorses them.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Hong Kong

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Hong Kong
fields.standfirst: Paul O'Grady
fields.trailText: Paul O'Grady
fields.body:
Why? I love the energy of the place. It is very glamourous, pretty to look at, the shops are fabulous and I like the people. I first went 23 years ago and I remember the Hong Kong waterfront, seeing the skyscrapers and thinking: What is this? There were maybe 20 skyscrapers then; now there are thousands.

Suzie Wong has a lot to answer for because people think that all Hong Kong girls wear cheongsams, have black bobs and are still jitterbugging around juke boxes in Kowloon. Everyone now is very smart, in black and grey and constantly on their mobiles, which drives you insane; it is very hi-tech.

Hong Kong is where people work hard and play hard. The expats have great parties. They love it. It's this energy that you feed off. I get a fix from it. I get off the plane and then I'm out all the time. There is something about Hong Kong which, if I could put it in a bottle and sell it, I'd be a millionaire.

The best thing: Just standing on your balcony at the Mandarin Oriental. At twilight, you watch Hong Kong harbour with the lights, the junks, the ferries, streams of traffic, and these huge skyscrapers. Then a bird of prey will suddenly fly down from the Peak. It is magnificent.

My advice: Avoid the touristy places like Cat Street and go over to Kowloon, to the markets where the locals go. Visit Aberdeen by trolley bus and then try the night life. Although there are girls in bikinis on metal poles it is not so aggressive or in your face as Bangkok, or as desperate as Pat Pong.

How do I get there? Cathay Pacific (020-7747 8888) flies direct from Heathrow and Manchester from £673 return. British Airways (0345 222111) flies direct from Heathrow from £661 return.

 Paul O'Grady's Orient begins Monday, July 24 at 10pm on ITV.

fields.headline: Green peace
fields.standfirst: Organic farmer and environmental activist  Lord Melchett enjoys the largely unspoilt pleasures of the Lake District National Park
fields.trailText: Organic farmer and environmental activist Lord Melchett enjoys the largely unspoilt pleasures of the Lake District National Park.
fields.body:
It starts among green fields and dry stone walls, but soon becomes a lung-stretching climb among screes and crags; then come the sudden views to far-off mountains and the sea, and the walk over the top with the wind in your face; and finally the return along the lakeshore or a quiet valley with sheep and a stream for company.

There are a hundred variations of this classic Lake District walk, and most visitors have a circuit they return to time and again for its special sights and memories. Lord Melchett's best route takes him over Mellbreak, a 1,700ft. fell beside Crummock Water in the quieter north-west of the national park.

He starts from the Kirkstile Inn in the village of Loweswater, where he's often stayed with his family and taken Greenpeace volunteers to recuperate after prosecutions for attempting to block the outfall pipe from the Sellafield nuclear reprocessing plant on the Cumbrian coast 15 miles away.

"Sellafield's close, but fortunately it's not visible," he says. "Instead you pass the church and a few farmsteads - typical Lake District lowland country with small fields and lots of sheep. It's very pretty and there are lovely old oak woods along the stream.

"Then, quite quickly, you're up the hill and on the scree and you're hanging on with your hands past Raven Crag and White Crag. The best part is about two thirds of the way up when the worst part of the climb is behind you and it's starting to get very spectacular indeed."

Mellbreak has a flat, rolling top with views to the north across the Solway Firth to Scotland and to the south down the Buttermere valley with the summits of Fleetwith Pike, Haystacks and High Crag round the head of the lake. Melchett and his wife once brought their children up in backpacks, and have even managed to get them here as teenagers.

After descending the southern flank, there's the option to visit Scale Force with the crowds who stroll over from Buttermere. "It's completely hidden, even when you're close," he says. "It's a mysterious, dark, damp place, and a huge contrast to the openness of Mellbreak, especially if it's a bright summer day."

One way back is a two-mile walk along Mosedale, which is rarely visited and has "a magical sense of emptiness and stillness and huge space". But his preference is to follow the shore of Crummock Water past the peninsula of Low Link Crag where's he's often swum and rowed with his family. The finale is crossing the meadows of wild flowers at the head of the lake and walking through Lanthwaite Wood, a plantation of conifers from the 1950s which the National Trust is gradually replanting with hardwood trees - an example of the steady improvement that Melchett sees in the Lake District landscape.

Two other examples, he says, are the skillful rebuilding of paths in areas that were heavily eroded, and the recent decision to impose a 10mph speed limit which will curb powerboating on Windermere. "I think the Lake District has over the years become less spoilt because it's being so well managed," he says.

"It's a question of being intelligent and stopping things that do permanent damage, such as new roads, conifer plantations and certain kinds of buildings. The conifer forests planted last century have left scars that will take hundreds of years to repair."

As an organic farmer, he would like to see an increase in cattle grazing in the Lake District, which would control the bracken which has taken over some hillsides, untouched by sheep because it poisons them: "There are some beef cattle around - we've seen big Charolais bulls just to the north and east of Loweswater. But but you need more of them grazing further up the valleys."

The idea of the Lake District as a National Park probably originated with the Romantic poets: William Wordsworth, who lived there much of his life, called for "a sort of national property in which a man has a right and interest who has an eye to perceive and a heart to enjoy."

But it took the Labour government of 1945 to pass the National Parks Act of 1949, and the 50th anniversary of the Lake District as one of the first parks comes in August next year: it remains the biggest, most spectacular and most popular, with 14m visitors a year.

Among the celebrations will be a pastoral theme to the BBC Promenade concerts, and the search is on for a tangible commemoration project, such as the restoration of one of the dilapidated Victorian viewpoints. As assessment of achievements and disappointments is also going on.

Robin Barratt, chairman of the Friends of the Lake District pressure group, said the National Park could take credit for getting speed limits on Ullswater, Coniston, Derwentwater and Windermere, and using its planning powers to help preserve the landscape.

But it had failed to prevent many developments that worked against the park's founding principle of "quiet enjoyment" and took away a sense of discovery and adventure: "There is too much signing, too much promotion of everything, including footpaths, everything laid on a plate," he said.

Bob Cartwright, head of park management at the Lake District National Park Authority, said it had recon ciled huge development pressures with preserving a supremely beautiful landscape. But the growth in car traffic, still to be tackled successfully, was a major disappointment.

"In general, we're able to deal with management issues in a proportionate way. For example, when we started to have problems with mountain biking. we didn't seek outright bans. Instead we produced a code that seems to have worked. For off-road vehicles, it looks as though stronger measures may be necessary."

The practicals

Main stations for the Lake District are Oxenholme, Penrith, Carlisle and Lancaster. National rail inquiries 0345 484950. For buses, call Stagecoach Cumberland (01946 63222). For accommodation, call Cumbria Tourist Board (015394 44444/ 08705 133059). Lake District National Park Authority (01539 724555). OS Landranger maps (1 inch to 1 mile) 89 (West Cumbria, Cockermouth and Wast Water) and 90 (Penrith and Keswick, Ambleside), £5.25. OS Outdoor Leisure map (2 inches to 1 mile), 4, £6.50. Walking guidebooks include the classic The North-Western Fells by A Wainwright, Michael Joseph, £10.99.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Whodunnit? | Memory lane | Shell out
fields.body:
Whodunnit?
Who killed Sir George Manvers? Look for clues and quiz the actors with the help of a guest list and character description as the Duelling Association evokes the atmosphere of a Regency household murder.

 Sat/Sun, from 1pm. £3.50/£1.80. Brodsworth Hall and Gardens, Brodsworth,Doncaster, S Yorks (01302 722598).

Memory lane
Hold your nose as you stroll and trade down the main road of Londinium circa 100AD - the smells of the capital are recreated along with the shops and stalls.

 Until January 2001. Open Mon-Sat 10am-5.50pm, Sun noon-5.50pm. £5/ children free. The Museum of London, London Wall, EC2 (020-7600 0807).

Shell out
A ceremonial landing of oysters at Whitstable today is followed by oyster-opening competitions and cookery demonstrations, Morris dancing, folk music and Viking battles on the seafront.

 Until July 30. Whitstable, Kent (01227 265666).

Cue Cumbria
It may look like a Teletubby house, but Rheged, a new, grass-covered discovery centre, should be everyone's first port of call in the Lake District. Celtic history, Arthurian legend, Wordsworth, an action-packed film and local foods and crafts on offer.

 Open10am-6pm daily. £4.95/£3.50/ family £14.50. Redhills, Penrith, Cumbria (01768-868000).

Taken for a ride
Philip Schofield, aka Dr Doolittle, is at Crealy Adventure Park in Devon today to launch El Pastil Loco, a £400,000 family rollercoaster.

 Open 10am-6pm. £5.50/under-2s free, most rides included. Clyst St Mary, Exeter, Devon (01395 233200).

Up the wall
The free "Essential Guide to Hadrian's Wall" leaflet is full of ideas for walks, cycle routes and suggested days out around the World Heritage site.

 Information line: 01434 322002.

Thomas mania
Steam on down to the London Transport Museum for children's activities (giant inflatable train, stage shows, badge making...) that herald a six-week Thomas the Tank Engine exhibition.

 Open 10am-6pm daily, exhibition until Sept 3, activities until July 30. £5.50/£2.95. Covent Garden Piazza, London WC2 (020-7379 6344).

Abbey habit
History comes to life at Tintern Abbey with the liberal use of fireworks, visual effects and action from over 100 actors, staged to mark the millennium in Monmouthshire.

 July 27/28/29; Aug 3-5 and 10-12. £10.00/£7.50 concessions. Fair at 19.00, show begins as darkness falls. Tickets and info: 01291-625391.

webTitle: The cheapest way to travel round Italy

fields.headline: The cheapest way to travel round Italy
fields.standfirst: My partner, one child and I are flying to Italy next month - into Milan and out of Rome. In two weeks we plan to visit Bologna, Florence and Pisa. We are wanting to do this the cheapest way in terms of accommodation and transport (although we don't want to drive). Any tips? We don't want to come back broke.
fields.trailText: My partner, one child and I are flying to Italy next month - into Milan and out of Rome. In two weeks we plan to visit Bologna, Florence and Pisa. We are wanting to do this the cheapest way in terms of accommodation and transport (although we don't want to drive). Any tips? We don't want to come back broke.
fields.body:
· Youth Hostels are the cheapest accommodation option depending on the age of your child: £10 per night and free breakfast, but you have to be a "youth". Get information from YHA in England and try to book by international booking network from the UK. To save money on meals, look out for self-service restaurants.
Sarah Kenyon

· Rail fares in Italy are based on the distance travelled so: Florence to Sienna is 8,000 lire, Sienna to Chiusi 8,000 lire, Chiusi to Rome 14,500 lire. Don't buy a Biglietto Chilo metrico costing £88 in UK. It is valid for 3,000km, but you need to travel nearly the full distance buying second-class tickets as you go before you show a small profit.
David Gill

· You can check out train timetables on www.fs-on-line.it.
Gregorius Garber

· Larger hotels in major towns are as expensive as anywhere, but the low-star hotels are excellent value. Lists available in all towns and from the Italian Tourist Office.
Chris and Joyce Peel

· Avoid staying in Milan for too long - costs an absolute fortune. For good hotel prices, go to the hotel booking service in the main railway station in central Rome. They have good vacancies for Florence/Rome/Pisa/Naples for that day and subsequent days only. In the middle of June, they booked me a room at the Hotel Montreal (centrally located and very nice) for half the usual rate.

Pisa is much cheaper to stay than Florence and is only a half hour away by train. Use sleepers to save on accommodation if travelling south to north. They are pleasantly surprisingly good and leave you money to maybe splash out on a better hotel the next day.

For cheap food, avoid heavy tourist areas and check out the quiet trattorias and pizza joints - lovely food, very cheap. In the south of italy, buy fresh fruit - very cheap by UK standards and much better quality.
Rehan Arshad

· Previous respodent has it right, but . . . for lodging also look into affitte camere (ah-FEE-te CAH-may-ray) - furnished rooms in private homes. For transport do not neglect the buses, which go where the trains can't - into the hills - and also many places they don't (usually where there are lots of small towns but few cities). As there is no national bus service comparable to the national rail network, the buses are little local or regional lines, and they get short shrift. Same is true in France. But they reach plenty of places that are otherwise accessible only by car.

Bill Marsano
