fields.headline: Boom town platz
fields.standfirst: Cranes tower over the biggest building site in Europe, but the arts and the nightlife have been reborn with a new vitality.  Andy Pietrasik meets the new megalopolis
fields.trailText: Cranes tower over the biggest building site in Europe, but the arts and the nightlife have been reborn with a new vitality. Andy Pietrasik meets the new megalopolis.
fields.body:
It must have all come as a bit of a shock to the Queen last Tuesday. First she had to contend with the blue and purple abstractions breaking out of the neat sandstone facade of the new British Embassy. Then there was the view from inside the space-age glass bubble that crowns the Reichstag building restored by Norman Foster.

And, oh ma'am, what a view. It must have looked to her like some animus horribilis was at work. For Berlin, the self-proclaimed new capital of Europe, is not that easy on the eye just yet. A forest of yellow cranes still towers over the biggest building site in Europe and brave-new-world architecture stands side by side with reclad relics from the collapsed East and scaffolded shells from the war.

Beyond this megalopolis in the making, Berlin is not the sort of place that instantly seduces you anyway. It lacks the intimacy of little squares and riverside cafés. There's no discernible centre, and the distances between locations are too great to walk. It's difficult to get your head around the geography of the city, but that is hardly surprising given that, until the Wall was torn down almost 11 years ago, it was divided into two cities with two centres, two easts, wests, norths and souths.

Which makes what is happening there all the more exciting - the greatest experiment in urban planning in modern times is being matched by an equally uplifting energy in the arts and the nightlife. By day, you can work your way through the Who's Who of architects and trawl through an extraordinary range of galleries. By night, you can hop between designer bars, cocktail lounges and nightclubs - although crawl is probably nearer the mark, as there are no closing times in a city that genuinely doesn't sleep.

All of this combines to make Berlin the fourth most popular city destination in Europe after London, Paris and Rome. God knows it needs the injection of tourism cash, as it has sunk billions into building this city of the future. And we Brits are leading the way in Europe, according to the latest figures from the Berlin tourist board, bolstered largely by our bullish pound. A decent hotel room can be had for as little as £70 a night, a good meal for two with wine for around £40 and the beer goes down nicely at £2 a pint.

What to see

Where to begin? The best way to get your bearings is to sign up for a city tour. The cheapest one is on the top deck of the regular number 100 bus, which passes most of the major sights, all for a DM3.90 ticket. Alternatively, the Insider Tour the Insider Tour is a three-and-a-half-hour guided walk conducted in English (DM20, tel: +49 30 692 3149). Also, lots of boats run up and down the River Spree - the commentary is in German, but the journey is relaxing enough (City Schiffahrt charges DM12 from the back of the Berlin Cathedral).

Walk up Unter den Linden from Friedrichstrasse to Alexanderplatz. Much of Berlin's turbulent history is encapsulated in this stretch. There are grandiose edifices built under Frederick II, destroyed in the second world war and rebuilt by the communist authorities. Across the street from the Humboldt University is Bebelplatz, flanked by the State Opera House and St Hedwigs' cathedral, where the Nazis started burning books on May 10 1933. Behind the Berlin cathedral and the Pergamon Museum on Museumsinsel sits the Communist kitsch of the television tower in Alexanderplatz (for 9DM, you can take the elevator up to the observation deck).

At the other end of Unter den Linden is the Brandenburg Gate, symbol of the city's division in the Cold War, stranded in no man's land behind the eastern side of the Wall; and the nearby Reichstag building, temple of Germany's re-unification. You can take a tour of the Reichstag and go up to the viewing gallery inside the glass dome, but get there early to avoid the two-hour queues (tours run 9am-10pm, and the building closes at midnight).

Potsdamer Platz is the centrepiece of Europe's boom town, a collection of futuristic high-rise office buildings and a pedestrianised forum with shops, cinemas, cafés and restaurants designed by some of the world's most celebrated architects.

Museums

Of the 170 museums, one of the most stunning is the Hamburger Bahnhoff, a converted railway station in Invalidenstrasse, Mitte, that opened in 1997. The interiors are cavernous and light with white glass tiles in the arched roofs, and the exhibits include Andy Warhol drawings from the 1950s and silk-screen prints of Mao and the Mona Lisa.

Just up from one of the few remaining segments of the Wall and next to the location of Hitler's secret bunker is the Martin-Gropius-Bau museum (Niederkirchnerstrasse 7, Mitte). This houses the city's millennium exhibition, Seven Hills - images and signs of the 21st century, which has, as its centrepiece, a futuristic installation by set designer Ken Adams of Bond and Dr Strangelove fame. It is breathtaking in its range, featuring 2,000 exhibits from more than 400 sources throughout the world. On until October 29.

The Jewish Museum (Lindenstrasse 15, Kreuzberg) is a series of zigzag metal buildings with slashes for windows that suggest scars. The layout and the uneven floors are designed to induce a feeling of dislocation and disorientation, reflecting the Jewish experience during the Holocaust.

When the cultural overload starts to kick in - and it will - clear your head with a stroll through the Tiergarten, the sprawling park that had to be replanted after the original trees were chopped down for firewood in 1945.

Where to drink

Unwind over kaffee und kuchen (cake). One of the most famous spots is Café Adler (Friedrichstrasse 206) overlooking the site of Checkpoint Charlie, the one-time gateway between East and West. While you're spoiling yourself with strudel (4DM) and sipping milchkaffee from a bowl (5.50DM) in the salon downstairs, bear in mind that at the height of the Cold War the CIA were installed on the third floor and the Stasi were located just over the street.

Most cafés also serve food and alcohol, but if you want to keep your powder dry for a night on the town, head over to Oranienburger Strasse in the district of Mitte. This strip of designer bars, lounges and restaurants in the former impoverished east has long since stolen the in-crowd away from the once glittering Kufürstendamm in the west. Resident DJs provide a background of chilled-out sounds in most places, and they don't charge an entrance fee. The refreshing thing about Berlin's bars - apart from their cocktails, of course - is that no matter how self-consciously stylish they appear, they welcome all - young and old, hip and square - with none of the snooty attitude of their London counterparts. It's as though, having lived in a divided society for so long, they are no longer willing to tolerate barriers of any sort.

Start at the Friedrichstrasse end, opposite the run-down squats colonised by artists when the Wall came down, and kick off with a cocktail from 808 Bar & Lounge (16DM a go).

Silberstein, up the road, is a more rigidly stylised venue with absurdly high-backed iron chairs. Here the new black is black. The waiters and waitresses are resting between parts, and the DJ is saving up for his return ticket back from the dark side.

Just off Oranienburger is a string of venues in the railway arches in Hackescher Markt. Resist the temptation to go al fresco at Zucca and sit inside under the art-deco chandeliers listening to the latest remixes.

Where to eat

A civilised way to start the day is over a leisurely DM20 breakfast in the garden of the Café im Literaturhaus (Fasanenstrasse 23, Charlottenburg), a turn-of-the-century villa that shares a street in the upmarket side of town with the likes of Gucci, Chanel and Cartier.

Lunch at Café Aedes in Hackesche Höfe (Rosenthaler Strasse, Mitte) - a labyrinth of courtyards housing bookshops, galleries theatres and artists' workshops. A simple bowl of Berlinner Kartofellsuppe und weiner - thick potato soup with slices of sausage - costs DM9.50.

In the evening, take a taxi over to Kreuzberg - known as the "multi-kulti" sector of town because of the number of alternative types who moved here to dodge conscription and the large Turkish population - for a taste of Austria in Jolesch (corner of Muskauer Strasse and Zeughofstrasse). A meal for two with a bottle of wine weighs in at £30.

Or go up to the Dachgarten Restaurant inside the dome at the Reichstag. It's a little pricier, with main dishes from DM45 to DM49, but it's worth it for the view and, if you have a reservation, you automatically jump the queue (tel: +49 30 22 62 99 33).

Where to stay

Hotels are relatively cheap in Berlin - rooms at the normally heavy-hitting Four Seasons, for instance, start at 510DM for a double, a fraction of the cost of those in other cities. "Art hotels", with paintings and installations, have sprung up all over the city, but the original one is Sorat Art'otel in Joachimstaler Strasse, just off the Kufürstendamm in Charlottenburg (+49 30 88 44 70), featuring the work of artist Wolf Vostell. A stylistic snip starting at DM165 a night.

Five of the best clubs

1 WMF Ziegelstrasse 23, Berlin-Mitte Cool arrogant DJs draw trendsetters, artists and celebs.

2 KIT KAT@Metropol Nollendorfplatz 5, Berlin-Schöneberg Dress code demands visitors wear as little as possible.

3 Shark Club Friedrichstrasse, Berlin-Mitte Doorkeepers are tough, but if you have a collection of credit cards and a model in tow, they'll have mercy.

4 Kaffee Burger Torstrasse 60, Berlin-Mitte Psychedelic interior and an eclectic mix of music

5 Tresor Club Leipziger Strasse 126a, Berlin-Mitte Once the cradle of techno, now a party zone for suburban ravers.

The practicals

Virgin Express (0207 772 0004) flies from London Stansted to Berlin-Schönefeld airport from £58 return. Buzz flies from Stansted to Berlin Tegel for £85 return. German Travel Centre (020 8429 2900) offers return flights for £100, overnight stays for £130. A WelcomeCard allows three days travel on all Berlin's public transport systems and costs DM32; it also offers discounts on a number of attractions. For further information, contact the German Tourist Board (020-7317 0908), or visit www.germany-tourism.de.
fields.bodyText: It must have all come as a bit of a shock to the Queen last Tuesday. First she had to contend with the blue and purple abstractions breaking out of the neat sandstone facade of the new British Embassy. Then there was the view from inside the space-age glass bubble that crowns the Reichstag building restored by Norman Foster. And, oh ma'am, what a view. It must have looked to her like some animus horribilis was at work. For Berlin, the self-proclaimed new capital of Europe, is not that easy on the eye just yet. A forest of yellow cranes still towers over the biggest building site in Europe and brave-new-world architecture stands side by side with reclad relics from the collapsed East and scaffolded shells from the war. Beyond this megalopolis in the making, Berlin is not the sort of place that instantly seduces you anyway. It lacks the intimacy of little squares and riverside cafés. There's no discernible centre, and the distances between locations are too great to walk. It's difficult to get your head around the geography of the city, but that is hardly surprising given that, until the Wall was torn down almost 11 years ago, it was divided into two cities with two centres, two easts, wests, norths and souths. Which makes what is happening there all the more exciting - the greatest experiment in urban planning in modern times is being matched by an equally uplifting energy in the arts and the nightlife. By day, you can work your way through the Who's Who of architects and trawl through an extraordinary range of galleries. By night, you can hop between designer bars, cocktail lounges and nightclubs - although crawl is probably nearer the mark, as there are no closing times in a city that genuinely doesn't sleep. All of this combines to make Berlin the fourth most popular city destination in Europe after London, Paris and Rome. God knows it needs the injection of tourism cash, as it has sunk billions into building this city of the future. And we Brits are leading the way in Europe, according to the latest figures from the Berlin tourist board, bolstered largely by our bullish pound. A decent hotel room can be had for as little as £70 a night, a good meal for two with wine for around £40 and the beer goes down nicely at £2 a pint. What to see Where to begin? The best way to get your bearings is to sign up for a city tour. The cheapest one is on the top deck of the regular number 100 bus, which passes most of the major sights, all for a DM3.90 ticket. Alternatively, the Insider Tour the Insider Tour is a three-and-a-half-hour guided walk conducted in English (DM20, tel: +49 30 692 3149). Also, lots of boats run up and down the River Spree - the commentary is in German, but the journey is relaxing enough (City Schiffahrt charges DM12 from the back of the Berlin Cathedral). Walk up Unter den Linden from Friedrichstrasse to Alexanderplatz. Much of Berlin's turbulent history is encapsulated in this stretch. There are grandiose edifices built under Frederick II, destroyed in the second world war and rebuilt by the communist authorities. Across the street from the Humboldt University is Bebelplatz, flanked by the State Opera House and St Hedwigs' cathedral, where the Nazis started burning books on May 10 1933. Behind the Berlin cathedral and the Pergamon Museum on Museumsinsel sits the Communist kitsch of the television tower in Alexanderplatz (for 9DM, you can take the elevator up to the observation deck). At the other end of Unter den Linden is the Brandenburg Gate, symbol of the city's division in the Cold War, stranded in no man's land behind the eastern side of the Wall; and the nearby Reichstag building, temple of Germany's re-unification. You can take a tour of the Reichstag and go up to the viewing gallery inside the glass dome, but get there early to avoid the two-hour queues (tours run 9am-10pm, and the building closes at midnight). Potsdamer Platz is the centrepiece of Europe's boom town, a collection of futuristic high-rise office buildings and a pedestrianised forum with shops, cinemas, cafés and restaurants designed by some of the world's most celebrated architects. Museums Of the 170 museums, one of the most stunning is the Hamburger Bahnhoff, a converted railway station in Invalidenstrasse, Mitte, that opened in 1997. The interiors are cavernous and light with white glass tiles in the arched roofs, and the exhibits include Andy Warhol drawings from the 1950s and silk-screen prints of Mao and the Mona Lisa. Just up from one of the few remaining segments of the Wall and next to the location of Hitler's secret bunker is the Martin-Gropius-Bau museum (Niederkirchnerstrasse 7, Mitte). This houses the city's millennium exhibition, Seven Hills - images and signs of the 21st century, which has, as its centrepiece, a futuristic installation by set designer Ken Adams of Bond and Dr Strangelove fame. It is breathtaking in its range, featuring 2,000 exhibits from more than 400 sources throughout the world. On until October 29. The Jewish Museum (Lindenstrasse 15, Kreuzberg) is a series of zigzag metal buildings with slashes for windows that suggest scars. The layout and the uneven floors are designed to induce a feeling of dislocation and disorientation, reflecting the Jewish experience during the Holocaust. When the cultural overload starts to kick in - and it will - clear your head with a stroll through the Tiergarten, the sprawling park that had to be replanted after the original trees were chopped down for firewood in 1945. Where to drink Unwind over kaffee und kuchen (cake). One of the most famous spots is Café Adler (Friedrichstrasse 206) overlooking the site of Checkpoint Charlie, the one-time gateway between East and West. While you're spoiling yourself with strudel (4DM) and sipping milchkaffee from a bowl (5.50DM) in the salon downstairs, bear in mind that at the height of the Cold War the CIA were installed on the third floor and the Stasi were located just over the street. Most cafés also serve food and alcohol, but if you want to keep your powder dry for a night on the town, head over to Oranienburger Strasse in the district of Mitte. This strip of designer bars, lounges and restaurants in the former impoverished east has long since stolen the in-crowd away from the once glittering Kufürstendamm in the west. Resident DJs provide a background of chilled-out sounds in most places, and they don't charge an entrance fee. The refreshing thing about Berlin's bars - apart from their cocktails, of course - is that no matter how self-consciously stylish they appear, they welcome all - young and old, hip and square - with none of the snooty attitude of their London counterparts. It's as though, having lived in a divided society for so long, they are no longer willing to tolerate barriers of any sort. Start at the Friedrichstrasse end, opposite the run-down squats colonised by artists when the Wall came down, and kick off with a cocktail from 808 Bar & Lounge (16DM a go). Silberstein, up the road, is a more rigidly stylised venue with absurdly high-backed iron chairs. Here the new black is black. The waiters and waitresses are resting between parts, and the DJ is saving up for his return ticket back from the dark side. Just off Oranienburger is a string of venues in the railway arches in Hackescher Markt. Resist the temptation to go al fresco at Zucca and sit inside under the art-deco chandeliers listening to the latest remixes. Where to eat A civilised way to start the day is over a leisurely DM20 breakfast in the garden of the Café im Literaturhaus (Fasanenstrasse 23, Charlottenburg), a turn-of-the-century villa that shares a street in the upmarket side of town with the likes of Gucci, Chanel and Cartier. Lunch at Café Aedes in Hackesche Höfe (Rosenthaler Strasse, Mitte) - a labyrinth of courtyards housing bookshops, galleries theatres and artists' workshops. A simple bowl of Berlinner Kartofellsuppe und weiner - thick potato soup with slices of sausage - costs DM9.50. In the evening, take a taxi over to Kreuzberg - known as the "multi-kulti" sector of town because of the number of alternative types who moved here to dodge conscription and the large Turkish population - for a taste of Austria in Jolesch (corner of Muskauer Strasse and Zeughofstrasse). A meal for two with a bottle of wine weighs in at £30. Or go up to the Dachgarten Restaurant inside the dome at the Reichstag. It's a little pricier, with main dishes from DM45 to DM49, but it's worth it for the view and, if you have a reservation, you automatically jump the queue (tel: +49 30 22 62 99 33). fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sweet dreams | Running repairs | Pot boiler
fields.body:
Sweet dreams
All British Airways Club World passengers on the Heathrow-New York route can go to sleep for the duration. The airline has fitted seats that turn into a completely flat 6ft bed. Club prices start at£3,068 for a return ticket. Details 0845 7733377 (www.britishairways.com).

Running repairs

Nmes airport is being closed from August 4 to August 24 because of repair work to the main runway. Ryanair has suspended its daily service from Stansted for the period.

Pot boiler
A nice cup of tea tops the list of things most missed by British holidaymakers abroad, according to Thomas Cook. The five other things most missed were their own bed, friends and relatives, British TV, British food and drink, and pets.

Track record
Eurostar's market share of passengers on the London/ Paris route has risen by 1%, to 62% this year.

Turkish delight
Two British divers on a scuba-diving trip to Turkey have found a previously-undiscovered 600-year-old shipwreck off the coast of Marmaris.

Short and sweet
Day trips from nine UK airports - Manchester, East Midlands, Leeds Bradford, Belfast, Newcastle, Stansted, Cardiff, Birmingham and Gatwick - to 17 European destinations are on offer from Airtours from December. Details 0800 0288001.

Back in the saddle
A new brochure promotes cycling in mid-Wales. To book accommodation, hire bikes or request the Bikes and Kites brochure, call 0800 273747.

Booking the trend
The price of a British hotel room has increased by only 0.61% in the past year, compared with 9.47% in New York, 10.61% in Rome, 6.94% in Madrid and 23.44% in Amsterdam, according to the latest Tariff Survey carried out by Expotel, the hotel reservations agency. The average room rate for all categories this year is £93.18.

Help yourself
Some 75% of people who take all-inclusive holidays admit to eating and drinking more than usual because they know at the end of the evening they will not be faced with a large bill, according to Valtur by Cadogan Holidays (0870 0363666). More than a third of the 500 people questioned were on honeymoon. The company run all inclusive holidays throughout the world.

fields.headline: Agents in danger
fields.standfirst: Service fees may lead some to decide they're better off without agents, says  John Carter
fields.trailText: Service fees may lead some to decide they're better off without agents, says John Carter.
fields.body:
British travel agents are bracing themselves for a backlash from customers over the introduction of service fees. The charges are regarded as inevitable when airlines and other travel suppliers follow the lead of British Airways, which is abolishing commission payments to travel agents from next January.

Members of the Association of British Travel Agents are concerned that the increased cost incurred by customers will undermine their relationship with the public, given that agents have traditionally pro vided a free service - although a minority make small charges for some transactions.

Furthermore the pressure to switch from commissions to service fees comes at a time when Britain's independent travel agents are under threat from internet travel sites, and threatened by operators printing direct-booking telephone numbers in their brochures.

As if all this wasn't enough, fee-charging also raises the prospect of UK independent agents having to compete with "be your own travel agent" schemes, which have devastated their American counterparts. In the US, newspaper advertisements declare that, for a one-off payment of $495 (around £300), anybody can become a travel agent - thereby avoiding fees and benefiting from the "huge discounts" enjoyed by the trade.

They also promise "first-class upgrades" on flights and explain that, if people arrange travel for friends, they can pass on those benefits and earn commission - without qualifications or experience.

James Ashurst of the American Society of Travel Agents, recently explained the situation to USA Today: "We have a problem with companies that sell travel agent credentials to consumers who have no intention or desire to be sellers of travel . . . who are simply attempting to reap discounts that are often bestowed upon legitimate sellers of travel."

Florida-based Global Travel International has recruited 30,000 "agents" who are currently doing around $120m million worth of business, putting it in the top 1% per cent of America's travel agencies.

The US trade has tried to take evasive action. In 1998, the ASTA asked the Federal Trade Commission to establish regulations for travel agencies to keep out the "DIY" brigade, but the Commission decided, unanimously, that no such rules were needed.

There is nothing to prevent such schemes being launched in Britain either because, as ABTA's Keith Betton said: "UK governments have never legislated the business of being a travel agent".

My inquiries at the Department of Trade and Industry and the Office of Fair Trading turned up no rule or regulation to stop "be your own travel agent" schemes being set up here. But an official at the Office of Fair Trading warned that people passing themselves off as travel agents under such circumstances could lose the protection of consumer legislation in the event of a subsequent dispute.

One veteran observer of the UK travel trade warned that the "DIY" approach has other pitfalls too: "The public believes that travel agents enjoy free, or very cheap, travel and all sorts of other benefits. It is easy to sell them the promise of sharing these perks, and that is why they would sign on and pay up. But without real knowledge and experience, they could pay more for travel products than they would if a genuine agent acted on their behalf."

However that is unlikely to deter people lured by the promise of heavy discounts. On this side of the Atlantic, similar schemes have historically had little or no appeal, mainly because they have been promoted by people outside, or on the fringes, of the established trade, and because British travel agents have traditionally provided a free service. But the prospect of UK agents charging fees means that possibility can no longer be ruled out.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Share your expertise with fellow travellers.
fields.body:
L Richardson, her partner and child are flying to Milan and planning to visit Florence, Bologna, Pisa and Rome. They wanted to know about cheap accommodation and transport.

Youth Hostels are the cheapest accommodation option depending on the age of your child: £10 per night and free breakfast, but you have to be a "youth". Get information from YHA in England and try to book by international booking network from the UK. To save money on meals, look out for self-service restaurants.
Sarah Kenyon

Rail fares in Italy are based on the distance travelled so: Florence to Sienna is 8,000 lire, Sienna to Chiusi 8,000 lire, Chiusi to Rome 14,500 lire. Don't buy a Biglietto Chilo metrico costing £88 in UK. It is valid for 3,000km, but you need to travel nearly the full distance buying second-class tickets as you go before you show a small profit.
David Gill

You can check out train timetables on www.fs-on-line.it.
Gregorius Garber

Larger hotels in major towns are as expensive as anywhere, but the low-star hotels are excellent value. Lists available in all towns and from the Italian Tourist Office.
Chris and Joyce Peel

This week's question

My partner and I are planning a walking honeymoon on Mallorca in November. We want to do this as cheaply as possible. Can anyone recommend a good website for flights leaving from either Exeter or Bristol and reasonably-priced accommodation?
Mary Butler

 If you have questions or advice, please send it to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Or e-mail: ask.a.fellow.traveller@theguardian.com. We will publish the answers as soon as we can. We cannot answer questions we do not publish.

fields.headline: Stormy weather
fields.standfirst: An old hand at Hollywood despite being only 35, Perfect Storm star Diane Lane dispenses advice on making movies, growing up and deep-sea fishing
fields.trailText: An old hand at Hollywood despite being only 35, Perfect Storm star Diane Lane dispenses advice on making movies, growing up and deep-sea fishing
fields.body:
As Christina Cotter in The Perfect Storm, Diane Lane has to sit at home waiting while her fisherman boyfriend, played by Mark Wahlberg, is caught in the biggest storm to hit the US east coast in a century. The 35-year-old Lane made her stage debut aged six, starred opposite Laurence Olivier in A Little Romance when she was 13, and has been in four of Francis Ford Coppola's films. She lives in LA with her six-year-old daughter.

Why would people want to risk their lives to catch fish?

I think it's the unpredictability of it and some people really get off on risk. It's in our nature, not to tempt fate, but to push the envelope. I had no idea until I read Sebastian Junger's book about what fishing involved. To go through so much and maybe return with no fish, it's so unfair.

Would you be happy to wait at home while your man went to sea?

I don't think you choose who you fall in love with, so that's a hard question to answer. I certainly understand what it's like to be frustrated by time and distance and waiting. But this added element of surviving is more intense. I guess if I were married to a stuntman that would be close.

The movie's based on a true story, so was it strange playing a woman who is still alive?

It's a fine balance. I didn't want to meet her until I had gotten enough of the character on film. I was concerned that she'd give me information that I couldn't use, which is a terrible feeling, because I had no input on the screenplay. I wasn't sure if she'd know that and I was afraid she'd say, "Here's what really happened." She was written as quite an impetuous person in the book, so I didn't know what to expect.

So what was Christina like?

She's changed quite a bit from the woman that we're portraying in the film. She's a little more mature, a little more patient with herself. It's nine years ago now. We had dinner last night and it was great because I finally got to complete the loop between us. I really wanted her blessing to play her.

How hard was it to make the transition from being a child actor to an adult one?

Well, the business has changed quite a bit. I hope it's not just me but it seems that when I was doing it so young it was a novelty. Now, it's the norm.

What sort of changes have you seen?

I think it started with Animal House when they started to say, "That's a successful movie, let's make 50 of them." So the industry is a machine that feeds itself and it becomes very preordained. I guess old Hollywood was kind of a factory and they controlled everything, so maybe I'm just being naive. But I think there's room for different kinds of films.

Like last year's Walk On The Moon?

Yeah. We made that in the summer of 1997. Miramax had that for a while. It's a long time when you're waiting for your favourite work to come out. I loved that character.

Do you look at your early films and think, that's not me?

No, I can see that it's me but I also see that I was running blind. But at the same time there's no other way to learn. You can't skip school and wind up educated, you know. You learn from experience and I hope I'm getting better.

How do you approach acting now?

I feel like it's harvest time. I just feel that if I'm going to get to play certain roles it's going to be now. Very few people get to have Bette Davis's career you know. I mean, this is what amazes me about Hollywood, the age issue for females, so I'm trying to make hay while the sun shines.

Yeah. We made that in the summer of 1997. Miramax had that for a while. It's a long time when you're waiting for your favourite work to come out. I loved that character. Do you look at your early films and think, that's not me? No, I can see that it's me but I also see that I was running blind. But at the same time there's no other way to learn. You can't skip school and wind up educated, you know. You learn from experience and I hope I'm getting better. How do you approach acting now? I feel like it's harvest time. I just feel that if I'm going to get to play certain roles it's going to be now. Very few people get to have Bette Davis's career you know. I mean, this is what amazes me about Hollywood, the age issue for females, so I'm trying to make hay while the sun shines.

fields.headline: 42 The Calls, Leeds
fields.trailText:
Address: 42 The Calls, Leeds LS2 7EW.
Tel: 0113 244 0099.
Web address: www.42thecalls.co.uk
fields.body:
Address: 42 The Calls, Leeds LS2 7EW.
Tel: 0113 244 0099.
Web address: www.42thecalls.co.uk

First impressions: Chatty, game for a laugh. Fantastic building - a converted flour mill with old beams and solid walls. Lovely views of the canal - and convenient location opposite Tetley's Brewery.

What are the rooms like? They're all different; ours was restful blue and cream, with fresh lillies, a bowl of fruit, champers in a bucket, CD player which pipes into the bathroom, satellite TV, plate of barley sugar. Astonishingly quiet for central Leeds.

The bed test: Very comfy, but room too hot at night, and that Tetley's Brewery lets out a gigantic fart every half hour.

The bathroom test: Big bath, "42" branding on everything, wonderful towels, posh toiletries (including Molton Brown mouthwash).

The restaurant: Michelin One Star for Pool Court at 42. Excellent food and presentation but service very fussy (they even slice your bread at your table) and only one veggie choice. Three courses £37.50. Also the Brasserie at 44 for a livelier, cheaper night out. Stupendous breakfast in the hotel: kedgeree, veggie sausages, 16 types of jam.

The lounge: Small - better to nip next door to the Brasserie.

What is there to see within walking distance? The brilliant Corn Exchange area (funky shops, very lively bars); Opera North; Leeds City Art Gallery; Brewery & Granary Wharf... and Harvey Nick's.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? Wonderful Wharfedale; National Photographic Museum at Bradford; Elland Road (Leeds United's ground); Salts Mill at Saltaire (Hockney museum), 20 minutes away.

How much a night? Doubles in the week £128 (room only). Weekend doubles £125 room only (including champagne).

Would you go back? 'Appen I would.

fields.headline: Gripping stuff
fields.standfirst: As schools break up for the summer holidays, 15-year-old  Anna McGrory test drives some of Europe's top rides, starting at Spain's Port Aventura
fields.trailText: As schools break up for the summer holidays, 15-year-old Anna McGrory test drives some of Europe's top rides, starting at Spain's Port Aventura.
fields.body:
I like to think of myself as something of an expert on theme parks and white knuckle rides, having ridden such rollercoasters as Oblivion, Space Mountain and the Big One, so I was confident that nothing in Port Aventura, Universal Studios' theme park in Spain, could shake me.

But even as we approached the 2,000-acre site just outside Salou on the Costa Daurada I could see the tracks of several rides soaring into the sky and realised this was no wimp's scene. This was the real thing: towering heights, dizzying speeds and death-defying drops.

The park is divided into five "worlds": the Mediterranean, the Far West, Polynesia, Mexico and China, with appropriately themed rides, shops, games and restaurants. My favourite was China, home to the dreaded Dragon Khan, the only rollercoaster in the world with eight loops.

This ride even looks scary, with its tangled mass of red metal showing more twists and turns than an episode of Sunset Beach. It leaves your heart in your mouth and your stomach doing somersaults. It begins with a steep nerve-wracking climb up a diagonal track. Then just as you're wondering whether you should have written your will, you're off - a mind-boggling drop followed by a series of angled twists where you feel not just that you will fall out of your seat as you do on most rides, but that the 32-seater car will leave the track altogether. It is this fear and the sensation of being whizzed upside down a staggering eight times and turned on your side that pumps the adrenalin round your body.

The big new attraction at Port Aventura that opened in May this year is the £16m Sea Odyssey, which claims to be the world's most technologically-advanced underwater simulator. The concept is that guests are taken on a deep-sea voyage by a research scientist and a talking dolphin to search for and rescue a trapped vessel from a dormant volcano. The effects are achieved by a mixture of a giant screen with high resolution images and moving seats that pitch and shake as you "travel" through the ocean encountering various hazards and adventures on route. The experience of being sprayed with water as you battle with sea beasts, dodge the baddies and rescue stranded divers adds to the authenticity.

There really is plenty for everyone at Port Aventura. There are more than 90 rides ranging from those for the very small to the older and more daring. We also managed the Stampida, an effectively rackety wooden roller coaster in which two cars race against each other.

The water rides are well worth a try although if you start your day with one, as we did, you might be better off not laughingly waving aside the offer of a waterproof coat: the Tutuki Splash, for example, should be renamed the Tutuki Soak. Wet through but wised up, we then saved the Grand Canyon Rapids and the Silver River Flume until last. Getting splashed can, however, be quite refreshing in the Spanish sun.

Of course, there were queues, the bane of every theme park visitor's life, but they were not too bad on the day we went. The longest wait was only 25 minutes - nothing for someone like me who once queued for two hours for a 30-second thrill.

For those who don't like being whizzed around all day, there's a wide variety of shops, game stalls and restaurants, both themed and fast food, plus 100 daily shows. We watched two: Fort Frenzee in the Far West section, which would be particularly good for smaller children with its cowboys and cowgirls, horses, fireworks and gunfights, and the Maori dancers in Polynesia - though sit well back unless you want to be roped in for embarrassing audience participation.

At midnight, we gathered with thousands of others on the shores of the lake to watch the grand fiesta finale, a mixture of music, light and special effects. Giant models from each of the five worlds crossed the water as kites swirled and dipped in a night sky lit up by spectacular fireworks.

Address: Universal Studios Port Aventura, Costa Daurada, Spain.

Contact: 0800 966540 (www.portaventura.es).

How to get there: Return flights to Barcelona inc taxes: easyjet (Luton) £170, British Airways (LHR) £271.

Where to stay: Plenty of choice along the coast , including Tarragona Hotel Ciutat de Tarragona (4-star) (977 250909, Hotel Astari (3-star) 977 236911; Salou: Apartahotel Da Vinci (3-star) 977 580433; Apartahotel Michelangelo (apartments) 977 385214. Thomson packages to Salou (one week including flight and accommodation) around £380 per adult, £300 per child under 16.

Opening hours: 10am-midnight until Sept 17; 10am-8pm Sept 18-Nov 5 (10.30pm at weekends). Regular train and bus services from all main towns to the park. Huge car park onsite.

Prices: One day: adults £18.40/junior or senior (60-plus) £13.60; two consecutive days: £26.80/£20.80; three non-consecutive days £35.20/£27.20. Children under 4 free.

Some of the biggest, fastest and scariest from Paris to Blackpool

Alton Towers

New rides: The £4.5m Hex or the Legend of the Towers. An eerie and disorientating journey through ancient galleries and icy vaults within the 19th- century ruins at the park.

Other rides: Home to some of the most frightening rides I have ever been on, including Nemesis, Corkscrew, Ripsaw and, above all, Oblivion - a terrifying vertical drop into a black hole with a maximum speed of 110kmph and a higher G-force than astronauts experience at take-off.

Specialities: Aug 5-28: Summer Spectacle with the Royal Marines Commando Display Team. To Oct 29: Barney, singing and dancing from the purple dinosaur and friends.

Food: KFC, McDonald's and Pizza Hut, plus family restaurants such as the medieval Courtyard Tavern.

Ages & heights: Lowest height restriction: 0.9m, highest: 1.4m.

Opening hours: Grounds and gardens open 9.30am, rides and attractions at 10am. Closing times vary between 5pm and 8pm.

Prices: Adult, 1 day: (off-peak/peak) 14.95/£19.95; child, 1 day 11.95/£15.95; family (2 adults, 2 kids) 1 day £49/£59; under 4s free.

How to get there: Signposted from the M1 and M6. 6,000 parking spaces. Deals available with train companies and coaches from many stations.

Accommodation: Hotel with 175 rooms and eight themed suites, including the Oblivion Bedroom, the Princess Suite and, my favourite, the Cadbury's Chocolate Bedroom.

Address: Alton Towers, Alton, Staffordshire ST10 4DB.

Contact: 08705 204060 (www.altontowers.com)

Rating: 9/10. One point deducted for mega queues.

Blackpool Pleasure Beach

New rides: Valhalla, is a high-speed, multi-sensory, dark ride through ice, fire and storms.

Other rides: This is a must for rollercoaster fans, with 13 to choose from including the 360-degree looping Irn Bru Revolution, the high-speed Avalanche bobsleigh, wooden classics such as the Big Dipper, the Grand National and the Wild Mouse. My favourites are Ice Blast where you shoot high into the air in two seconds before plummeting down again, and the Pepsi Max Big One. Built in 1994 at a cost of £12m, it is the world's tallest and fastest rollercoaster: 235ft high, a mile in length, a top speed of 85mph and a G-force of 3.5.

Specialities: Until Nov 5: Hot Ice, a skating spectacular; Mystique, a magic show; and Eclipse, a mix of circus and ballet. Plus hyp notist Ken Webster; QEII, the Queen tribute band; the Acapulco Olympic High Dive Show; and the Bradley Beaver Show for young children.

Food: Over 40 restaurants, bars and cafés, offering anything from a sandwich to a soufflé or a burger to a boeuf bourgignon.

Ages & heights: Lowest height restriction: 1.01m; highest: 1.32m.

Opening hours: Open daily to Nov 5. Times vary, so call for details.

Prices: Rides are classified as AA (white-knuckle), A (scary), B (less scary), C (baby or tame). White Knuckle ticket: 10A and 2B tickets for £22; Pink Knuckle Ticket: 18 tickets for A, B and C rides for £22. Unlimited Ride Wristband: £25. Or pay at individual rides.

How to get there: J32 off the M6 onto the M55 , follow signs for Blackpool, South Shore and then brown tourist signs to Pleasure Beach. More than 1,000 car-parking spaces on site. Regular train services to Blackpool North and Pleasure Beach station. Call National Express on 08705 808080 for bus services.

Accommodation: No hotels on site, but loads in the town to suit every taste and budget.

Address: Ocean Boulevard, Blackpool FY4 1EZ.

Contact: 0870 444 5588 (www.blackpoolpleasurebeach.co.uk).

Rating: 9/10. Thrills galore and perfect for all the family. But pricing system can make it expensive. Can be bitterly cold.

Chessington World of Adventures

New rides: No new white-knuckle rides but Beano Land for younger children.

Other rides: Plenty of thrills including my favourite, Rameses Revenge, which lifts you high in the air, spins you around and then splashes you with water as you dangle horizontally over a fountain. Plus Vampire Ride, Bubble Works, the log flume and Samurai.

Specialities: July 15-Sept 3: park open late for "Extra Happy Hours" and "Boogie Nights". July 31-Aug 11: "Love Week".

Food: I opted for McDonald's, but there is a large selection of food stalls and restaurants.

Ages & heights: Lowest height restriction: 0.9m; highest: 1.4m.

Opening hours: Open daily to Oct 29 from 10am. Closing times vary from 5pm to 7.30pm.

Prices: (on day/open dated/date specific) Family (four people) £63/£61/ £59; adult £19.95/£18.95/ £17.95; child (under 14) £15.95/ £14.95/£13.95; OAP £11 all categories; disabled £10.45 all categories; children under 4 free. Tickets can be booked at least two days before by telephone or online.

How to get there: two miles from the A3 and the M25 J9 and J10 on the A243. Trains to Chessington plus buses.

Accommodation: No hotel on site.

Address: Leatherhead Road, Chessington, Surrey KT9 2NE.

Contact: 0870 444 7777 (www.chessington.com)

Rating: 7/10. Not enough scary rides, disappointing log flume.

Disneyland Paris

New rides: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Peril has a new twist - the high-speed chase on board a mine cart now goes backwards too! A must for all white-knuckle experts and, in my view, the best ride on site.

The new "fast pass" "virtual queuing" system claims to alleviate waiting times at the most popular rides during the busy summer months.

Other rides: Over 50 in five themed areas, including Thunder Mountain, another runaway mine train but suitable for most (even my mother could stomach it) and the famous Space Mountain, where you are catapulted from a cannon into a spiral of loops and twists. Not one to ride with a headache.

Specialities: ImagiNations Parade, a 50-minute march with 100 performers and seven floats led by Mickey Mouse,aerial show Tarzan Encounter, Winnie the Pooh and Friends and the Electric Light Parade every night at 10.30pm, followed by Tinker Bell's Fantasy in the Sky fireworks display.

Food: Dozens of restaurants with ethnic themes plus favourites such as McDonald's.

Ages & heights: Lowest height restriction: 1m if not accompanied by an adult. Highest 1.4m.

Opening hours: July 8-Sept 3: 9am-11pm; Sept 4-Nov 30: 10am-8pm.

Prices: 1-day passport: adult £23/child £18; 2-day passport: £45/£35; 3-day passport: £63/£48; under 3s: free.

How to get there: Eurostar operates a daily direct service (until Sept 24) from Waterloo International and Ashford. Ferry or plane passengers can pick up a shuttle bus to the park from the centre of Paris.

Accommodation: Seven themed hotels, including the art-deco New York and the Wild West Cheyenne, all located a short walk or shuttle ride from the park.

Address: Disneyland Paris, Paris, France.

Contact: 08705 030303 (www.disney.co.uk)

Rating: 7/10. Expensive to get to. It was a disappointment not getting to touch Mickey Mouse - even we cool thrill seekers want to see him, but the crowds were impossible.

Thorpe Park

New rides: £5m Tidal Wave, the highest water ride in Europe, with a heart-pumping 85ft drop with accompanying 40ft splash.

Other rides: The best log flume I have ever ridden and rapids that you wish would never end. Plus a great rollercoaster, the Flying Fish, a guts-churning swinging boat, a four-lane water slide and the scary but enjoyable No Way Out, which plummets you backwards in pitch dark.

Specialities: Mardi Gras carnival with bands and street performers on July 29 and every Saturday in August and August Bank Holiday Monday.

Food: A variety of themed restaurants, fast-food joints, snack kiosks and sweet shops.

Ages & heights: Lowest height restriction: 0.9m; highest: 1.4m

Opening hours: Open daily from 10am weekdays, 9.30am weekends and school holidays to Oct 29. Closing times vary from 5pm to 7.30pm.

Prices: (on day/specified date in advance/open dated in advance) adult £18.50/ £16.50/£17.50; child £14.50/£12.50/ £13.50; OAP £14/£12/ £13; disabled £11/na/na; helper free/ free/free; family (2+2/1+3) £59/£56/£54

How to get there: On the A320 between Staines and Chertsey and easily reached from J11 and J13 of the M25. Parking for 8,000 cars. Nearest station, Staines.

Accommodation: No hotel on site.

Address: Thorpe Park, Staines Road, Chertsey, Surrey, KT16 8PN.

Contact: 0870 444 44 66, (www.thorpepark.com)

Rating: 8/10. Not enough white-knuckle rides, but brilliant for families.

Anna's top 10 tips

1 Find out in advance where the camera is that's going to capture you at the scariest point. That way, you can prepare a cheeky grin or cool pout.

2 Get a map and plan the day ahead, especially if you are part of a large group - there's nothing worse than arguments over what ride to go on next.

3 Work your way up to the bigger rides. If you go on them first, all the rest will seem too tame in comparison.

4 Rides that attract long queues are more accessible during big parades. Queues are shorter in Spain at lunchtime.

5 Don't wear heels. They're uncomfortable, and you may have to remove them in front of everyone so the park stewards can check your height.

6 Word games can take your mind off long queues and pre-ride nerves.

7 Don't eat a huge meal, double scoop ice cream, can of cola or candy floss just before you go on a ride that involves spinning around.

8 Don't take a heavy bag, just a bum bag or mini rucksack.

9 If nerves get the better of you, don't shut your eyes but try counting out loud or repeating the same sentence until the ordeal is over.

10 When going on a wet ride, keep your handbag shut.

How to get there: J32 off the M6 onto the M55 , follow signs for Blackpool, South Shore and then brown tourist signs to Pleasure Beach. More than 1,000 car-parking spaces on site. Regular train services to Blackpool North and Pleasure Beach station. Call National Express on 08705 808080 for bus services. Accommodation: No hotels on site, but loads in the town to suit every taste and budget. Address: Ocean Boulevard, Blackpool FY4 1EZ. Contact: 0870 444 5588 (www.blackpoolpleasurebeach.co.uk). Rating: 9/10. Thrills galore and perfect for all the family. But pricing system can make it expensive. Can be bitterly cold. Chessington World of Adventures New rides: No new white-knuckle rides but Beano Land for younger children. Other rides: Plenty of thrills including my favourite, Rameses Revenge, which lifts you high in the air, spins you around and then splashes you with water as you dangle horizontally over a fountain. Plus Vampire Ride, Bubble Works, the log flume and Samurai. Specialities: July 15-Sept 3: park open late for "Extra Happy Hours" and "Boogie Nights". July 31-Aug 11: "Love Week". Food: I opted for McDonald's, but there is a large selection of food stalls and restaurants. Ages & heights: Lowest height restriction: 0.9m; highest: 1.4m. Opening hours: Open daily to Oct 29 from 10am. Closing times vary from 5pm to 7.30pm. Prices: (on day/open dated/date specific) Family (four people) £63/£61/ £59; adult £19.95/£18.95/ £17.95; child (under 14) £15.95/ £14.95/£13.95; OAP £11 all categories; disabled £10.45 all categories; children under 4 free. Tickets can be booked at least two days before by telephone or online. How to get there: two miles from the A3 and the M25 J9 and J10 on the A243. Trains to Chessington plus buses. Accommodation: No hotel on site. Address: Leatherhead Road, Chessington, Surrey KT9 2NE. Contact: 0870 444 7777 (www.chessington.com) Rating: 7/10. Not enough scary rides, disappointing log flume. Disneyland Paris New rides: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Peril has a new twist - the high-speed chase on board a mine cart now goes backwards too! A must for all white-knuckle experts and, in my view, the best ride on site. The new "fast pass" "virtual queuing" system claims to alleviate waiting times at the most popular rides during the busy summer months. Other rides: Over 50 in five themed areas, including Thunder Mountain, another runaway mine train but suitable for most (even my mother could stomach it) and the famous Space Mountain, where you are catapulted from a cannon into a spiral of loops and twists. Ferry or plane passengers can pick up a shuttle bus to the park from the centre of Paris. Accommodation: Seven themed hotels, including the art-deco New York and the Wild West Cheyenne, all located a short walk or shuttle ride from the park. Address: Disneyland Paris, Paris, France. Contact: 08705 030303 (www.disney.co.uk) Rating: 7/10. Expensive to get to. It was a disappointment not getting to touch Mickey Mouse - even we cool thrill seekers want to see him, but the crowds were impossible. Thorpe Park New rides: £5m Tidal Wave, the highest water ride in Europe, with a heart-pumping 85ft drop with accompanying 40ft splash. Other rides: The best log flume I have ever ridden and rapids that you wish would never end. Plus a great rollercoaster, the Flying Fish, a guts-churning swinging boat, a four-lane water slide and the scary but enjoyable No Way Out, which plummets you backwards in pitch dark. Specialities: Mardi Gras carnival with bands and street performers on July 29 and every Saturday in August and August Bank Holiday Monday. Food: A variety of themed restaurants, fast-food joints, snack kiosks and sweet shops. Ages & heights: Lowest height restriction: 0.9m; highest: 1.4m Opening hours: Open daily from 10am weekdays, 9.30am weekends and school holidays to Oct 29. Closing times vary from 5pm to 7.30pm. Prices: (on day/specified date in advance/open dated in advance) adult £18.50/ £16.50/£17.50; child £14.50/£12.50/ £13.50; OAP £14/£12/ £13; disabled £11/na/na; helper free/ free/free; family (2+2/1+3) £59/£56/£54 How to get there: On the A320 between Staines and Chertsey and easily reached from J11 and J13 of the M25. Parking for 8,000 cars. Nearest station, Staines. Accommodation: No hotel on site. Address: Thorpe Park, Staines Road, Chertsey, Surrey, KT16 8PN. Contact: 0870 444 44 66, (www.thorpepark.com) Rating: 8/10. Not enough white-knuckle rides, but brilliant for families. Anna's top 10 tips 1 Find out in advance where the camera is that's going to capture you at the scariest point. That way, you can prepare a cheeky grin or cool pout. 2 Get a map and plan the day ahead, especially if you are part of a large group - there's nothing worse than arguments over what ride to go on next. 3 Work your way up to the bigger rides. If you go on them first, all the rest will seem too tame in comparison. 4 Rides that attract long queues are more accessible during big parades. Queues are shorter in Spain at lunchtime. 5 Don't wear heels. They're uncomfortable, and you may have to remove them in front of everyone so the park stewards can check your height. 6 Word games can take your mind off long queues and pre-ride nerves. 7 Don't eat a huge meal, double scoop ice cream, can of cola or candy floss just before you go on a ride that involves spinning around. 8 Don't take a heavy bag, just a bum bag or mini rucksack. 9 If nerves get the better of you, don't shut your eyes but try counting out loud or repeating the same sentence until the ordeal is over. 10 When going on a wet ride, keep your handbag shut.

webTitle: Welsh assembly's debates utterly boring, says Morgan

fields.headline: Welsh assembly's debates utterly boring, says Morgan
fields.trailText: July 22 2000: Rhodri Morgan, Wales's first secretary, admitted yesterday that the assembly is so boring that viewing its proceedings is like "watching paint dry".
fields.body:
The Welsh assembly has struggled to make its mark since last year's grand opening ceremony in Cardiff - and now we know why.

Rhodri Morgan, Wales's first secretary, admitted yesterday that the assembly is so boring that viewing its proceedings is like "watching paint dry".

The outspoken Mr Morgan, who has devoted his career to fighting for devolution in Wales, blamed the calibre of assembly members and the limited powers of the new body for its dreary debates.

"Performance of the assembly has not been as punchy or as focused or as strong or as interesting for the people outside as I would have liked," Mr Morgan said in an interview with BBC News 24's One to One programme.

"The kind of secondary legislation that we have powers over, that we debate on a typical Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon, is like watching paint dry."

Mr Morgan's remarks will come as a surprise to Labour leaders, who have been impressed by his handling of the assembly after he replaced the Blair favourite Alun Michael as first secretary earlier this year. But the assembly has failed to make the same sort of mark as the Scottish parliament.

Mr Morgan puts this down to the limited powers devolved to Wales, which is an assembly rather than a parliament.

Devolution also never won the same support in Wales as it did in Scotland. The referendum in Wales was won on the votes of the final constituency. Only a quarter of the population voted for the assembly.

Mr Morgan also struck a seri ous note, when he warned that Britain's failure to join the euro risked deterring inward investors. "I think we would all say, 'This is one of those decisions where everybody wants to go to heaven, but nobody wants to die first'," Mr Morgan said. "So you say, in 10 years' time everybody thinks we will be in the euro, realistically."

webTitle: Britain still selling arms to rights violators

fields.headline: Britain still selling arms to rights violators
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Britain is continuing to sell arms to countries involved in regional aggression or with poor human rights records, in spite of its commitment to an ethical foreign policy, according to the government's annual report on arms exports published yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain is continuing to sell arms to countries involved in regional aggression or with poor human rights records, in spite of its commitment to an ethical foreign policy, according to the government's annual report on arms exports published yesterday.

Two of the biggest buyers of British arms are Indonesia and Saudi Arabia, both with poor human rights records. The two account for 25% of British arms sales.

Other countries with scant regard for human rights, such as China and Bahrain, also receive British military equipment.

Weapons are also going to both India and Pakistan, two nuclear powers engaged in a stand-off in Kashmir.

Human rights organisations and campaigners seeking to clean up the arms trade welcomed the report as a step to wards transparency. But they expressed disappointment that sales decisions failed to match the government's rhetoric.

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said: "Arms exports provide the most searching test of ethics in foreign policy. It is high time the government passed that test."

The foreign office minister, Peter Hain, was unapologetic, saying: "This report underlines the government's strong commitment to greater openness in arms licensing policy and reinforces the UK's position as one of the most responsible and transparent arms exporting states in the world."

He added: "We have banned the sale of types of equipment that have been used in torture and led the way to ban landmines across the world. We are committed to tackling the problem of small arms proliferation and have taken many positive steps to promote a responsible, legal trade and to combat illicit trafficking, including taking part in major initiatives in southern Africa and Albania."

The 345-page report - produced jointly by the Foreign Office, the Department of Trade and Industry, and the Ministry of Defence - details the sale and value of British arms sales to individual countries. It is the third such report since Labour came to power, and is the most transparent yet, following criticism from a Commons select committee that last year's report was too obscure. But huge gaps in information remain.

Ministers issued 8,967 standard export licences, down from 9,689 licences in the previous year. The number of "open licences", which allow multi-shipments of arms to certain destinations, was also down, 449 against 556 the previous year.

The total value of arms exports halved, down to £980m from £1.9bn the previous year. But arms campaigners said the fall was not significant because the trade tended to fluctuate. A Foreign Office official attributed the fall to the tailing-off of the big Saudi arms contract signed under the Conservatives and the economic crisis that had hit much of Asia.

Saudi Arabia bought £131m worth of arms from Britain in 1999, ranging from naval parts to ground-to-air missiles. Saudi Arabia has been repeatedly criticised by human rights groups for carrying out executions as well as for amputating the hands and feet of criminals. Sales to Indonesia have dogged Robin Cook since he became foreign secretary. The report shows it bought £102m in military equipment, including 10 Hawk aircraft.

Indonesia's armed forces have been involved in repression in its own country, with its soldiers responsible for abuses in East Timor.

China, which Amnesty International said had last year engaged in its worst human rights abuses for a decade, bought £42m in equipment, ranging from aero-engines, radar equipment, and explosives to ammunition.

India bought armoured vehicles, combat aircraft equipment, nuclear biological and chemical weapon detection systems, and night-sights.

An arms embargo was imposed on Pakistan in October after a military coup but before that it received mortars, armoured personnel carriers, combat aircraft and produc tion equipment for assault rifles and machine guns. The embargo has now been lifted.

There was a similar row over arms exports to Zimbabwe, which bought £60,000 of equipment, in spite of near bankruptcy. Zimbabwe has been condemned for intervening in the war in the Congo.

Legislation to tighten up control of the arms trade is expected to be in the Queen's Speech in the autumn.

Paul Eavis, director of one of the campaigning groups, Saferworld, said yesterday: "I will be deeply disappointed if no new legislation governing arms exports is forthcoming in this parliament."

Beverley Duckworth, an Amnesty spokeswoman, said: "This report only provides details of arms exports covered by a law which is full of loopholes. But many arms transfers go completely unregulated."

Cleaning up the trade would not mean the end of British arms manufacturing. Much of the hardware goes to uncontroversial destinations, such as £69m last year to Italy.

webTitle: Stewart out for 97 but England lift trophy

fields.headline: Stewart out for 97 but England lift trophy
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe 169 for 7 (50 overs)
England 170 for 4 (45.2 overs)
England won by 6 wickets
fields.trailText: England have won the NatWest Triangular Series, beating Zimbabwe in the final at Lord's by six wickets with 28 balls to spare. Set 170 to win, England were in trouble at 9 for 2, but Alec Stewart, with 97, and Graeme Hick (41) added 134 to set England on the path to their first one-day trophy since winning at Sharjah in 1997-98. Stewart's last four innings in one-day internationals have now been 74*, 101, 101* and 97. And they said he was too old.
fields.body:
England have won the NatWest Triangular Series, beating Zimbabwe in the final at Lord's by six wickets with 28 balls to spare. Set 170 to win, England were in trouble at 9 for 2, but Alec Stewart, with 97, and Graeme Hick (41) added 134 to set England on the path to their first one-day trophy since winning at Sharjah in 1997-98. Stewart's last four innings in one-day internationals have now been 74*, 101, 101* and 97. And they said he was too old.

It was batting of the highest order - and it rescued England from a tight spot. Heath Streak had got rid of Marcus Trescothick, caught at first slip for 1 cutting a ball that was too close to him, and Andrew Flintoff, bowled fourth ball through the gate for a duck, to leave England tottering at 9 for 2 in the third over.

Stewart's response was immediate: he cracked Mluleki Nkala for three consecutive off-side fours in the next over, and although England added just one run in four overs after that, the run-rate was never an issue. With the sun out and Zimbabwe obliged to attack, England just had to keep their nerve.

Bryan Strang took 16 balls to concede a run, but Stewart had played himself in by then, and followed a slashing square-cut off Strang with an off-drive for four more in his next over.

The 50 came up in the 17th over, and Stewart brought up the fifty stand with three through mid-on off Dirk Viljoen. He moved to his own half-century off his 75th ball with a single to long-off, before slapping Neil Johnson for four through mid-on in the next over.

Hick had been little more than a spectator up to now, but Viljoen dished up a full-toss and Hick swatted him for four over mid-on. When Johnson bowled a wider one in the next over Stewart cracked him square for four. It had been his most productive shot of the day.

England moved to 100 when Stewart mis-timed Guy Whittall to the long-on boundary, but a pull for four soon after off Streak was far more authoritative. And the 100 stand came up when Hick paddled Whittall for a couple to fine leg.

By now the game was virtually over, and interest now centred on Stewart's attempts to notch a third successive hundred. A single off Viljoen took him to 400 runs in the series, 112 ahead of his nearest competitor, Trescothick. Stewart then moved to 93 with a glorious cover-drive for four off Streak, and to 97 the ball after with a flick through midwicket as Streak drifted onto his pads.

One more boundary and Stewart would become the first Englishman to hit three consecutive one-day hundreds. But from the next ball he aimed another crashing cover-drive and edged through to Andy Flower. Out for 97. Lord's rose as Stewart smiled wryly.

He had added 134 for the third wicket with Hick, and England needed just 27 with more than 16 overs to spare. But Hick fell four runs later for 41, patting the ball straight back to the bowler Viljoen.

Graham Thorpe and Nasser Hussain knocked off the runs in an atmosphere of anti-climax and England had won a competition in which, forgetting the blip at Trent Bridge against West Indies, they had got progressively better.

Earlier, Zimbabwe had laboured their way to 169 for 7 in 50 overs in overcast conditions far more conducive to seam bowling. The meat was provided by the Flower brothers, who added 89 for the fifth wicket to give Zimbabwe a fighting chance. Andy made 48 and Grant finished not out 53. They rescued the innings from the depths of 31 for 4 from 15 oves after Darren Gough had picked up two early wickets. Gough finished with three for 20, adding the scalp of Heath Streak in the final over, after Streak had deposited White for two sixes over extra cover the over before.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

England moved to 100 when Stewart mis-timed Guy Whittall to the long-on boundary, but a pull for four soon after off Streak was far more authoritative. And the 100 stand came up when Hick paddled Whittall for a couple to fine leg. By now the game was virtually over, and interest now centred on Stewart's attempts to notch a third successive hundred. A single off Viljoen took him to 400 runs in the series, 112 ahead of his nearest competitor, Trescothick. Stewart then moved to 93 with a glorious cover-drive for four off Streak, and to 97 the ball after with a flick through midwicket as Streak drifted onto his pads. One more boundary and Stewart would become the first Englishman to hit three consecutive one-day hundreds. But from the next ball he aimed another crashing cover-drive and edged through to Andy Flower. Out for 97. Lord's rose as Stewart smiled wryly. He had added 134 for the third wicket with Hick, and England needed just 27 with more than 16 overs to spare. But Hick fell four runs later for 41, patting the ball straight back to the bowler Viljoen. Graham Thorpe and Nasser Hussain knocked off the runs in an atmosphere of anti-climax and England had won a competition in which, forgetting the blip at Trent Bridge against West Indies, they had got progressively better. Earlier, Zimbabwe had laboured their way to 169 for 7 in 50 overs in overcast conditions far more conducive to seam bowling. The meat was provided by the Flower brothers, who added 89 for the fifth wicket to give Zimbabwe a fighting chance. Andy made 48 and Grant finished not out 53. They rescued the innings from the depths of 31 for 4 from 15 oves after Darren Gough had picked up two early wickets. Gough finished with three for 20, adding the scalp of Heath Streak in the final over, after Streak had deposited White for two sixes over extra cover the over before. fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: www.travelleronline.com
fields.trailText: www.travelleronline.com
fields.body:
The Independent Traveller's Club... this sounds like rather an exclusive website.

Indeed. The organisation behind Traveller Online is Wexas, the World Expeditionary Association, which counts David Bellamy, Sir Ranulph Fiennes and Michael Palin among its honorary presidents. It is a rare Heart of Darkness among the tawdry package escapism of the bigger travel sites.

No package holidays?

Absolutely none. The site holds a collection of useful travel tools and information, most of which are scattered elsewhere on the web. You can save important personal details in Passepartout, read the Columbus Travel Guides, hire a mobile phone or set up an e-mail address for holidays.

Can I book a flight, though?

That's rather complicated. Registering allows you to search the OAG database of flight information, but it doesn't give any prices, and the interface is distinctly old-fashioned. Most of the special deals on flights are for business class only. Traveller Online links to a few other services such as thetrainline. com, but there's no great advantage to booking here.

Oddity of the week

Your Daily Escape

Every day, Away.com presents a different postcard from somewhere in the world. You can make it into screen wallpaper, find out more about the place, or count down the days, weeks or months until your next holiday.

Nominate a travel oddity on the web by e-mailing: ros.taylor@theguardian.com
