fields.headline: Into the sunset
fields.standfirst: What are Saga holidays really like? Playwright  Bernard Kops joins 49 other over-50s on a cruise down the Yangtze
fields.trailText: What are Saga holidays really like? Playwright Bernard Kops joins 49 other over-50s on a cruise down the Yangtze.
fields.body:
'The damming of the Yangtze river has already commenced, and, slowly but surely, this amazing landscape will be lost forever. You can enjoy a memorable cruise on this river before it changes irreversibly." Thus, the Saga brochure announced its Yangtze trip on the Victoria Pearl for the over-50s.

"Do the kids know where we left the will?" Angst always strikes me at 39,000ft. To calm my rampant fear, I finally got down to reading the Saga itinerary. "Unfortunately standards of public convenience in China are not as high in as in most western countries." And there was another ominous warning. "Water used for drinking, brushing teeth or making ice should be sterilised or boiled before use." It seemed that the two most important ends of the body could turn your holiday into a nightmare.

I swallowed my aspirin and did the first of my two-minute walks around the aircraft, clocking my dozing Saga companions. "They're all rehearsing for death," I said returning.

"Just relax and enjoy." Erica has this most infuriating habit of looking on the bright side.

I fired another salvo. "How many coffins do you reckon the ship carries in its hold?" I resisted the temptation to look for myself when, on the quay at Chongqing, I first set eyes on the Victoria Pearl, our mother for the next eight days, squatting benignly on the Yangtze.

"Offering the best in comfort and facilities, ensuring your journey is relaxed and enjoyable." She had everything. T'ai chi, Jacuzzi, acupressure, calligraphy expert, kite maker, massage. A waiting, beaming crew. But how to get on board?

She was several hundred yards away, across the muddy shore, and there were several narrow planks to negotiate. It did not quite compare with the gangway of QE2. In abject terror, I held my breath and my wife. The other Senior Saga Somnambulists, a chain gang of 49 souls, were wobbling across the planks; jolly and joking. What it is about the British? Why are they so incredibly stoic? Talk about gallows humour. Dunkirk came to mind.

Once onboard, all the survivors relaxed, chatted. Feeling a sense of achievement. We nibbled, drank and started to coalesce. And there was that wonderful complex smell of Chinese food wafting up from the kitchens. Ah! The food! The food! It was continuously spectacular, even better than my local in north London.

We were moving. We were off up the Yangtze, the Chang Jiang, heading for the fabled Three Gorges, meandering the heartland of China.

Dapper, bearded Mike from Nottingham informed us that the river was 6,300km long, from the Tibetan plateau to the East China Sea.

Later, when I entered the Dynasty Lounge, the truth dawned. An ominous gong reverberated in my bones. All my travelling companions were over the hill. Up until now, I had kidded myself that I had been slowly negotiating the early foothills of middle age. "Erica! How did I get to be 73?" I went upstairs, resigned to my fate and joined the other inmates on deck. Renee from Harrow on the Hill bee-lined for us. She was well into the hinterland of 70 years. She was urbane, elegant and sophisticated; and still quite sexy. There was still hope for us all. She had been everywhere.

"My husband died 10 years ago. I must have travelled 30 countries since then." What energy. What expense.

Renee was not unique. This travelling seemed to be an occupation, the method of survival for many of the unattached people on board. Joan was another widow. She was once a mathematician, but now she was an inveterate traveller. Ever since she lost her husband at an impossibly early age, she hadn't been able to settle at home. "I've been away four times already this year. It's become a sort of obsession."

I looked out of the window. The misty landscape slowly passed like an intangible dream. The Victoria Pearl was a bit like life. You hardly knew you were moving but suddenly you found yourself at a new destination. Was I the only one wondering if the old man with his scythe would hobble up the gangplank come next stop?

The Three Gorges. The gentle lush green mountains like so many soft sweet breasts loomed up in the mist, undulating into the far distance, at once therapeutic, making me feel more serene than I had ever felt since hitting three score and 10.

"Look!" Mr Romford Essex waxed elegiac for Mrs Romford Essex. "Look! Just like a Chinese painting."

Indeed. Painters had been trying to recapture this magic for over 1,000 years.

Dapper Michael with the incurable energy and enthusiasm of a schoolboy didn't actually have time to admire the scene. He was running from one end of the ship to another, dashing up and down the decks, clicking away with his camera like the end of the world. Before the end of the journey he would use up 36 reels of film.

Michael had had done his homework; seemed to know more about China and the Chinese than anyone else on board. "Thirteen cities will disappear with the flooding, 140 towns, 1,352 villages. All this will disappear when the great dam is completed in 2009." He went on clicking.

Going ashore, we all were excited as schoolkids as we zoomed upward by cable car to the top of Zhongshan Lu and looked back down at the Yangtze. She had been free and unfettered for 5,000 years. She had witnessed everything, all the years of Chinese history from the Xia dynasty 2,000 years before Christ to the long march of Mao, and the terrible Cultural Revolution. And now the greatest revolution was about to unfold.

The word was "reform". A palatable euphemism for the blatant capitalism that was taking place all over this vast land. You wait! In 30 years or so, this mind-blowing country would become the greatest nation on earth. But we, the present passengers of Victoria Pearl, would not be around. We would have long since embarked on SS Styx.

It was happy hour: 30% off all drinks in the Yangtze Bar. Later, I went up on deck, sought a quiet corner to re-read my Arthur Waley translation of Li Bai. The moon was shivering on the surface of the Long River. More than 1,000 years ago Li Bai wrote: "Drinking alone, with no friend near, raising my cup, I beckon the bright moon. My shadow included, we're a party of three."

Li Bai could match Dylan Thomas when it came to words and drink. In his cups he tried to embrace his beloved moon in the river. And drowned. It was ever thus.

All revelry had died on the lower decks. Sleep cocooned the entire ship. I peeped around corridors, hoping to spy at least one superannuated Lothario tapping on the cabin door of an expectant peripatetic widow. Sadly, no throaty voice whispered back. National Health dentures were all safely submerged in tumblers of bottled water in the bathrooms. There would be no orgasmic shrieks from Saga Sirens tonight.

Middle England was deep in endlessness. Like Li Bai, I also turned in. But I embraced my sleeping wife and not the Dragon River.

Next morning, wild monkeys ambled down from the heights to gape at us gapers. The balmy breezes of the Gorge caused the earlier humidity to vanish. The atmosphere was pure golden wine.

The world of the ship was serene, calm, perfect. But the world ashore, in China, was mind-blowing. Impressions kept coming thick and fast. You needed a holiday from this holiday.

We arrived at Fengdu. The Ghost City. In the temple horrendous stone ghost figures smashed each other, and ate stone babies. Sinister Tao monks grabbed yuan in exchange for a stick of incense. It was Madame Tussauds on Walpurgis Eve.

Our young guide possessed a nice sense of humour; she didn't bombard us with dreary statistics, the expected rice yield for the next five years. But rather she informed us about the lives, dreams, and problems of the local people. Fengdu town was an endless torrent of living people. Dogs, lizards, frogs and pheasants in cages, waiting to be poked and devoured. In two years, all this street life would disappear, drowned by the waters of the Yangtze. That park, the kids at their games. The toothless old men who were still too young to qualify for Saga. I looked up to where the new town was being constructed on top of the mountain above and felt sick.

I was amazed at the fortitude of some of the less-mobile travellers among us. Anne and Bob, despite being disabled, managed most of the arduous journeys with incredible humour. Sometimes, they struggled on the arm of a member of the crew, and sometimes they went up and down all the mountains carried in Sedan chairs.

"Having a good time?"

"Wonderful," they both shouted back. They were so brave and so life affirming. Their praise for the staff was absolute. "Marvellous. So caring." No brochure could claim more. Bob and Anne never moaned once. They will remain in my memory. Another shore trip was to witness the great dam under construction. More than 40,000 construction workers; busy, tireless men and women ants, massed on a mound; the largest construction site on earth. Their mission? To build a new China. To seek a glorious future. And in the process to eliminate the Three Gorges, one of the most beautiful sights on the planet. I could hear Kurt Vonnegut sighing. "So it goes."

It took three and a half hours to drive to the Yellow Mountains. When we arrived, Jimmy Rea from Glasgow produced his bagpipes and began to coax it to full croak. An astonished crowd of Chinese and Japanese tourists stood around, excited like five year olds as he led us upwards, playing Scotland the Brave. The path was gentle, but there was an awful lot of heavy breathing. And when we reached the summit, one of our three ladies from Galashiels tripped over the edge. It was a mile down. We all died, until she emerged bruised and smiling. A clump of bamboo sticks broke her fall, stopped her from becoming haggis.

Back in the coach. Our local guide announced that he would like to sing us a song. People groaned, but this did not stop him immediately plunging into his awful aria: "Edelweiss. Edelweiss. Everyone morning you greet me . . ." We clapped like mad when he finished.

On the long way back, all I can focus upon was the wonderful, bountiful dinner waiting for us.

When we finally clambered off the coach our guide told us how happy he had been to serve us, while his narrowing eyes clocked up the yuan that was pressed into his hand. Total ineptitude sometimes pays. Come to think of it, almost all the local guides were abysmal. But there were two exceptions, and both of these were young women.

Suddenly, like life, time quickened. Just as you settled in, you have to settle out. An aura pervaded the ship, telling us that this Saga was all over. The river opened out and we could barely see its banks. But factories in the foggy distance belched fire, and everywhere people were hurrying, scurrying, building. Gargantuan container ships loomed and the Yangtze had lost its close embrace. Its foghorns moaned, warning that Shanghai was fast coming towards us. It was all over. It was time for us to go.

I looked back for the last time at the long river. This truly was a Saga. More than 500m people were sustained by its endless journey. This river was the very lifeblood of this impossible and incredible land. It linked all the ages; the long history of China. But for me, it now sang a threnody. China was looking forward and was reinventing herself.

In 1956, Mao astonished the world by swimming across this Yangtze. Shortly after, he wrote a poem called Swimming: "Great plans are afoot . . . To hold back Wushan's clouds and rain. Till a smooth lake rises in the narrow gorges. The mountain God dess, if she is still there, will marvel at a world so changed."

But 1,000 years ago, Li Bai, that other poet, wrote: "Looking at the old river,/ From the opposite banks of a yellow ribbon/Like reading an ancient scroll./Pictographs of man's flailing/Against the eddies of oft-told histories."

Between these two visions, China is delicately balanced.

As we got off Victoria Pearl, Sonia from Cardiff and her breathless husband followed behind. "Did you enjoy yourself?" I asked.

"Immensely," she replied. "But I am a little disappointed. I thought Saga meant Sex and Games for the Aged. All I got were the games."

The practicals

The 10-night Yangtze to the Yellow Sea holiday with Victoria Cruises from Saga Holidays Ltd, Freepost, FO49, Sandgate, Kent CT20 3SE (0800 056 5880) costs from £1,349 per person, including flights and insurance, 10 breakfasts, six lunches and 10 dinners. Saga holidays are exclusively for people aged 50 and over. Austrian Airlines (0845 601 0948) flies three times a week from Heathrow to Beijing and Shanghai, and Virgin Atlantic (01293 747747) flies Heathrow to Shanghai, all from £614 return.

 Bernard Kops' latest book, Shalom Bomb, Scenes from My Life, is published by Oberon Books at £15.99.

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst: The Family Handbook (National Trust, £6.99)
fields.trailText: The Family Handbook
fields.body:
They can be relied upon to tell you most things about a property, from the name of the man who designed the ormolu clock in the salon to the year that the second viscount had the nearby village converted into a lake. But when it comes to pointing out the best grassy slopes for running down, National Trust guidebooks are next to useless.

Similarly they won't invite you to imagine you are a Roman soldier on the look-out for Picts and Scots, to climb on to a cannon or to shout loudly in order to hear your voice echoing around the stone tower.

Which is why the Trust has produced this attractive, spiral-bound book that views a selection of its properties through the eyes of children.

It offers 125 ideas for days out at properties as diverse as George Stephenson's birthplace ("Clamber on to the beds to discover what it felt like to be a family asleep in one room") and the Victorian fort overlooking the Needles ("Learn to use the Beaufort Scale to work out how strong the wind is").

There are lists of things to see ("messages written in the woodwork by Tudor carpenters") and no end of things to do ("try out the spinning wheel - not so easy!"). There's even a section of puzzles and stickers - to make the journey as much fun as the arriving.

It offers 125 ideas for days out at properties as diverse as George Stephenson's birthplace ("Clamber on to the beds to discover what it felt like to be a family asleep in one room") and the Victorian fort overlooking the Needles ("Learn to use the Beaufort Scale to work out how strong the wind is"). webTitle: Raphael Rowe was freed as one of the M25 Three. But his fight for justice goes on

fields.headline: Raphael Rowe was freed as one of the M25 Three. But his fight for justice goes on
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Raphael Rowe thought the long fight to clear his name would end the day his convictions were quashed and he walked free from court.
fields.body:
Raphael Rowe thought the long fight to clear his name would end the day his convictions were quashed and he walked free from court.

But when the moment finally came at lunchtime on Monday - 10 years into a life sentence for a murder and robberies he insists he did not commit - the euphoria quickly turned to anger.

In his eyes, there had been another injustice. Instead of sympathising with Rowe and his co-defendants Michael Davis and Randolph Johnson, the court of appeal could not have been more grudging.

The men, known as the M25 Three, were being released only on technicalities. Lord Justice Mantell finished his judgment by saying: "This is not a finding of innocence, far from it."

That night, Rowe and Davis met at a relative's house to share a glass of champagne, but it was not much of a celebration. When Rowe, 32, woke up, he was still fighting. "I know the judges were involved in a damage limitation exercise. But what they said was diabolical.

"They didn't say I was guilty, but that's how everyone interpreted it. I have battled every day of the last 12 years to prove I was set up by the police, to prove I am not a murderer. It has been my passion. I am free now, but it's as if I'm still inside. I'm still trying to get my voice heard."

Friday, December 16, 1988 is the date which changed his life. In the early hours, three masked men, one carrying a knife, another a gun, surprised a gay couple, Peter Hurburgh and Alan Eley, who were making love in a car parked in a field near Fickleshaw, Surrey.

They were beaten and robbed. The gang poured petrol around them and someone lit a cigarette. Mr Eley passed out and when he woke his lover was dead. He had suffered a heart attack.

Next, the three men drove to a house in Oxted, 10 miles away. They stole rings and jewellery, and stabbed a man, Timothy Napier. At 5am, they robbed a couple living in a house in Fetcham, 20 miles from Oxted. The victims were certain that one, possibly two, of the robbers were white. The police were equally certain that Rowe, Davis and Johnson - three black men - were responsible.

All had criminal records; Davis, a childhood friend of Rowe's, pleaded guilty to a robbery committed days before the M25 offences. Johnson, a friend of Davis, had raped a woman on the same job. Rowe had previous convictions, one for malicious wounding.

"I've done things I regret. I was 18 in 1988, and when you are that age you are selfish and you don't realise the impact of what you are doing. You don't see the consequences. But murder is not something I could ever do."

Rowe detests Johnson. "I didn't know Randolph before all this and I don't want to know him now. We don't speak. I abhor the fact he raped a woman. We were in the same dock, but that's it as far as I am concerned."

He is increasingly estranged from Davis. Last Saturday they shared a cell at Pentonville prison for the first time in 12 years. Rowe, who was on the top bunk, woke in the middle of the night to hear Davis screaming in his sleep.

"Michael and I have developed in different ways. Prison affects everyone. I've seen some terrible things - fights where men have had boiling water thrown on them in a row over a bit of tobacco and their skin has peeled off. Some people crumble and collapse in the system. Knowing I was innocent kept me going. Perhaps Michael and Randolph didn't have that. They already had long sentences to serve for the other crimes."

Rowe was convicted chiefly on the evidence of a lover, Kate Williamson, and a man, Norman Duncan, who was living in a hostel in Sydenham, south London, with Rowe.

Williamson had spent the evening of December 15 with Rowe, Davis, and a group of friends. There were witnesses to say they were in the house from late afternoon, went out to collect videos, and returned at 12.30am.

The prosecution relied on these times being wrong. Williamson claimed Rowe left the house and returned hours later with jewellery.

Rowe says she "told a pack of lies", probably because she was jealous of his girlfriend, Nancy Stanley.

"We watched videos in bed, made love, had a smoke (of marijuana), and then fell asleep. I did get up in the night, but only to go down to Michael's room to get some more dope. Kate was out for the count."

Williamson wrote to Rowe admitting she lied, but later claimed she was coerced into doing it. "You can't believe both of us. Our stories hit head on.

"I don't know what she is doing now, whether she got married, had kids. She disappeared into the shadows after the trial. Perhaps one day she will tell me the truth. Up until our release I hated her for what she did to me."

Now Rowe's anger is focused on Duncan. During the trial, he claimed Rowe asked him to steal a Spitfire car used in the first robbery, and overheard him plotting the raids.

Rowe and his lawyers did not know Duncan was a criminal with numerous convictions who had turned police informer.

And they did not know Duncan spent two days in the rape suite at Reigate police station being informally interviewed about the M25 crimes, and that he had not initially mentioned Johnson as a suspect.

Duncan was keen to talk about rewards. He was paid £10,300 from the Daily Mail which had launched an appeal for information.

Surrey police did not disclose this at the trial - the law did not require them to, and in 1988 there were no procedures for informing the judge.

When Duncan gave evidence, he lied about his collusion with officers. The court of appeal described this as "profoundly disturbing". "It amounts to no less than a conspiracy to give perjured evidence ... it must dent the credibility both of Duncan and the police."

Duncan, who is white, stole the Spitfire. Rowe believes he was involved in the M25 robberies and concocted a story to get himself off the hook. "The police did not fit me up, as much as fit me in.

"When we found out about Duncan, everything started to make sense. The police conspired with Duncan and I now suspect they conspired with Kate Williamson. The only people who had nothing to gain from all this were the victims, who went through an horrific ordeal. They said two of the robbers were white. Why weren't they heard?"

Rowe says he will keep protesting his innocence and will seek compensation for the lost years. He does not have a career to fall back on. He has a son, aged 12, he has never seen.

"He doesn't want to know me because he thinks I am a murderer. That breaks my heart. I have been keeping a diary for the last 12 years. I was writing for him. I hope he will read the diary and realise I'm not the man he thinks I am.

"I'm still working off my anger about what's happened, but it's the final chapter. When this is over, I don't know what I am going to do with my life."

Surrey police say they are bemused by the criticism in the judgment, and will be seeking clarification. "The investigating officers were forced to keep the existence and the identity of the informant secret to protect his life. The law and procedure in place at the time was inadequate to deal with this situation."

fields.headline: Illegal sect keeps needling Beijing
fields.trailText: In a contest that seems stranger than fiction, followers of the Falun Gong sect persisted in defying the Chinese government on the eve of today's anniversary of the ban on the movement.
fields.body:
In a contest that seems stranger than fiction, followers of the Falun Gong sect persisted in defying the Chinese government on the eve of today's anniversary of the ban on the movement.

Sect members appeared in Tiananmen Square yesterday for the fourth day this week, unfurling banners and trying to practise ritual meditation in spite of a strong police presence.

The mostly middle-aged followers, some of whom called out "Falun Gong is good", were shoved into police vans and driven away, while a few onlookers expressed sympathy for them.

Chinese officials claimed to have won "a major victory" but admitted in the same breath that the drive to eradicate the movement remains "a long-term and complex struggle".

The full weight of the state and Communist party apparatus has been brought to bear on the loosely organised movement of ordinary citizens, who are mostly inarticulate and have no apparent political aim.

Beijing's propaganda continues to train its heavy guns on the shadowy figure of the group's founder, Li Hongzhi, who issues largely incoherent messages on the internet from his refuge in the US; Mr Li now claims that ban issued on July 22 last year was predicted by the 16th-century French astrologer Nostradamus.

Mr Li, who is not known for modesty, recently wrote a poem titled "The knowing heart" to rally the spirits of his followers, part of which read: "With teacher [Mr Li] at the helm,the Fa [Law] saves all beings; one sail is hoisted, 100 million sails follow."

The poem ended by predicting a "day of consummation" when Mr Li would reveal a great truth which "will leave the world in amazement".

Falun Gong followers claim that thousands of them have been rounded up in the past year, imprisoned, and forced to pay fines if they refuse to recant. Up to 25 are alleged to have died in custody - a charge denied by Beijing.

"This is a living hell," guards told a supporter in a detention centre in Shandong province, according to the movement's website. "Nobody would care if we beat you to death."

Beijing says that Mr Li forbids his followers from seeking medical help, leading to nearly 1,400 deaths. It has published the last testament of a Communist party member won over by the sect, who repented and denounced Mr Li as he lay dying of cancer.

The allegations of both sides are impossible to verify, but police tactics against the demonstrators have been on display in Tiananmen Square this week: they have ranged from quiet persuasion to brute force, with some demonstrators kicked and punched or dragged along the ground.

There appears to be a growing sense of frustration that the sect refuses to go away.

Many Chinese regard the sect and Mr Li with scepticism, but believe they are harmless. There is a widespread belief that it might have been ignored if it had not staged a mass protest in Beijing in April last year outside the compound where senior leaders work.

Mr Li takes a different view, arguing that "what is currently unfolding in China was previously arranged".

webTitle: Give me Banger, Vorders and two turquoise minis and watch the punters roll in

fields.headline: Give me Banger, Vorders and two turquoise minis and watch the punters roll in
fields.trailText: There's a bush telegraph in the game they call cricket, and when news filtered through from the last A tour of Bangladesh about young Banger Trescothick we all got very excited - the powers that be had found what they'd been looking for since the 1980s.
fields.body:
There's a bush telegraph in the game they call cricket, and when news filtered through from the last A tour of Bangladesh about young Banger Trescothick we all got very excited - the powers that be had found what they'd been looking for since the 1980s.

Anyone who saw Marcus's Scary Spice impersonation knew instantly that England had unearthed a Christmas party performer to rank with the greats like Chris Tavare and Neil Foster. The young left-hander kept his wig on for several hours in blistering heat, which shows he's got the appetite for the job, and Duncan Fletcher's been banging his drum ever since.

Of course, he's not quite the newcomer the media have portrayed. Banger's been involved with the England set-up from under-14 level (where he showed amazing maturity as Tina Turner in a Saturday night get-together at Lilleshall). He had a couple of years in the doldrums recently and perhaps put on a bit too much weight. And it's only natural that if a guy can't get into his frock, well, it's going to affect his form out in the middle.

But now he's back to his best and, as far as Pod's concerned, the lad's ready to take the big step up. If the selectors are searching for someone to provide the very best in interval entertainment for the ODIs, they need look no further than the Keynsham southpaw.

Obviously I'm disappointed with the phasing-out of my own pilot scheme - Two Giant Transparent Balls Rolling Slowly Across The Outfield - especially as I'm not going to be able to get them back in the garage, even when they're deflated. But I accept that the game's got to go forward and if we didn't move with the times we'd all be living in caves with animal skins on our backs (a concept which we also experimented with once at Headingley).

On balance, you have to say that the triangular tournament has been a roaring success and has helped take everybody's minds off the seemingly endless test series against West Indies. Anyone who thinks that the two dozen one-dayers are in some way completely pointless needs only look at the constantly fluctuating Psychological Advantage Table. This currently shows Zimbabwe just shading it at plus 17, with England 14.35 and the Windies trailing at minus 0.26. But that could all be blown apart today.

Plus, rather like the moon landing, this NatWest series has brought all kinds of technological advances. It's hard to imagine now what life was like before the helmet-cam. It gave us that fantastic, just-like-being-there view of the drinks tray being carried out by the Zimboks' 12th man - though for Dave Podmore the most exciting moments were those early images of the pavilion steps at Edgbaston as Hicky went out to bat. And the equally arresting shot of the pavilion steps 30 seconds later as he came back in again.

It can only be a matter of time before a helmet-cam is hanging on every peg in the England dressing room, though I understand there are a few glitches still to be ironed out with the Flintoff-cam: try as they might, the boffins can't seem to get an unobscured picture of the ground in front of Freddie's feet.

It's all about presentation. Like Pod always says, cricket has to be pro-active if it's to succeed as a business. You can bat and bowl all day but, if it doesn't bring the punters in, where are you? Look at Hampshire: can't make a run in the championship yet they sign Shane Warne and the membership's up by 25%. Ditto Notts and Shoaib Akhtar. We've got 6,000 new season-ticket holders at Trent Bridge this year and the Rawalpindi Express has never even turned his arm over, or up and across in his case.

The public like to see star names and, mark my words, the first county to snap up Harry Potter or Carol Vorderman to bat at No3 will have made a very shrewd investment indeed. Vorders is no mug with the bat, by the way - she certainly gave me some serious slap in a Taverners match at Ropley the other week. As well as running across to the scoreboard every five minutes to correct their adding up.

She's even helped arrange a loan for me. The APR's a stiffish old ask but the cash is immediate, that's the thing. There's nothing that girl can't do - except maybe carry off a turquoise mini-dress as well as Banger Trescothick.

Finally, a last word on the vexed question of the England captaincy. In Pod's opinion it was only right that Nass should take over at the helm again as soon as possible - even though he was only 100% fit at most - rather than let Alec Stewart lead the lads for the remainder of the one-dayers. It means Stewie can concentrate on his batting and wicketkeeping duties. And now that he's expressed an interest in tackling street crime in the capital, he'll have yet another string to his bow.

fields.headline: Mad cow
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: My Mother has just phoned in a panic, gabbling about CJD. She is convinced that she is to be the next victim in the cluster of unfortunates to have contracted the deadly disease
fields.body:
Thursday, July 13, Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire

My Mother has just phoned in a panic, gabbling about CJD. She was once driven through the village of Queniborough on the way to a garden centre in Quorn and is now convinced that she is to be the next victim in the cluster of unfortunates to have contracted the deadly disease. She has become a hypochondriac since Ivan Braithwaite moved into our house with his mania for sterilising the chopping boards and sprinkling Dettol on the new dog's bedding.

I tried to calm her fears but she was near to hysteria and begged me to forgive her. "For what," I enquired, wondering which of her parental crimes I should forgive her for. "The cheap beefburgers I used to serve up, three times a week," she said. "I didn't know they were made of bits of old spinal chord and sawdust, Aidy."

I reassured her that the beefburgers of my childhood were so utterly disgusting that I used to surreptitiously feed the dog with them. It would take its place under the table whenever it saw my mother drag a box of the vile things out of the freezer. Personally, I'm waiting for the boil-in-the-bag cod-in-butter-sauce food scare. I must have consumed a shoal of the fish. Then there's the frozen beef TV dinners for one, which we used to consume on Sundays. That tinfoil couldn't have done us much good, either. "It's 100% organic food for me from now on," said my mother.

"But you don't know what to do with real food," I reminded her. She replied, "I've got Delia and Nigel and Jamie to help me," as though her ill-equipped kitchen was full of celebrity chefs jostling for space.

Friday, July 14

Mrs Wormington has gone to Mablethorpe with the Ludlows. They have got an eight-berth caravan in a field near to the sea. They asked if they could take William with them but I had to say no. He is an impressionable lad and easily picks up on the Ludlows' verbal infelicities. Yesterday he came back from playing at their house, and when I told him it was time for bed, he said, in a Louisiana accent while showing me his left palm. "Tell it to the hand, cos the face ain't listening. Leave a message after the bleep." Peggy Ludlow said that the Jerry Springer Show had been on while William had been playing on the rug with Vince Ludlow's socket set.

Saturday, July 15

I watched the Inside Downing Street documentary tonight. What a fine figure of a man he is. He is masterful, charming, clever and has a good head of hair. He is altogether impressive. Mr Blair, on the other hand, seemed lacklustre by comparison. He has been transformed since Leo insisted on sharing the marital bed and Euan started hitting the bottle. In fact, Tony has undergone a feminisation: his hair has turned fluffy, his voice has softened, his expression is girly, his hands move as gracefully as a geisha's. Is he on a course of hormones that will eventually transmogrify him into Toni - the first woman Labour Prime Minister? The country should be warned. We will need time to adjust to the change.

William Hague, on the other hand, is awash with testosterone lately. He'll be starting a parliamentary chapter of the Hell's Angels next if he doesn't watch his hormone levels. Does Ffion welcome this new thrusting Mussolini-like man in her bed, or is she already sleeping in the spare room, like Prince Edward's wife?

The Ludlows have returned home with hypothermia after walking along the promenade at Mablethorpe. Mrs Wormington has been taken to hospital in Skegness. She has been wrapped in a silver space blanket.

When Auntie Susan rang my mobile and asked angrily why I'd not turned up at the prison library as promised, I replied truthfully that I was anticipating a tragic bereavement.

webTitle: Film fashions that hit the mark

fields.headline: Return of the mac
fields.standfirst: Shaft is back with a new wardrobe. Damn right! But do you dig it? Will Armani's new black leather jacket measure up to the classic 70s brown trenchcoat? Angela Buttolph reports on those film fashions that hit the mark
fields.trailText: Shaft is back with a new wardrobe. Damn right! But do you dig it? Will Armani's new black leather jacket measure up to the classic 70s brown trenchcoat? Angela Buttolph reports on those film fashions that hit the mark
fields.body:
Detective John Shaft was not only the star of cinema's first African-American mainstream success, but also its first super-bad style icon. Back in 1971, he triggered a major fashion moment that saw grown men strutting pigeon-like down the street in loverman Afros, sharp flares and loud overcoats, with that soundtrack playing in their heads. And when Isaac Hayes asked "Who is the man...?" every last one of them thought he knew the answer.

"Shaft appealed to everyone - every man wanted to be the sex machine for all the chicks," says costume designer Ruth Carter, the woman charged with doing the impossible: trying to update and up the ante on the coolest contemporary screen dude for the return of Shaft, starring Samuel L Jackson as Richard Roundtree's nephew.

The original Shaft was right on the money style-wise. Back then, men's fashion was still pretty conservative, until Shaft arrived looking sharp as a knife. But will he strike the right note 30 years on? "Shaft 2000 is about dressing up and looking good," says Carter, so out go the flares, gargantuan lapels and long collars, and in come cashmere turtlenecks and sumptuous simplicity. And that all-important coat.

"The first Shaft was all about the coat," explains Carter, referring to Roundtree's long, brown, belted, leather jacket, which was made by the director Gordon Parks's tailor, and spawned a host of imitators. This time, it is a black leather number by Giorgio Armani - very long, very simple, very streamlined.

Lucky old Giorgio. There are worse models to hang your designs on than the velvety Samuel L-J. But will our strapping hero have the same fashion clout in 2000 as he did in 1971? So far, the jury is out. "It's a great coat," admits Hal Rubenstein, of America's celebrity fashion bible InStyle, "but we saw the longer-length leather coat in The Matrix last year, and it didn't catch on. You can't run for a bus in a coat that length. In the end, pragmatism will always win out."

And there's the rub: we may admire a snappy dresser with an original look, but we are only going to copy them if it is practical. "You could believe in Shaft," says Carter. "That's what was hot - the fact that he was a 'real' person made all the difference, that's what made people want to buy into it."

Which presumably is why Gladiator, while an enormous box-office smash, will never inspire a great fashion following, despite shoe designer Cole Haan's rather feeble attempt to get in on the act by advertising Roman sandals. Let's face it, if Gladiator starts any trends at all, it'll be in the stripogram industry.

Some looks, however, are instant hits. In the 70s, it was Annie Hall. In the mid 90s, every girl was doing the Pulp Fiction look, wearing Uma Thurman's white, fitted Agnes b shirt and black bootcut trousers. And Demi Moore's black strappy Thierry Mugler evening dress from Indecent Proposal was so simple and sexy that it is still being copied now.

Of course, some trends are just easier to follow than others. Audrey Hepburn's wide blonde streaks were de rigueur for 60s chicks after Breakfast At Tiffany's (and again after Mrs Robinson in The Graduate). And which lad didn't shave his head after Trainspotting? Anything that's quick and easy to do is likely to take off: Uma's Chanel Vamp nail varnish in Pulp Fiction set off a fashion frenzy, as did Alicia Silverstone's pale blue Hard Candy polish after she wore it in Clueless (although the trend lasted about as long as the lingo).

Sunglasses are another common cinema-inspired craze. Tom Cruise's Ray-ban Wayfarers from Risky Business and Aviators from Top Gun were sooo popular in the 80s, as were Elvis shades after True Romance.

The basic rule is that only realistic, contemporary, wearable looks catch on from movies. Take the 50s-fest The Talented Mr Ripley, which has only inspired everyone to go to Rome on holiday: we loved the film, we loved the look, but no one sane wants to wear something so retro it's virtually period costume (only mad old ladies and rockabillies are doing the 50s look right now).

However, try telling that to staff at J Peterman, a chain of stores in the States specialising in frankly hilarious "reproduction vintage apparel inspired by the movies". They do ranges from Titanic, The Avengers and LA Confidential. Surely they haven't really caught on?

"Someone came in and spent $8,000 buying all of [Titanic heroine] Rose's outfits - dresses, hats, shoes everything - for an Easter Sunday outfit," reports a relentlessly cheerful sales assistant at the Grand Central Station store. But isn't the Titanic look, rather, um, dated?

"You'd be surprised. It's a very timeless look, it's not faddish, it's not trendy-trendy." It certainly isn't. Yet not even the movie's more downbeat storylines can deter Maison Peterman.

"You know when Rose is having lunch and her fiance slaps her face and turns over the table?" continues the assistant excitedly. "We've got that dress! It's cream with a gold collar and rhinestone embroidery." And there's more: the dress that Rose wears while considering whether to commit suicide by throwing herself overboard has been lovingly reproduced as "an ideal wedding dress".

J Peterman not only breaks all laws of taste, decency and credulity, it pretty much breaks all the rules in the handbook of flogging film-inspired fashion. The store is a roaring success.

"You can never predict which fashions are going to catch on after films," says Bloomingdale's fashion director Kal Ruttenstein, and he should know. As far back as 1967, the store created one of its first in-store boutiques for Bonnie & Clyde fashions: berets, long skirts, elongated jumpers. Customers were fighting in the aisles (albeit not with machine guns).

Promotions followed, with varying success, for Chariots Of Fire (boater hats, red striped ties and blazers, and white summer clothes), Les Liaisons Dangereuses (lingerie with Malkovich-style frilly shirts as ladies' nightgowns) and Evita. Studios now approach the store to do fashion tie-ins.

It helps, of course, if the star is pushing the look off-screen. When Madonna was in Evita she took to wearing 40s-style Prada suits off-duty. This begs the question which comes first, the film or the trend? "Usually it's the film," says Ruth Carter, "but by the time the film is released two years later, the fashion designers have picked up on it."

The Evita boutique was a huge success, but there is really no guessing what will sell. Six hundred yellow trenchcoats flew out of the store after Warren Beatty's starring role in Dick Tracy.

So is Shaft 2000 heading for a fashion moment? Will it be wall-to-wall streamlined leather overcoats on the streets of London and Manhattan this autumn? So far it's looking pretty good, but the difference is that the 1971 Shaft look was fresh. The latest look is not particularly directional - we've seen turtlenecks and leather jackets before, after all. "Sam looks terrific," says Hal Rubenstein, "but the clothes just aren't that revolutionary."

This time, though, Shaft is packing a powerful new weapon - all that Armani hype. The Shaft theme tune played at Giorgio's January menswear show, and he invited Samuel L Jackson up onto the catwalk, simpering "you provide the attitude, I'll provide the wardrobe".

Will the old film and fashion alchemy work again? Shaft's badass jacket has already hit Armani's US stores. The cost is a cool $3,500. The only question now, as Isaac Hayes might have put it, is can you dig it?

 Shaft (1971) is out now; Shaft (2000) is out on September 8

fields.headline: You're so vain
fields.standfirst: John Patterson on how Hollywood's sweetener deals are turning sour
fields.trailText: John Patterson on how Hollywood's sweetener deals are turning sour
fields.body:
It is house-cleaning time in Tinseltown, and all that kicking and screaming you hear is the sound of pampered stars being rudely ejected from their comfy, all-expenses-paid digs on the studio lots. The Hollywood suits are tightening their belts and digging in their heels. The day of the vanity production deal may be over.

Perhaps the best way to explain the term "vanity deal" is to list a few movies that derive from these sweetheart arrangements between studios and stars. A pattern will emerge, just you wait and see: The Scarlet Letter, Breakfast Of Champions, Crazy In Alabama, The Postman, any recent Barbra Streisand movie you might care to mention, Battlefield Earth, That Thing You Do, I Dreamed Of Africa, Little Man Tate and Nell, The Deep End Of The Ocean and Cop Land. Those names might make you think that vanity deal is a synonym for "shit movie", and on the available evidence, that's not far from the truth, but usually it means the star is either producing or directing, and is only being permitted to do so because the studio wants to keep them sweet for the next real movie they want to make with them.

A vanity deal is often a reward for egocentric actors with ideas above their station and IQs smaller than their waistlines who've racked up a couple of sizeable hits. The perks are straightforward enough. The studio will give you a certain amount of money to establish your own production company in offices. Your staff of assistants, manicurists, personal chefs, leg-waxers, brothers-in-law, script readers and such members of your retinue that you choose to employ will base themselves here and essentially be paid by the studio. Your benefactor will probably also cough up development funds and money for script acquisitions. The purpose is to make stars feel in charge of the creative side of the production.

The early days are exhilarating enough: choosing the wallpaper, the office furniture, the couches, the carpets and so on ("send the bill to Fox/Sony/Paramount/Universal"). Then things get uglier, mainly because the movie has to be made (well, it doesn't, as we shall see, but let's assume the star is actually interested in getting it made). All too often the actor, having finally achieved the control he or she has been craving since their first kindergarten Nativity play, finds out what producing really involves, how many people you have to scream and shout at, how little the studio really cares about your Mickey-Mouse, rinky-dink personal movie, and starts to yearn for the security of those zillion-dollar action movies that made them rich and which as creative artists they affect to despise.

Which brings us neatly back to that list of movies. This is the stuff the overindulged stars really wanted to get involved with. Often they approved the writer, sought out the director - malleable yes-men are preferred - and had a hand in the casting. The result of giving actors their heads is plain to see. Over here we have the wan, animal-loving antics of Ms Kim Basinger, cuddling lions and making like Joy Adamson redux as the slick, blonde mistress of an African farm in the slack, bland I Dreamed Of Africa. I bet she never dreamed it would vanish from the nation's screens in a fortnight.

Over there we can spy the wreckage of Demi Moore's The Scarlet Letter (to say nothing of Nathaniel Hawthorne fighting his way out of his grave to get his hands on Demi) and the almost simultaneously released Striptease. Both of these were worked up by Demi's own production company and apparently owed their existence to Moore's desire to showcase her recent breast-augmentation. The Scarlet Letter, to which critics awarded a scarlet D-minus, contained an unarousing bathtub sex scene not found in the novel. The critical response to Striptease was "put 'em away, love". There is a school of thought that says Demi Moore's entire career is little more than one of Bruce Willis's many vanity projects. Universal has since cancelled its deal with Moore's Moving Pictures Company, most likely because of Moore's vertiginous loss of marque-value.

Chances are, if the star also directed, it's a vanity project. Here one can cite the directorial oeuvre of Jodie Foster - Little Man Tate, Home For The Holidays - which would very likely not have come into being without the success of The Silence Of The Lambs. Without Clarice Starling there would be no Egg Pictures, the chintzy new-age name of Jodie's production company. Actors often do a little direction as a vacation from huge studio pictures, and some fare OK. That Thing You Do was modest and sweet enough, Robert De Niro's A Bronx Tale was rather good, and Costner's saccharine Dances With Wolves made money, won Oscars and kept audiences happy. Hanks and De Niro have backed off, apparently satisfied that they've proved something to themselves, but Costner, as we know, wasn't happy with just one shot. Having won the Best Director Academy Award for Wolves (against Scorsese for GoodFellas, a sick joke), he had to come back for more. The result, The Postman, is a vanity project writ so large that a million men with brooms were required to sweep up the debris. Kevin directed, starred in and even sang over the final credits with Jennifer Warnes. The result was box-office poison and it and Costner quickly descended to the level of national laughing-stock.

Now Tinseltown has had enough. A backlash against sweeteners for stars has been building up ever since 1995, when Columbia/TriStar chairman Mark Canton gave the 18-year-old Alicia Silverstone and her First Kiss production company a $10 million development deal after the success of Clueless. After two years Silverstone had managed, with great difficulty, to get only one movie into cinema, the critically savaged commercial flop Excess Baggage, whose title well describes the way the studios now perceive these deals. Silverstone found out her number was up when Columbia left her name off a list of production deals submitted to Variety. At around the same time, others were being cancelled, including Elle McPherson's office at Miramax, where she was prepping some witless documentary about women's lingerie called Bend Me, Shape Me, and Jason Alexander, who had been developing a white supremacist project for 20th Century Fox.

In the new penny-pinching studios, they're off-loading everyone but the most dependable money earners. And access to the studio trough will be regulated even for the biggest players, as Sean Penn discovered when he tried to commandeer a Fox jet for The Thin Red Line promo tour (that movie, incidentally, was some producer's prestige vanity project). Last year Warner Bros closed down development deals it was backing with Tim Burton and Matthew McConaughey, and only retained proven warhorses such as Robin Williams and Sean Connery who, in the words of one studio head "always pretty much get what they want anyway".

Behind the changes one can detect one of Hollywood's occasional periods of austerity, caused by the cost of making and marketing movies and lower profit margins. The last problem has mainly been caused by the insatiable demands of overpaid movie stars, whose salaries have been hyper-inflated for a decade now. It's pleasingly ironic that when the cutbacks arrive they should fall heavily on stars' hobby projects.

Other big names on the way out are Melanie Griffith and Antonio Banderas, who came a cropper when Crazy In Alabama headed straight for the box-office toilet on its opening weekend. Griffith's company, Green Moon, had been bankrolled for five years by Warners. Result: one $10 million flop that took barely $600,000. Griffith and Banderas - who directed, more vanity! - were asked to vacate their offices.

Michelle Pfeiffer also moved on after the failure of her movie The Deep End Of The Ocean, which had taken four years to put together, proved the actress lacked the golden touch her husband David E Kelley has shown on TV. "She walked away before she was chased off the lot," said one Sony executive.

Sylvester Stallone has also lost his CopLand Ventures, the last remnant of his desire to be taken seriously, and even Madonna has been denied the chance to re-up at Warners. An office that she has had on the lot since 1990 has just been shut down. "It was a tidying-up exercise," said one executive. "Her acting career seems to have reached an impasse. Hers may have been the last of the old-fashioned vanity deals. I can't see our shareholders allowing us to sign such deals again."

You don't hear me moaning.

Over here we have the wan, animal-loving antics of Ms Kim Basinger, cuddling lions and making like Joy Adamson redux as the slick, blonde mistress of an African farm in the slack, bland I Dreamed Of Africa. I bet she never dreamed it would vanish from the nation's screens in a fortnight. Over there we can spy the wreckage of Demi Moore's The Scarlet Letter (to say nothing of Nathaniel Hawthorne fighting his way out of his grave to get his hands on Demi) and the almost simultaneously released Striptease. Both of these were worked up by Demi's own production company and apparently owed their existence to Moore's desire to showcase her recent breast-augmentation. The Scarlet Letter, to which critics awarded a scarlet D-minus, contained an unarousing bathtub sex scene not found in the novel. The critical response to Striptease was "put 'em away, love". There is a school of thought that says Demi Moore's entire career is little more than one of Bruce Willis's many vanity projects. Universal has since cancelled its deal with Moore's Moving Pictures Company, most likely because of Moore's vertiginous loss of marque-value. Chances are, if the star also directed, it's a vanity project. Here one can cite the directorial oeuvre of Jodie Foster - Little Man Tate, Home For The Holidays - which would very likely not have come into being without the success of The Silence Of The Lambs. Without Clarice Starling there would be no Egg Pictures, the chintzy new-age name of Jodie's production company. Actors often do a little direction as a vacation from huge studio pictures, and some fare OK. That Thing You Do was modest and sweet enough, Robert De Niro's A Bronx Tale was rather good, and Costner's saccharine Dances With Wolves made money, won Oscars and kept audiences happy. Hanks and De Niro have backed off, apparently satisfied that they've proved something to themselves, but Costner, as we know, wasn't happy with just one shot. Having won the Best Director Academy Award for Wolves (against Scorsese for GoodFellas, a sick joke), he had to come back for more. The result, The Postman, is a vanity project writ so large that a million men with brooms were required to sweep up the debris. Kevin directed, starred in and even sang over the final credits with Jennifer Warnes. The result was box-office poison and it and Costner quickly descended to the level of national laughing-stock. Now Tinseltown has had enough. A backlash against sweeteners for stars has been building up ever since 1995, when Columbia/TriStar chairman Mark Canton gave the 18-year-old Alicia Silverstone and her First Kiss production company a $10 million development deal after the success of Clueless. After two years Silverstone had managed, with great difficulty, to get only one movie into cinema, the critically savaged commercial flop Excess Baggage, whose title well describes the way the studios now perceive these deals. Silverstone found out her number was up when Columbia left her name off a list of production deals submitted to Variety. At around the same time, others were being cancelled, including Elle McPherson's office at Miramax, where she was prepping some witless documentary about women's lingerie called Bend Me, Shape Me, and Jason Alexander, who had been developing a white supremacist project for 20th Century Fox. In the new penny-pinching studios, they're off-loading everyone but the most dependable money earners. And access to the studio trough will be regulated even for the biggest players, as Sean Penn discovered when he tried to commandeer a Fox jet for The Thin Red Line promo tour (that movie, incidentally, was some producer's prestige vanity project). Last year Warner Bros closed down development deals it was backing with Tim Burton and Matthew McConaughey, and only retained proven warhorses such as Robin Williams and Sean Connery who, in the words of one studio head "always pretty much get what they want anyway". Behind the changes one can detect one of Hollywood's occasional periods of austerity, caused by the cost of making and marketing movies and lower profit margins. The last problem has mainly been caused by the insatiable demands of overpaid movie stars, whose salaries have been hyper-inflated for a decade now. It's pleasingly ironic that when the cutbacks arrive they should fall heavily on stars' hobby projects. Other big names on the way out are Melanie Griffith and Antonio Banderas, who came a cropper when Crazy In Alabama headed straight for the box-office toilet on its opening weekend. Griffith's company, Green Moon, had been bankrolled for five years by Warners. Result: one $10 million flop that took barely $600,000. Griffith and Banderas - who directed, more vanity! - were asked to vacate their offices. Michelle Pfeiffer also moved on after the failure of her movie The Deep End Of The Ocean, which had taken four years to put together, proved the actress lacked the golden touch her husband David E Kelley has shown on TV. "She walked away before she was chased off the lot," said one Sony executive. Sylvester Stallone has also lost his CopLand Ventures, the last remnant of his desire to be taken seriously, and even Madonna has been denied the chance to re-up at Warners. An office that she has had on the lot since 1990 has just been shut down. "It was a tidying-up exercise," said one executive. "Her acting career seems to have reached an impasse. Hers may have been the last of the old-fashioned vanity deals. I can't see our shareholders allowing us to sign such deals again." You don't hear me moaning.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText:
Guardian readers need no introduction to Lawrence Donegan and his nifty talent for instant autobiography
Hear an audio clip
fields.body:
No News At Throat Lake
Lawrence Donegan (Penguin, £8.99, 165mn)
Hear a clip

Guardian readers need no introduction to this author and his nifty talent for instant autobiography. Donegan left this newspaper and migrated to Donegal in search of the remote idyll. The abridged audio omits his abortive bash at farming and cuts to his work on the Tirconaill Tribune, an eccentric, campaigning local newspaper. He meets Newt Gingrich and Meryl Streep, takes part in a wake and sees the appalling living conditions of some Irish travellers. But the biggest shock is the storm of Irish outrage at his irreverent doggerel on the first anniversary of Princess Diana's death. Alan Cumming has a spry but sensitive delivery.

webTitle: Is sporting success essential to national self-esteem?

fields.headline: Is sporting success essential to national self-esteem?
fields.standfirst: For UK Sport chiarman Rodney Walker, sporting success provides a measure of a country's competitiveness in the world and an essential sense of belonging to the players. But novelist Tim Pears believes that the point of sport is not to dominate or win, and is not sure he wants a "national self-esteem" at all. Have your say here.
fields.trailText: For UK Sport chiarman Rodney Walker, sporting success provides a measure of a country's competitiveness in the world and an essential sense of belonging to the players. But novelist Tim Pears believes that the point of sport is not to dominate or win, and is not sure he wants a "national self-esteem" at all. Have your say here.
fields.body:
Dear Mr Pears
Have you been enjoying the summer of sport? On the credit side, sports fans have enjoyed the unexpected European Cup success of the British men's athletics team, the growing prowess of our women's modern pentathlon squad, and the enduring excellence of Lennox Lewis. On the debit side, our swimmers obtained only a modest medal haul at the European Championships, the England football team made a less-than-glorious exit from Euro 2000, and Britain has been relegated from the World Group of the Davis Cup. The England men's cricket team, meanwhile, have managed to cram Himalayan highs and subterranean lows into the space of just a few days. Does any of this matter? I am certainly not among those who believe that sport is more important than life and death. But it would be short-sighted to underestimate the part sport plays in the overall scheme of things. To borrow from CLR James, a sporting event does not reflect the age. It is the age. In a fast-changing world, sport is arguably our most potent expression of local, regional and national identity. It holds up a unique mirror for societies seeking to understand who they are and what they are; it provides a measure of a country's competitiveness and its capacity to succeed. The government wants to demonstrate that the UK is a thriving, dynamic country that can engage with the world and promote itself with confidence. Winning medals in major sports events is a high-profile way of illustrating this. That's one reason sport is climbing up the political agenda. Yours sincerely,
Sir Rodney Walker
Chairman, UK Sport

Dear Sir Rodney

Let's be honest, once England departed Euro 2000, this country (and every other one) breathed a huge sigh of relief and settled back to enjoy that festival of beautiful football. As for Wimbledon, we English seem to be divided between those who, upon watching Tim Henman make his thin-lipped and doomed assault on Centre Court, feel their hearts pump faster, and those who cringe.

The trouble with seeking national self-esteem through sporting success is twofold. First, it involves dominating other people and using sport as a metaphor for war, as opposed to treating sport like an exhilarating dance, in which, with our opponents, we create something beautiful. Second, and this is our own particular Anglo-Brit problem, there is the legacy of our imperial past. We seem to find it impossible to accept who we are and to take a relaxed place among the middle-sized nations of the world. So it's hard to wear our national self-esteem, our patriotism, in the way it should be worn - as a mask for a carnival, a persona for a party.

I and the people I mix with do not wish to derive our self-esteem from national sporting success. I don't think we even want national self-esteem. We don't want to be proud to be British. Or English. Or male or female, black or white, short or tall. No, nor ashamed, either. But relaxed and comfortable with who we are, and with each other. All sorts of people play sport all around us: young and old, graceful and hopeless. But not enough people. Let's forget national sporting success. Let's just get out there and play.

Yours sincerely,
Tim Pears

Dear Tim

I am sorry and a little saddened that you find it difficult to take pride in the various manifestations of your identity. A sense of belonging is, after all, one of humanity's most basic needs.

Actually, I feel most sorry for our sportsmen and women themselves; they deserve a lot better. These days some stand to earn considerable wealth from their sport, but that doesn't mean they don't have to sacrifice a great deal to get to the top. And getting to the top means competing against the best in the world, usually by representing one's country. If sporting talent has to express itself this way, then so be it; let's not deny talented athletes our support, for they are national assets as precious as talented artists, musicians, designers and architects.

I am surprised, too, that you fail to see the connection between national sporting success and the impulse to "get out there and play". Of course, I accept that the behaviour which accompanies certain major sports events can be ugly. But as you yourself hint, the dividing line between carnage and carnival is remarkably thin. Sport has a unique ability to bring nations and peoples together. It is an ability worth fighting for - even when the going gets tough.

Yours sincerely,
Sir Rodney Walker

Dear Sir Rodney

You're right, the line between carnage and carnival is thin - as illustrated by the fact that we are debating in a week when one programme devoted to football on terrestrial TV was a celebration of the beautiful game's dirty bastards, as George Best called them.

George Orwell wrote that "serious sport has nothing to do with fair play. It is bound up with hatred, jealousy, boastfulness and disregard of all the rules." One has to admit he had a point. The custodians of football did their best to eliminate violent play in Euro 2000, but cheating became ever more prevalent.

To return to the original question, what do we mean by sporting success? We live in an age when success for the few is the aspiration, and is rewarded with vast wealth. But the real success in sport comes when people play it. I thought the recent fad for books about being a football supporter was really odd - I spent my weekends playing on council pitches in various parts of this country and, to borrow from Albert Camus, learned all I know of life there.

Unserious sport is bound up with vitality, togetherness, joy. The trouble is that the more national triumph we have, the more we'll sit back and watch it on Sky with our couch-potato children. Meanwhile, school playing fields will continue to be sold off.

Yours sincerely,
Tim Pears

Dear Tim

We may sometimes struggle to get our message across - but most people would associate the sports councils with the concept of "sport for all". Nothing is dearer to us than getting people to play, and seeing them remain involved for the rest of their lives.

But winning is unavoidably a part of sport. Take away the winning and the whole structure of sport falls apart. Indeed, if people play without, ultimately, trying to win, then it could be argued they are participating in an activity which is not, in fact, sport at all. True, the dirty bastards sometimes win, but the good guys don't always lose. Can't we use sport to teach ourselves - especially our children - how to win in the right way and how to lose in the right way?

Football is our highest-profile sport, and we all tend to use it as a template for the state of sport in toto. But it is not the only sport, and what happens in the football world is not a model that is slavishly followed by athletes, coaches and managers in other sports. Track and field athletes, swimmers, rowers and cyclists may all overstep the mark from time to time, but I believe those and other sports can still exhibit friendship, camaraderie and the spirit of shared experience - even in a fiercely competitive environment.

I have no doubt the Sydney Olympics will throw up its fair share of controversy. But I am equally sure they will move us and humble us as well.

Yours sincerely
Sir Rodney Walker

Dear Sir Rodney,

Now you're talking! Yes, let's use sport to teach ourselves how to win in the right way and how to lose in the right way. We need to say: "Of course we try to win, we commit our every nerve and sinew to winning." Yet we also need to know that it doesn't matter whether we win or lose, that the purpose of competition is not to beat an opponent, but for opponents to fulfil each other's highest potential, as they create together an event of beauty.

You quite rightly mention games other than football, and let's take this much wider still: you and I love sport, Sir Rodney, but we also know how many children (especially girls) are put off sport at school by the nature of competitive games. I'm convinced that everyone could experience the joy that sport can give, if they were given access to enough variety to choose from.

I say, let the children practise yoga in the hall and aerobics in the gym. Let there be table tennis in the classroom and dancing on the desk tops. Give our sons and daughters Ordnance Survey maps so that they may ramble our footpaths, the veins and arteries of this island. Let's wander these green hills, run the wild coastal paths, and stride across our liberated moorlands.

Let's rollerblade all this dead concrete back to some kind of life, and climb to the tops of the trees that are left in Britain, just so we can sway in the wind. And say to each other: "Now, here we are, and this is sport, and we are kings and queens."

Yours sincerely,
Tim Pears

webTitle: Gag on spies' role in Noye case

fields.headline: Gag on spies' role in Noye case
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has signed "gagging orders" to protect the role of the intelligence agencies in catching the M25 killer Kenneth Noye, one of Britain's most notorious villains.
fields.body:
Jack Straw has signed "gagging orders" to protect the role of the intelligence agencies in catching the M25 killer Kenneth Noye, one of Britain's most notorious villains.

The existence of the orders is the first official confirmation of the involvement of the spying agencies in the capture of Noye.

Details of the home secretary's action have been released to the Guardian under John Major's "open government" code - in use in advance of the freedom of information bill becoming law next year - following a request from the newspaper.

Mr Straw has taken the action in advance of an appeal by Noye against his life sentence for a "road rage" murder in 1996.

The home secretary signed two gagging orders - officially known as public interest immunity certificates - on February 2 and 8 this year.

He said that the certificates were necessary in order to "prevent real harm" being inflicted on the confidential work of the intelligence agencies, who now have an important role in catching criminals.

Noye, 53, was jailed for life for stabbing to death Stephen Cameron during an argument on the M25 in May 1996. Immediately after the murder, Noye fled abroad.

It is believed that the gagging orders keep secret how the intelligence agencies helped to track down Noye by covertly eavesdropping on his mobile telephone calls.

It is understood that the security service MI5, and operatives at the government communications headquarters (GCHQ) at Cheltenham, monitored Noye's calls to friends and business associates.

After numerous alleged sightings over two years, this apparently enabled police officers to locate the origin of the calls and then home in on Noye's real hiding-place in Spain.

Following the end of the cold war and IRA ceasefires, MI5 lobbied fiercely within Whitehall to be given other work to justify its existence. In 1996, its activities were extended to support police in the prevention and detection of serious crime.

Critics argued that the obsessive secrecy surrounding MI5 would damage the open criminal justice system because, unlike the police, the organisation would seek to use gagging orders to stop its activities from being scrutinised fairly in court.

fields.headline: Crowd-pleaser leads England to victory
fields.trailText: It was probably Darren Gough and Andy Caddick who won this match, by bowling their 20 overs with a lethal combination of hostility and economy. It may even have been Nasser Hussain, who won a vital toss. But neither of these theories would cut much ice with the sunburnt thousands at Lord's. For them, there was only one matchwinner: Alec Stewart.
fields.body:
It was probably Darren Gough and Andy Caddick who won this match, by bowling their 20 overs with a lethal combination of hostility and economy. It may even have been Nasser Hussain, who won a vital toss. But neither of these theories would cut much ice with the sunburnt thousands at Lord's. For them, there was only one matchwinner: Alec Stewart.

Eight days ago, Stewart was having a one-day series to forget. He was keeping well, but his captaincy was indifferent (England were awful in the first two games) and as an opening batsman, he was playing junior partner to a much younger man, Marcus Trescothick. When Stewart failed for the third time in a row, his career average slipped below 30. He has admitted that as he gets older, he is more interested in statistics. This one was not so much a stat as a scandal. Stewart realised it, and rectified it with successive scores of 79 not out, 101, 100 not out and 97: the purplest patch not just in his one-day career, but in the whole chequered history of the boys in bright blue.

Today he was at his imperious best, adjusting to the conditions so well that he barely got a run with his two favourite strokes, the cut and the pull. Instead he was cover-driving, in that distinctive thwacking way of his, and even on-driving, to the delight of a crowd who were traditional enough to know the difference between a cow-shot and real class. It barely mattered that Trescothick and the other young pretender, Andy Flintoff, managed just one run between them. Stewart was on the field for 86.3 overs today, to go with 100 on Thursday, 96 on Tuesday, and the whole match last Saturday. And he was in the thick of the action all that time. Some of the crowd were unhappy that there wasn't a band playing at Lord's today. There was: a one-man band.

In one-day tournaments, the team that finishes first is the team that finishes best - that hits form half-way through, and builds an unstoppable momentum. For once, that team was England. Nasser Hussain, with an awful lot of help from Stewart, became only the second England captain of recent times after Adam Hollioake to lift a three-sided trophy.

The opposition weren't great, but you still have to do the business and England, as well as having two high-scoring openers (they could have had three if they had played Nick Knight ahead of Flintoff), were much the best bowling side in a bowlers' tournament. Today the third, fourth and fifth seamers - Mullally, Ealham and White - were less miserly than before, but that just made a reasonable game of it. And Gough and Caddick were exceptional. Mullally, rated No. 2 in the world by PriceWaterhouseCoopers, isn't even the second-best one-day bowler in this team.

Abroad, on flat tracks, this attack will be too samey, and the tail it entails too long. But in these conditions, it was spot-on.

For the Zimbabweans, losing the toss made the game a bridge too far. Their tour ends in defeat, but with the dignity that characterised it from day one. Buffeted by events at home and blown away in the Lord's Test, they fought back strongly and won many friends. Now they are losing two of their few real internationals, Neil Johnson and Murray Goodwin. Andy Flower, who batted superbly with his brother Grant in a crisis, deserves better.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.
