He was keeping well, but his captaincy was indifferent (England were awful in the first two games) and as an opening batsman, he was playing junior partner to a much younger man, Marcus Trescothick. When Stewart failed for the third time in a row, his career average slipped below 30. He has admitted that as he gets older, he is more interested in statistics. This one was not so much a stat as a scandal. Stewart realised it, and rectified it with successive scores of 79 not out, 101, 100 not out and 97: the purplest patch not just in his one-day career, but in the whole chequered history of the boys in bright blue. Today he was at his imperious best, adjusting to the conditions so well that he barely got a run with his two favourite strokes, the cut and the pull. Instead he was cover-driving, in that distinctive thwacking way of his, and even on-driving, to the delight of a crowd who were traditional enough to know the difference between a cow-shot and real class. It barely mattered that Trescothick and the other young pretender, Andy Flintoff, managed just one run between them. Stewart was on the field for 86.3 overs today, to go with 100 on Thursday, 96 on Tuesday, and the whole match last Saturday. And he was in the thick of the action all that time. Some of the crowd were unhappy that there wasn't a band playing at Lord's today. There was: a one-man band. In one-day tournaments, the team that finishes first is the team that finishes best - that hits form half-way through, and builds an unstoppable momentum. For once, that team was England. Nasser Hussain, with an awful lot of help from Stewart, became only the second England captain of recent times after Adam Hollioake to lift a three-sided trophy. The opposition weren't great, but you still have to do the business and England, as well as having two high-scoring openers (they could have had three if they had played Nick Knight ahead of Flintoff), were much the best bowling side in a bowlers' tournament. Today the third, fourth and fifth seamers - Mullally, Ealham and White - were less miserly than before, but that just made a reasonable game of it. And Gough and Caddick were exceptional. Mullally, rated No. 2 in the world by PriceWaterhouseCoopers, isn't even the second-best one-day bowler in this team. Abroad, on flat tracks, this attack will be too samey, and the tail it entails too long. But in these conditions, it was spot-on. For the Zimbabweans, losing the toss made the game a bridge too far. Their tour ends in defeat, but with the dignity that characterised it from day one. Buffeted by events at home and blown away in the Lord's Test, they fought back strongly and won many friends. Now they are losing two of their few real internationals, Neil Johnson and Murray Goodwin. Andy Flower, who batted superbly with his brother Grant in a crisis, deserves better. Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

fields.headline: England's next Test venue?
fields.standfirst: Fancy yourself as a Wisden columnist? Email your opinions, musings and rants to beamer@guardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: I have been to several cricket matches before, but when I went to the Riverside a week ago there was a palpable sense of history. A dream had been released and the occasion certainly did not disappoint.
fields.body:
I have been to several cricket matches before, but when I went to the Riverside a week ago there was a palpable sense of history. A dream had been released and the occasion certainly did not disappoint.

It was only the third international match to be held at the ground and the first to involve England. A match between England and West Indies has a slightly higher profile than one between Scotland and Pakistan (who met here in the last World Cup). On that sultry, resplendent Thursday a small band of Pakistan fans screaming for the television cameras, and a kilted Conga were the highlights in a predictable Pakistani romp. However, last weekend below Lumley Castle, cricket won, as a new Test venue was surely found in a magnificent, if one-sided match.

Fifteen thousand people packed into the extensive ground, which a decade ago did not exist. There may be only one stand (incorporating the pavilion) at the moment but when the hotel is built, Durham cheeks will be beetroot colour with pride as 20,000 people will be able to be packed in.

The atmosphere was brilliant: unlike Headingley the people were friendly, and unlike Edgbaston the crowd (minus two) knew their drinking limits. Not even the weather could spoil the occasion. An England victory helped though. The temporary seating showed the potential the Riverside ground has.

As I walked around the ground, there were people smiling, dancers jigging with joy and all different kinds of boisterous horns being bellowed into. But as we left the ground - after the usual monotonous presentation formalities (I am yet to stand in front of the pavilion and actually hear what on earth is being said) ready to join the endless disorderly queues of cars I heard people moaning about how uneven the match was. The word "boring" was even used. I could not believe it.

Daily I read people moaning in the press about England. Indeed this very column is often a whine about the state of the national team. But as soon as we wallop the Windies by ten wickets, the match is "disappointing". I wonder whether they would have moaned if it had been Australia demolishing the tourists at the MCG by the same devastating margin. I doubt it.

I am 16 and cannot remember England even threatening to win the Ashes. In fact my memory only serves me with three England series victories. Pathetic. My generation revels in any England victory; they are so few and far between that we celebrate and enjoy any molecule of success. What our national football team would do for the recent success the cricketers have bathed in.

Zimbabwe are a good, compact side and to beat them twice comprehensively is a major achievement. To find a new Test opener in the process is a real bonus.

I really do hope that in the very near future, when England introduce a new Test ground to the world (for the first time since an Ashes match in 1902 at Bramall Lane) that Marcus Trescothick opens the batting and a young local lad, Steve Harmison, delivers the first ball.

Chris Wilson is a 16-year-old student. To read last week's Punter's Point, on the almost perfect England one-day XI, click here

webTitle: Could you cope with an unexpected rise in salary?

fields.headline: Could you cope with an unexpected rise in salary?
fields.standfirst: Spend some, save some and keep a little back for the taxman
fields.trailText: Spend some, save some and keep a little back for the taxman
fields.body:
There's only one suitable reaction to a big salary increase. Pure, unadulterated glee. An increased salary can mean many things - a new car, a glammy holiday, designer clothes, the chance to get a mortgage. But they all are based on the same first reaction - increased salary means increased spending - and usually a deeply meaningful relationship with a gold card.

Or at least that's how it feels at first. "I went from a full-time job on a salary of £32k to working as a contractor on £45k," says Richard McCarthy, an IT programmer. "The first couple of months it felt fantastic - finally, no money worries. But gradually it dawned on me that my new salary caused me different worries - shouldn't I save some of it? Put some away for tax? Get a pension or an individual savings account (Isa)? I just had no idea where to start."

According to psychologist Jonathan Maddox, an increase in wealth can bring a whole host of new anxieties and problems. "Money is an odd thing," he says. "Supposedly, being better off makes your life easier - but you have to decide what to do with it. Should you invest it - and if so, what percentage? How much should you save? Financial matters can seem incredibly daunting if you've only ever had a current account and a Visa card. But in order to enjoy money you have to be in control of it and that usually means consulting someone professional."

With the demise of bank managers, it can be hard to know who to turn to for advice. Some of the high street banks offer account managers, who you can talk to about your money - but more often the best person to turn to is an independent financial adviser (IFA) - someone who is not affiliated to any bank or financial organisation and so can offer what is genuinely the best option for you. The best way to find a good IFA is a personal recommendation so ask around, but they are generally listed in the phone book."

"When most people receive a salary hike, they tend to split it 50/50 - half to spend and half to invest," says Matthew Orr of Killik & Co Stockbrokers. "That's the easy part. Then you have to decide whether you want an Isa or a pension, or go for individual stocks and shares. The common mistake is putting off investing in an Isa or a pension until you're in your 30s. It makes much better financial sense to start investing in your 20s."

Anna Maidley, who works as a magazine journalist, admits to regretting not sorting out her finances earlier. "Two years ago I got promoted to features editor - with a £7,000 pay rise - and I haven't saved a penny," she admits. "Now all my friends are buying flats and I simply don't have the deposit. At the time I just loved having money to spend, and investing in an Isa or sorting out a savings account just seemed really dull."

Admittedly, sorting out your finances is about as much fun as a double episode of Emmerdale - but if the effort is too much it can be worth paying someone else to do the dirty work for you. "There are two common misconceptions about accountants," says Mike Davis, who specialises in accountancy for small businesses and individuals. "One is that they cost a fortune and the second is that they are only necessary for big businesses. Both are incorrect. If you're earning good money then a few hundred pounds spent on an accountant each year is nothing - and they can advise on all financial matters - not just tax."

According to Davis, the most common mistake people make is not to save for the short term.

"People put money in Isas or pensions and think that's all the saving they need to do," he says. "But it's important to have some back-up money that you can get to should you need it - and if you work as a freelance or a contractor, with no company behind you, then it's essential."

Anna Maidley agrees with this. "I'm starting to save now, but I seem to be miles behind all my friends. I just don't have a clue where to start. Even getting a savings account was a nightmare - there are just so many different options to choose from."

The key, as with most things, is to do your research properly. "The number of savings and investment options open to you is bewildering," says Matthew Killik.

"But it's important to realise that interest rates change all the time. Generally, building societies do offer better rates, but sometimes a bank will roll out a special deal. The best thing to do is ring round and see who is offering what. Investment is not a static thing - it changes all the time and you have to stay on your toes to keep up with it."

The advantage of a salary hike is having some spare dosh. Spoil yourself with a couple of modest luxuries by all means. But if savings and investments bore you stupid, splash a little cash on an IFA or accountant to sort your money out for you.

webTitle: How to... sit on the other side of the interview table

fields.headline: How to... sit on the other side of the interview table
fields.standfirst: Don't let your prey wriggle off the hook - press them for an answer
fields.trailText: Don't let your prey wriggle off the hook - press them for an answer
fields.body:
Fail to prepare... prepare to fail. As maxims go this could be applied to many tasks - but it's particularly relevant when it comes to mastering the art of interviewing. How often have you heard it said that interviewers make up their mind about interviewees in the first two minutes? But now that you're on the other side of the table and interviewing someone for the first time, you should appreciate that making quick judgements is not the way to determine whether someone has the right skills and experience for the job.

But where do you begin? How do you know what questions to ask? How can you judge if the person you're interviewing is not only right for the job but right for the team and the company? In the book Successful Interviewing, its authors define the four Ps of interviewing as: purpose, preparation, performance and postscript.

Think back to when you were on the other side of the desk, sweating and fidgeting nervously as you were asked about your strong and weak points. You had a purpose (you wanted a job), you had (or should have) prepared and done some research on the company. You were interviewed and your performance was probably analysed afterwards (postscript).

According to Carolyn Axtell, research fellow at the Institute of Work Psychology, University of Sheffield, "determining the purpose of the interview beforehand will make your job a lot easier. The type and structure of the interview will be different, for example, if you have been asked to assess someone's skills and experience than if you want to find out about their personality."

Preparation is more than just reading a CV or application form. The candidate's CV or application form should be the building block from which you source your background information and decide which questions to ask.

So, you've read the CV, made a list of questions and are ready to start. It's best to begin the interview with an 'icebreaker' - ask the candidate about their journey etc, and try to build some rapport. Your role as the interviewer is to give the interviewee a good impression of the company. Be polite and make the candidate feel relaxed. Keep smiling and maintain a non-threatening stance.

Remember that the interview is an information-gathering exercise, so avoid asking closed questions, which will result in a 'yes' or 'no' answer. Asking open questions - for example, "Explain how you did..." - will yield much more information and may help to clarify any ambiguities on their CV.

The interview should be a two way process: just as you are assessing them, the interviewee is trying to determine if they want to work for your team. Being aware of non-verbal communication is just as important.

Nervousness at interviews is only to be expected. But if the interviewee seems over anxious and you're interviewing for a job in something like sales, where confidence is important, it may be time to move on to the next candidate.

Eva Reynolds had only been working in a media-related job for a year when she was asked to interview two people for the position of junior account executive. "It was a small company and since I had done the same course as the two interviewees, I knew what skills the course taught and what skills the job required. Oddly enough, the skills you need for the course and those you need for the job are very different. The people who did well on the course were not necessarily the best people for the job," she explains.

Carolyn Axtell says that whatever the objective of the interview, whether it's to find out if the person can do the job or to suss out their personality, you should try to avoid the following:

 Making a premature decision - wait until the end of the interview.

 The 'halo effect' where one favourable aspect clouds your judgement of all other aspects.

 The over-weighting of negative information, where one negative response prejudices your judgement.

 Bias and prejudice.

 Dispositional errors - de-emphasising the effect of the situation on behaviour

 Information overload, especially if you are the only one interviewing.

After the interview is over, you've written up your notes, weighed up all the facts and made your decision (yes or no) it's a good idea to assess your own performance.

If you don't remember anything else....

Don't let the good candidates slip through the net. A lazy interview might make the interviewee think the company is chaotic and disorganised. But if you are well-prepared and go about the interview professionally, you will leave a favourable impression with those you are keen to attract.

fields.headline: Bubbling up
fields.trailText: Joelle Marti, wine manager at London's Great Eastern Hotel
fields.body:
Name: Joelle Marti

Status: Wine manager at London's Great Eastern Hotel

Past: Studied catering, wine tasting and wine making at a French university. Her first job was as an assistant sommelier, sourcing the wine for the Michelin-starred La Poularde restaurant near Lyon. Moved to England and worked for several restaurants before becoming head sommelier with the Great Eastern Hotel.

Present: Buys wine for four restaurants, three bars and all 267 bedrooms of the hotel. Also responsible for training the team of seven sommeliers.

Future: "I can't imagine working outside the wine industry."

Strengths: "Integrity - you can use fantastic words to describe a wine but you have to believe it."

Weaknesses: "I have a really bad temper. I shout at people sometimes, but never in an unfair way. I've been told it will change as I get older, but it's getting worse!"

Wisdom: "Listen, progress and never forget to be humble. With humility you will become more approachable. By being approachable you will carry on working and learning."

References:www.great-eastern-hotel.co.uk

webTitle: Can A-levels predict your career success?

fields.headline: Can A-levels predict your career success?
fields.standfirst: Steps to take if your UCAS points don't add up
fields.trailText: Steps to take if your UCAS points don't add up
fields.body:
Asking how many UCAS points you have is not just a desperate fresher's chat-up line. For many companies it is a perfectly acceptable way of dumping what they perceive to be unattractive applicants. And with around half of graduate recruiters using UCAS points in some way in their selection process, job seekers whose A-level grades don't tot up might wonder what their time at university has added to their pull in the job market.

"I think there is some justification for this point of view," says Catherine Gregory, career adviser at the University of Bradford, "particularly when people are excluded by computer or a simple clerical sift. If an application form never gets seen by a recruitment manager how can you make your case? A lot of the evidence is anecdotal, but I have even seen a PhD student whose academic abilities could hardly be doubted experience great difficulty in trying to convince one of the big consultancy firms of his merits, though eventually he was accepted."

The secret to overcoming poor UCAS points, or in certain cases no UCAS points at all, is to know as much as you can about how and why they are used as well as having the perseverance to push your application as hard as possible. For the companies, the main justification for using A-level grades is because they can predict future performance. This is demonstrably the case in areas like accountancy where post-university qualifications are essential.

Accountancy firms justify their use of UCAS points by referring to the correlation between success at A-level and the ability to pass the professional exams. Although the reasons for this correlation are unclear, (it may be that both A-levels and accountancy exams require the ability to cover several subjects at once), it remains too tempting a relationship to ignore.

Angus Farr is recruitment manager at HLB Kidsons, a medium-sized firm of chartered accountants and business advisers which takes on around 50 graduates a year. "We recently estimated that a new graduate costs us around £100,000 in the first three years," he says. "That is a sizable investment and we are a commercial organisation, so if there is a way to minimize the risk of our trainees failing we will use it, and utilising the correlation is the best way we can do that."

This, then is why the more an organisation relies upon professional qualifications, the more likely it is to specify a minimum UCAS requirement. Once you move away from these sectors, the tendency is for A-levels to diminish in importance.

Glaxo Welcome UK, for example, uses a range of criteria. "We read every form," says Joe Voelcker, graduate programme manager, "and we assign scores to applications across a range of pre-determined criteria. A-levels and GCSE results are included in the scoring system, but points are also awarded for the answers to the competency questions. It is the total that matters, and if the academic points are not high, the deficit can be made up elsewhere."

The best thing an applicant can do therefore is find out as much as possible about the way a company scores the application form, and then to use this knowledge to focus hard on areas which score highly. "I always advise people who are worried about this to ring up and ask," says Catherine Gregory. "In fact, it is even worth doing if you fail to meet their minimum requirement. You never know, if you put your case well enough, you could even circumvent that difficulty."

The other solution to this problem of course is to apply to one of the 50% of graduate recruiters who don't care about UCAS points. "Apart from finance applicants, we don't look at A-levels at all," says Paul Sunderland, graduate recruitment manager at Safeway. "For IT and our general scheme we are assessing competency and enthusiasm for working in retail. We do look at degree results because they reflect the applicant's abilities now. Otherwise we could be excluding certain groups of candidates."

A small, but growing, number of students now fall into these excluded groups:

 Late developers will show a mismatch between their A-level grades and degree;

 Mature students will often either have taken one or two A-levels at night school or have entered university through an access course; Others will have come through GNVQ advanced qualifications (though the UCAS points system is changing next year to take this into account);

 Some graduates will have got into university with lower grades through clearing;

 Others will not have performed well due to illness or other personal difficulties.

And while individual companies may have specific arrangements which allow them to cater to these non-standard applicants, there remains a feeling among some graduate job seekers that the indiscriminate use of UCAS points borders on unfair discrimination.

There are however only three reasons why those companies which rely heavily on using UCAS points as a selection tool will change: economics, ethics, and a change in the law. In terms of economics, stringent criteria indicate that a company feels it is attracting a broad and talented enough range of applicants to secure its future success. Only when this is not the case will the UCAS minimum be removed. Secondly, from the ethical point of view, as the number of non A-level applicants slowly increases, it may slowly become less acceptable to deselect candidates in this way. Thirdly, although there is as yet no legislation on age discrimination, if this were to be enacted, mature students in particular could find their position improved.

fields.headline: The Village Pub, Barnsley
fields.standfirst: If your outdoor plans are scuppered by the weather, a country inn is the best alternative. Especially when it's as good as The Village Pub, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: If your outdoor plans are scuppered by the weather, a country inn is the best alternative. Especially when it's as good as The Village Pub, says Matthew Fort
fields.body:
Address: The Village Pub, Barnsley
There is a ritual to the making of a good Bloody Mary, a certain ceremonial stateliness to the ordering of ingredients, adding the dash of this and the splash of that, building up the layers of flavour, keeping a balance and harmony between them, so that, as you taste that first slug, there's the crackle of celery salt, the fruitiness of tomato juice, the round warmth of Worcestershire sauce, the slow burn of Tabasco, the dry crackle of sherry and, finally, the long fingers of alcohol reaching gently up into the brain as the vodka comes into its own.

But horseradish? "Would you like horseradish?" asked the young lady behind the bar of the Village Pub. Why not, said Philomena, for whom the sacramental Bloody Mary was being prepared. So it came with horseradish, and celery salt crusted around the rim. The perfect, definitive Bloody Mary, said Philomena. Oho, I thought. Ahah.

We - that is, Philomena, Room-for-Two Lewis, their son Ben and I - had gone to The Village Pub at the suggestion of two readers. You can find it in the languidly pretty village of Barnsley, just outside Cirencester. The appealing baldness of the name is matched by the appealing comfort of the place. Had the weather been more clement, we could have eaten in the courtyard outside. As it was, proto-Arctic conditions encouraged us to take up a table in the plain, handsome interior.

I was right about the wider implications of the Bloody Mary rituals. The Hook Norton bitter, with which Room-for-Two and I settled the nerves, was in exquisite nick, and young Ben's lemonade was Fentimans, a superior brand. If a pub will take such pains over its Bloody Mary, beer and lemonade, you need have no fear about lunch, that's my feeling.

The chef is a young fellow by the name of Graham Grafton, who got here by way of The Greenhouse, The Ivy, Le Caprice and Bibendum, a CV that suggests that he knows how to cook sensible food seriously, which is what you want in a pub. You may quibble with the pedigree of a dish such as smoked mackerel Niçoise, but you couldn't, according to Room-for-Two, complain about the result. The smoked fish, he said, really benefited from the Niçoise treatment, and the smoking actually did things for the salad, too.

Ben and Philomena's grilled sardines were as fresh as you could wish, splendidly cooked, and some baked pepper and tomato (a bit of a Delia touch) helped flesh out the dish intelligently. I, meanwhile, had been drawn to a dish of chicken liver and black pudding hash. The job description was a bit misleading -hash, I thought, meant that everything was mashed up together. Here, the hunks of liver, the chunks of soft, French-style pudding and the fried potatoes were arranged separately around a tussock of salad. Still, each element was well-sourced and very well cooked, and the salad was dressed for the occasion.

I didn't get quite such a kick from the duck-plums-and-noodles business with which I followed this up, largely because I am not convinced that this is the best way to serve duck. I could have done without the noodles, for one, and the slop of soya gravy. The duck breast, on the other hand, was superbly rich and juicy, while the gently tart plums were on hand to discipline any sense of over-indulgence.

Ben declared his steak to be the best he had ever had. I noticed that he passed on the creamed leeks, but I put that down to the natural aversion of a 15-year-old boy to all vegetables except chips (which were very good, incidentally). Room-for-Two's Moroccan beef casserole looked and tasted a hit. It was massive, black and glossy; sweet, soft and fibrous; genial and broad-shouldered, with a hint of the exotic. In short, it was very fine eating from every perspective. Philomena was just as entranced by her sea bass, which demonstrated the benefits of not mucking about with a good piece of very fresh fish, other than to cook it with precision. It gave her a lot of pleasure.

She was not, however, so voluble about her fish as she was about the coffee crème caramel. This is a very difficult dish to carry off because texture is almost everything in the crème caramel universe; that, and the bitterness of the caramel. The delicate, just-holding wobble was perfect and the coffee flavouring marked but not unbalanced - perhaps it didn't quite have the second-strike bitterness from the burnt caramel that distinguishes my mother's peerless version, but it was pretty damned fine whichever way you ate it. The pannacotta was not in the same league, unfortunately: a shade too much gelatine in the mix had turned it rather too solid for my liking, though this is not a major-league complaint.

Indeed, such small quibbles aside, I have nothing but praise for The Village Pub. Aside from the care taken with the beer and the Bloody Mary, there are 17 wines available by the glass from a short, well- chosen and sensibly-priced list - we put paid to a bottle of silky Sedara Donnafugata Rosso Sicilia at £16.95, as well as a glass of Vina Carmen Insigne Sauvignon Blanc for Philomena. There are no bar snacks, but a couple of interesting sandwich items appear on the menu. The service had a diverting charm. The food was as above. And the bill was £101.85, or about £25 a head all in. You can take that down to £17 if you strip out drinks, coffee, etc, which is pretty fair value all round. Make that very good value

Small helpings

Telephone: 01753 855370
Address: Al Fassia, 7 St Leonard's Road, Windsor, Berks
16/20
Food: Moroccan
Price: £10-20 per head (excluding drinks)

A short haul from mainstream, tidied and twee tourist Windsor lies a treasure house of North African cooking: Al Fassia has the warmth and informality of a family-run place, and the scrupulous attention to detail of serious professionalism. The couscous has the dry, light, airy quality of a dandelion head. The tagines unleash a sequence of seductive, euphonious riffs. Mellow is right. Order specialities such as m'hummar, trid, mechoui and sharia madfouna a couple of days ahead. Proto-wine list, but decent enough.

Telephone: 020-7636 2833
Address: Passione, 10 Charlotte Street, London W1.
16/20
Food: Italian.
Price: £15-25 per head (excluding drinks).

It's small, it's cool, it's smart, but it buzzes with real passione. Chef Gennaro Contaldo (Jamie Oliver's guru) was the man who came up with all the wild things for Antonio Carluccio's TV series, and now he is doing the same at Passione. So there are, natch, wild mushrooms here and there, but also wild sorrel in a risotto, wild garlic in a pesto variation, wild broccoli as a veg doused in olive oil and lemon juice, real wild rocket for salads. Unwild meats and fishes are treated with notable precision, and with the lightness of touch redolent of southern Italian cooking. Short, sharp wine list. Dextrous service of great charm.

Telephone: 01227 751360
Address: The Dove Inn, Plum Pudding Lane, Dargate, Near Faversham, Kent
14/20
Food: Modern European.
Price: £10-25 a head (excluding drinks).

Pub with a restaurant, not a restaurant posing as a pub. Red brick and flower-girt without. Comfortable, unmucked-about within. The bar is still a bar, where you can murder a pint of tip-top Shepherd Neame and properly prepared bar snacks; or head for the dining room if it's more serious tucker you're after. Chef/proprietor Nigel Morris is a man of Kent with a real cooking pedigree. He brings the skills of the big professional kitchen to bear on local ingredients with notably happy results. Most dishes are in the mainstream European tradition - viz saddle of lamb with tomato and basil jus; pork rillettes with chutney; brown shrimps with ginger and garlic. There's a potent wine list, to boot.

fields.headline: Go the whole hog
fields.standfirst: Enjoy a fresh-air feast by all means, but make sure you do it in style, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Enjoy a fresh-air feast by all means, but make sure you do it in style, says Christopher Lloyd.
fields.body:
As an opener of my own garden, Great Dixter, to the public, I share the attitude of other regular garden-openers: that is, the last thing I want is picnickers. The debris left behind is hideous, and someone has to clear it all up. It is disastrous to scatter litter-bins around the garden, as visitors will pile into them all the rubbish they would otherwise have had to dispose of in their own dustbins. Anyway, if you want a view to enjoy while you picnic, my garden is the wrong place. Shelter matters to serious gardeners far more than a view, so most views have been planted out here.

When I see picnickers by the road-side on my annual visit to Scotland, I am always amazed. As close as they can to car or caravan, they set up a great paraphernalia of tables and chairs, even of shelter screens; they might just as well have remained at home and in their own gardens.

To sit or, better still, lie on grassy turf has a lot going for it. Dispense with rugs, and you get the direct pleasure of the smell of green and growing grass, which is quite different from when it has been mown.

The garden in which I picnic most often is not my own but that at Glyndebourne, during the 80-minute interval expressly allowed for the purpose during the opera festival; the conductor always gets an extra-enthusiastic ovation on his return - it's wonderful what champagne, or even a quite ordinary wine, can do. Every regular has their favourite spot, and positions are taken up before the opera starts, sometimes hours earlier. Peripheral positions around the lawns seem to be preferred, though personally, not being over-inhibited by modesty, I am happy to settle down in the middle of the biggest lawn. A position next to the ha-ha and overlooking the meadow beyond, with Firle Beacon in the distance, is also popular.

Glyndebourne audiences, having taken the trouble to dress up a bit for what is, after all, an occasion, are pretty well behaved on the whole, and tend not to leave much debris behind. However, an assortment of picnicking equipment does get left, because it is dark by the time the opera ends. On one occasion, a refuse container was found to contain a funeral casket of human ashes - presumably, an opera buff who had asked to have them scattered in the garden was ill-served by a relation without the willpower to carry through the request.

I am sorry to see a creeping sophistication on the increase: an ever-smaller proportion of Glyndebourne picnickers is now happy with a rug on the ground. There is an increasing tide of tables and chairs, even of candles and silver candlesticks. Some show-offs even bring a butler.

A picnic should not, I think, be elaborate. The fewer knives, forks, plates and other equipment, the better. Some people seem to be born picnickers; they'll prepare the fare at great speed and with the minimum of fuss. Something simple such as Scotch wild smoked salmon sandwiches is ideal (I did not say that money spent on a picnic should be minimal, after all). As to having a picnic in your own garden, however, I really don't see the point. It is, of course, lovely to use a seating area as an outside dining room, but that hardly constitutes a picnic.

On those rare occasions when a summer's evening is really still, I like to eat outside with saved-up candle ends scattered all over the terrace. But while you may enjoy the pots of flowers that have been stood around by day, don't be surprised if you are aggravated by hordes of so-called thunderflies, especially this month. These are actually thrips - they don't bite, but they madden by settling all over you, with a special preference for your scalp

England v Zimbabwe NatWest Triangular Series, Lord's

Sky Sports 1 live 10.30am-6.30pm

webTitle: I'm proud of my record, says doctor guilty of malpractice

fields.headline: I'm proud of my record, says doctor guilty of malpractice
fields.trailText: Richard Neale, the gynaecologist found guilty of more than 30 charges of malpractice, was yesterday described as incompetent, arrogant and downright dishonest in hearings before the General Medical Council to decide whether he should be struck off the medical register.
fields.body:
Richard Neale, the gynaecologist found guilty of more than 30 charges of malpractice, was yesterday described as incompetent, arrogant and downright dishonest in hearings before the General Medical Council to decide whether he should be struck off the medical register.

But after a searing indictment by the prosecuting counsel, Vivian Robinson QC, of his inadequacies and the damage he has done to women over the 14 years in the UK since losing his licence to practice in Canada in 1985, Mr Neale made a tearful plea to the tribunal, claiming he was always "a surgeon who put his patients' best interests at heart".

He told the professional conduct committee, which will decide next week whether to strike him off after hearing from character witnesses: "I do hope that I am not the worst surgeon there has ever been. I hope the evidence from other doctors will show that I showed sympathy, compassion and tender loving care to my patients."

He said he was "especially proud" of his record at Friarage hopspital in Northallerton, North York shire, where he had saved 100% of his elderly cancer patients for at least five years. "I loved medicine, it was my life and I was wedded to it. It was the greatest privilege," he said.

He claimed the complaints against him had been orches trated by just two patients and that he had been demonised by the media.

He was, he said, "just an average surgeon, not good and not all bad."

He admitted he had made mistakes in Canada. To hollow laughter from former patients in the gallery, he offered to take a retraining course in gynaecology in the UK.

Once the case is over, there will be questions to answer for both the GMC, which did not take action against Mr Neale after it was informed he had been struck off in Canada, and the hospital trust in Northallerton where Mr Neale was given a £100,000 pay-off to leave after 10 years and a clean reference in spite of concerns over his competence.

fields.headline: Poor Clare
fields.standfirst: John Clare enthusiasts are up in arms over an American academic's claim to own copyright of the poet's works unpublished in his lifetime.  John Goodridge reports on the battle over a great literary legacy
fields.trailText: John Clare enthusiasts are up in arms over an American academic's claim to own copyright of the poet's works unpublished in his lifetime. John Goodridge reports on the battle over a great literary legacy
fields.body:
When John Clare died of a stroke on May 20 1864, aged 70, he was almost a forgotten figure. For 23 years he had been confined in the Northampton General Lunatic Asylum, which he called "the purgatorial hell and French bastile of English liberty, where harmless people are trapped and tortured until they die". He is now recognised as the finest and most prolific of all English rural poets, as important as his contemporaries Keats, Shelley and Byron.

But the growing interest in Clare and increasing demand for new editions of his work have exposed a literary imprisonment almost as cruel, certainly as unusual, as the one he suffered in the "bastile" at Northampton. The case has united such high-profile Clare enthusiasts as Seamus Heaney, Tom Paulin and Andrew Motion, the poet laureate, in a campaign to "free" the poet. For, amazingly, 136 years after Clare's death, the copyright to most of his writings is still claimed as private property by a single individual.

Professor Eric Robinson, a historian at the University of Massachusetts, Boston, has for the past 35 years claimed to own the copyright to Clare's unpublished writings. He has enforced this claim, demanding acknowledgement and often payment from anyone who wishes to publish Clare material. In the view of Tim Chilcott, the effect has been "the impoverishment of editorial debate compared with other Romantic writers, the absence of challenging alternative views, the deadening hand of the authorised 'definitive version'."

For 35 years scholars have grumbled, and sometimes tried to resist this singular control of Clare. In recent years, such writers as Zachary Leader and Hugh Haughton have criticised the effects of the copyright claim. But it was not until last July that anyone did anything about it. Then, a young Clare scholar whose PhD I supervised, Simon Kövesi of the University of Dundee, published a selection of Clare's Love Poems, openly refusing to accept the validity of the copyright claim.

Four months later, he and his publisher received letters from Robinson's solicitors, Harbottle and Lewis, claiming a breach of Robinson's "copyright in those works written by John Clare which were not published during his lifetime". The letters also claim, for good measure, that poems in the anthology were taken from Robinson's edited texts, and that Kövesi had defamed Robinson "both on the internet and to journalists". Kövesi and his publisher deny both these accusations.

Robinson, said his lawyers, was "entitled to damages together with an undertaking that you will not infringe, in the future, the copyrights that he holds". Kövesi and his publisher were invited to supply, within 21 days, proposals for "compensating Professor Robinson", with the threat of "immediate legal proceedings" should they fail to supply such proposals.

So how did this extraordinary situation come about?

As an officially patronised "peasant poet", the young John Clare had much of his income tied into trusts, managed on his behalf by two trustees, his London publisher, John Taylor, and his local clergyman, the Reverend Mr Mossop. After the relative popularity of his first two books, Poems Descriptive Of Rural Life And Scenery (1820) and The Village Minstrel (1821), literary success increasingly evaded Clare, and the two other volumes published in his lifetime, The Shepherd's Calendar (1827) and The Rural Muse (1835), were subject to delay and heavy editorial cutting. As he became more prone to depression and illness, Clare worried about the legacy of his copyright and the income from his publications, and drafted several wills, though none was probated on his death.

Even as his literary hopes were fading, Clare was writing some of his best poetry, and he would continue to write almost to the end of his life. His two most anthologised poems, "I Am" and "Little Trotty Wagtail", were written in the asylum, as were more than 1,000 others, many of them transcribed by the asylum attendant WF Knight. During the long asylum years, his loyal supporters made several attempts to revive interest in his work and create new editions of it, but nothing came of any of these plans. After his death, however, more determined efforts began to be made, and this is where the story of Clare's copyright really begins.

Under the 1842 Copyright Act which was in force at Clare's death, in the case of published works copyright endured for 42 years after publication or seven years after the author's death, whichever was later. Thus three of Clare's published volumes came out of copyright in 1871, and the fourth in 1877. For unpublished works, however, copyright was a very different matter. Under common law, an author, or after his death his personal representative, retained perpetual control over his work as long as it remained unpublished. This is particularly important in Clare's case, since his four published volumes contained only about 10% of his total output - some 300 poems out of more than 3,000 he wrote in his lifetime.

This common law "perpetual" loophole for unpublished material was written into the Copyright Acts of 1911 and 1956, and finally replaced in the 1988 Act with a finite, 50-year term of protection (made potentially extendable by a further 25 years in a 1996 Act). In Clare's case, this could extend the copyright claim well into the middle of this century, though, as Jonathan Griffiths of Nottingham Law School has argued, such a claim could be open to challenge under the freedom of expression legislation in the Human Rights Act 1998, due to come into force in October.

It is by no means clear whether Clare's personal representative after his death was his widow Patty Clare, or his trustees; nor is it obvious that the enticing legal vision of perpetual power over the work was continuously transmitted through a hundred-year period to the current claim, though a simple provenance can be deduced. The key figure is Joseph Whitaker (1820-95), now remembered for Whitaker's Almanack but known in his time as an astute publisher who was, as the Dictionary of National Biography says, "recognised as an authority upon copyright". Planning his own edition of Clare, he made in May 1864 a "provisional bargain", presumably verbal, with the dying John Taylor, to pay Patty Clare £10 a year in exchange for manuscripts and publication rights. Then, on 8 August, he signed an agreement with Patty and her children for the transfer of their rights to Clare's copyrights. This agreement, discovered in the archive of the Whitaker publishing house in 1932, was destroyed with the rest of the archive by a German bomb eight years later.

Whitaker's edition of Clare never materialised, and although he clearly insisted on his ownership of the unpublished material's copyright in relation to the publication of JL Cherry's Life And Remains Of John Clare (1873), there is evidence to suggest that by the time of his death in 1895 he had either relinquished it, or passed it on to the Peterborough Museum Society, along with the bulk of Clare's manuscripts. Certainly none of the many editions of Clare between 1895 and 1965 acknowledged any general copyright holder. Robinson's purchase from Whitaker's, on 9 July 1965, for £1, of "all rights whatsoever possessed by the company in the published and unpublished works of John Clare" initiated the revival of a claim that appears to have been defunct for 70 years.

The revival has helped to ensure that Robinson's many editions of Clare have dominated the field for a generation. The positive side of this has been the bringing into the light of thousands of Clare poems unknown to earlier readers, as well as major prose works. The downside is that it has tended to sideline and sometimes blight the work of other scholars, and to make life harder, for example, for Clare enthusiasts such as folk musicians who wish to compile tapes or CDs of Clare material. It is possible to get permission from Robinson's literary agents, Curtis Brown, to use unpublished Clare material, but it is likely to cost money. And, as I discovered last year as the editor of an edition of Clare's writings of 1841, it is a tiresome process that can involve prevarication and delay. Our edition was set back several months.

Much more serious problems can also arise. In my 15 years of Clare scholarship I have heard many tales of blighted projects. Perhaps the most notable is the case of the late Geoffrey Summerfield, who believed that the copyright claim was used to press him into rewriting an account of how he came to start working on Clare in the 1950s.

The problems created by a single individual controlling the posthumous publications of a major literary figure have been evident in several high-profile modern cases, such as those of James Joyce and Sylvia Plath. With Clare (as with Joyce) there is the vital question of how he is to be edited.

The copyright has helped to ensure the overwhelming predominance of a single editing style: the so-called "textual primitivist" presentation where nothing of the text is corrected or standardised from the manuscript. After the heavy correction of earlier editions, this seemed to create a refreshingly raw "authenticity" in Clare's work, described by John Barrell as being like "discovering the original of a great painting previously known only through engravings". But its dominance has also limited Clare's accessibility, denying him the wider audience that his poetry deserves.

For Clare is, as the Independent's literary editor Boyd Tonkin recently put it, "The People's Poet". He speaks for the common people and for the dispossessed (birds, animals, flowers as well as people). He is important for many who have suffered from mental health problems, for ecologists and for nature-lovers. It is a grotesque anomaly for one person to try to control a poet from the 19th century, particularly one who, as Tim Chilcott notes, "so tellingly damned all manifestations of 'property', 'possession' and 'enclosure'".

But "The People" seem at last to have begun fighting back. Kövesi's decision to publish and be damned began a continuing campaign. Last week a letter supporting Kövesi appeared in the TLS signed by Seamus Heaney, Andrew Motion, Tom Paulin and 25 other Clare scholars. The threatening letter from Harbottle and Lewis received a polite but firm reply from Kövesi's publisher, Mike Gorman of M&C Services, requesting proof that Robinson genuinely owns the copyright to Clare's unpublished works. This has been met with six months of silence.

Kövesi is now preparing his second "unauthorised" edition, John Clare: Flower Poems, which will be published in October. "Until clear proof is offered that the copyright claim is legitimate," he says, "I will continue to publish Clare in accessible and easily available editions, and I would urge others to do the same. I think the copyright claim has damaged Clare studies, and it is now time that it was laid to rest."

· John Goodridge is reader in English at Nottingham Trent University and editor of the John Clare Society Journal. fields.trailText: Greece | New England | Bangkok and Bali
fields.body:
Europe

Greece: Two weeks' windsurfing tuition on Kos in October costs £120pp. Seven nights' accommodation starts from £219pp based on three sharing self-catering apartments. Flights included. Argo Holidays 020-7331 7070.

North America

US: Experience New England in the Fall. The five-day Mountain Foliage Getaway coach tour begins in Boston, and follows a seasonal trail through the striking villages of Vermont and the White Mountain National Forest in New Hampshire. Departing on September 10, the tour costs £959pp. Osprey Holidays 08705 605 605.

US: Three-night Christmas shopping break to Boston from November 1 to December 14 for £305pp, including flights and accommodation. Cheapflights.com

Asia

India: Enjoy a tour of the real Rajasthan and the medieval walled city of Jaisalmer in the Thar desert. The 13-day tour departs October 20 and costs £1,371pp, including a donation to the fund set up to save Jaisalmer. Price includes scheduled British Airways flights, all domestic flights and transfers and room-only accommodation. Greaves Travel, 020-7487 9111.

Bangkok and Bali: Fourteen nights for £1,049 including return scheduled flights with Garuda International, all transfers and room-only accommodation. For departures between September 1 and November 30. Tradewinds 0870 751 0004.

Middle East

Egypt: A six-day diving package staying at the Falcon Hills Hotel in Ras Um Sid, November 1 to December 15, costs £499pp. Half-board accommodation and Gatwick return flights included. Discover Red Sea 020-7407 2111.

Israel: Three-night weekend breaks in Jerusalem from £329 including flights and self-catering accommodation. November onwards. Pullman Holidays 08700 133085.

Cruising
Food: Thirteen-night cruise aboard the Crystal Symphony from Barbados to Acapulco via the Panama canal with demonstrations by chef Brian Turner. Fly out from UK on November 19. Cost from £2,410pp. Crystal Cruises, 020 7287 9040.

The Galapagos: Fourteen-day trip with 10-day cruise of the islands. Departs September 23. Price from £2,875pp, including international and internal flights, accommodation and expert guides. Discovery Initiatives (01285 810621)

Mediterranean: A seven-night cruise on Sunbird leaves September 23 visiting Palma, Corsica, Rome, Florence, Monte Carlo and Barcelona, costs £649pp including flights from Gatwick or Manchester, transfers, all meals and entertainments. Airtours 08701 577775.

fields.headline: Hollick raises for sale sign
fields.standfirst: United's plan for £10bn merger with Carlton collapses
fields.trailText: United News & Media yesterday conceded defeat in the battle for control of ITV after its planned £10bn merger with fellow ITV company Carlton Communications collapsed.
fields.body:
United News & Media yesterday conceded defeat in the battle for control of ITV after its planned £10bn merger with fellow ITV company Carlton Communications collapsed.

United chief executive Lord Hollick effectively raised the for sale sign over the company or its three ITV franchises, Meridian, Anglia and HTV, after a brief statement confirming the deal with Carlton had broken down. Insiders said that Lord Hollick may prefer to attract a bid for the entire group.

A source close to the company said: "United won't be sentimental about this. This is a cold and calculating decision to deliver value to their shareholders.

That could be an offer for the whole company or it could be that if they had a very good offer for their TV assets that they would sell them piecemeal."

Shares in United ended the day 14p higher at 958p while Carlton was 18p lower at 802p. Granada Media was down 29p at 577p.

The announcement will pave the way for a period of behind-the-scenes discussions that could see Carlton and fellow ITV company Granada divide the spoils between them. "Hollick is looking pretty wounded," said a Granada adviser.

Granada chief executive Charles Allen said he was still ready to go hostile for one of the two companies but added: "We are open to dialogue but it has to be the right assets at the right price."

The United statement recognised that consolidation of ITV is now inevitable. "It remains clear to the board of United that there is significant value to be generated from the consolidation of UK television ownership," it said.

"The board therefore intends to pursue discussions with interested parties to establish how this value can best be captured for the benefit of United's shareholders".

Both United and Carlton were at pains to play down suggestions that the breakdown of the merger agreed last November had been acrimonious.

Conversations between Lord Hollick and Michael Green at Carlton had been "businesslike" in the past week according to one.

If the TV assets are disposed of United would be left with the Express newspaper titles, the Daily Star, its online arm and trade magazine division Miller Freeman CMP. United is understood to have been approached by various putative bidders during the week including RTL which owns 65% of Channel 5 and French commercial television network TF1.

RTL however, which is the soon to be floated combination of the TV assets of Pearson and CLT Ufa, could simply be sabre rattling to make sure it gets hold of the 35% of Channel 5 owned by United.

webTitle: Power struggle after ITV merger flop

fields.headline: Power struggle after ITV merger flop
fields.trailText: The proposed £10bn merger between the ITV companies Carlton Communications and United News & Media collapsed yesterday, clearing the way for a behind the scenes power struggle for control of Britain's leading commercial channel.
fields.body:
The proposed £10bn merger between the ITV companies Carlton Communications and United News & Media collapsed yesterday, clearing the way for a behind the scenes power struggle for control of Britain's leading commercial channel.

Carlton said the condition imposed by regulators to sell the lucrative United-owned Meridian licence in return for approving the deal had proved too onerous.

The collapse of the deal will be a bitter blow to Lord Hollick, United's chief executive and Labour peer, who was to have been chief executive of the combined group.

United, which also owns the HTV and Anglia franchises as well as the Express newspapers and a stake in Channel 5, has now effectively resigned itself to quitting the race to dominate ITV. A statement said the company was pursuing talks to dispose of its licences which could be carved up between Carlton and Britain's biggest ITV company, Granada, through horse trading over the next few weeks.

In a 236-page report last week, the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, gave landmark approval for the lion's share of the ITV network to be owned by just two companies. The de cision is seen as an interim one before changes to primary legislation can lay the foundations for a single company to run the network.

Granada, which has been given permission from regulators to bid for either United or Carlton, said it would be prepared to discuss the acquisition of United's franchises at the right price. It has until August 4 under takeover rules to declare its hand.

Conversations have already been held between Carlton's chief executive, Michael Green, and his opposite number at Granada, Charles Allen. Carlton owns the London weekday, West Country and Central licences.

Alternatively, Granada could still make a full bid for one of the companies. Granada owns the Granada, Tyne Tees, LWT and Yorkshire licences and is ITV's most prolific programme maker with shows including Coronation Street, Blind Date and Cold Feet.

Lord Hollick precipitated his fate when, along with Mr Green, he bounced the government into approving the consolidation of ITV by proposing their merger at the end of last year.

The United statement said: "It remains clear to the board that there is significant value to be generated from the consolidation of UK television ownership. The board there fore intends to pursue discussions with interested parties to establish how this value can best be captured for the benefit of United's shareholders."

As well as Granada and Carlton, United is said to have held talks with pan-European TV business RTL which owns 65% of Channel 5 and French media group TF1.

There were signs last weekend that the merger between Carlton and United was on shaky ground. A series of briefings to the press made it clear that Carlton wanted to renegotiate the terms of the agreement the two companies had struck last November. "It has been on the cards all week and it became clear yesterday that the deal woudn't happen," said one United insider.

A Carlton source said there was no sense in progressing the merger without Meridian, the franchise covering the south and south-east of England which accounts for almost half United's revenues from ITV.

"Without Meridian the logic of the merger was fatally undermined," he said.

Broadcasting regulation states that no single company can command more than 15% of the total television audience which means Granada could not swallow either company whole.

fields.headline: Equitable's winners and losers
fields.standfirst: 90,000 policyholders will get 25% extra on their pensions and may also have a windfall of £4,000, says Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: 90,000 policyholders will get 25% extra on their pensions and may also have a windfall of £4,000.
fields.body:
Equitable Life's 90,000 guaranteed annuity policyholders scooped the jackpot this week after a three-year legal wrangle which culminated in total defeat for the company and forced the 238-year-old mutual into a takeover.

The guaranteed policyholders will see their pension payouts increased by around 25% as a result of the ruling, plus they may be in line for windfalls expected to average £4,000 following the demutualisation and takeover of the company. Michael Simmons (pictured above right), a solicitor with London law firm Finers Stephens Innocent, is typical of the high net worth clients that make up most of Equitable's policyholders.

He says he expects his pension income to rise by around £25,000 a year to £115,000 from the £90,000 before the House of Lords ruling. He says: "The Law Lords ruling is a great pleasure and relief, combined with sadness that Equitable Life has made such a pig's ear of the whole thing."

The losers are the many more policyholders, around 500,000 people, who hold policies without the guaranteed element. Equitable Life says they will be hit by the ruling, but is not being explicit as to how.

Managing director Alan Nash says: "We will need to look at the returns guaranteed policyholders will receive, and what impact that may have on other policyholders. As regards the values quoted in December 31, 1999 policies, we can expect those to still apply. Non-guaranteed policy- holders will be hit by this judgment, but we do not expect policy values to fall."

In other words, the 'hit' on non-guaranteed policyholders is likely to be lower future bonuses. However, this is almost certain to be offset by the money that will be pumped into the company when it is taken over. So non-guaranteed policyholders may still not lose out, and will also, if they have a qualifying with-profits policy, gain from any windfalls.

Early indications are that there is a queue of buyers wanting to snap up Equi table, which has an enviable reputation as a highly efficient provider of pension policies to high net worth clients who include high court judges, investment bankers and Harley Street doctors. Analysts are pencilling in a takeover price of around £3.5bn-£4bn, with Barclays and Dutch insurer Aegon named as the likely frontrunners in an auction for the company.

Shared between Equitable's 600,000 policyholders, the price tag equates to average windfalls of £6,500-£7,000, in line with the payouts made when Lloyds TSB bought Scottish Widows. However, the windfalls will be deflated by the need for any acquirer to set aside £1.5bn to rebuild Equitable's long-term fund, depleted by the payouts to the guaranteed policies.

Therefore windfalls are likely to be reduced to an average of £4,000 or less. The windfalls will be lower than the figures enjoyed in other demutualisations because Equitable has a policy of keeping small reserves and paying out the maximum possible to policyholders.

Other insurers regularly squirrel away money to meet future potential liabilities, holding 'free assets' worth around 15%-20% of the with-profits fund. But Equitable's free asset ratio is much closer to 5%, leaving less cash to be paid out on a sale.

Independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet says: "The existing policyholders are generating little profit for shareholders to get their paws on, so that will reduce the amount of windfall policyholders can expect."

But the good news is that the payouts will come sooner rather than later. Corporate financiers expect the sale of Equitable, being handled by Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, to be carried out swiftly. Last year Equitable Life revealed that it had put aside £1.5bn in reserves to meet guaranteed annuity promises, raising questions as to why it now feels it must demutualise.

The cost would also have drip-fed its way through Equitable's accounts over many years. But managing director Alan Nash says that while Equitable's solvency position would not have been hit hard by the payouts, it would have constrained its freedom to invest in equities.

The extra liabilities created by the guarantees would force the company to buy government stock, known as gilts, and sell shares, thereby reducing its long-term returns.

Mr Nash said: "Our investment freedom would have been so curtailed by the judgment that it would not have been in the interests of policy- holders for Equitable to continue as a mutual."

Your questions answered

I have a guaranteed annuity policy with Equitable. How much more will I now receive?

The average increase is put at around 25%. The exact figure will depend on the level of annuity guarantee written in your contract. Typically, this is around 11%, compared to current annuity rates of around 8% for a 65-year old man. Annuity rates vary with age, so for example, one policyholder, 72-year old Dr David Abrams, will be able to claim an annuity of 14.7% compared to 12% currently on offer.

I had a guaranteed policy but took the benefits several years ago. Will I be compensated?

Equitable says yes, but it's not clear how or when. The annuity guarantees only became valuable when market annuity rates fell below the promised rate in the mid-1990s. David Hyman, who brought the case against Equitable, is in this position. "I took the terminal bonus but didn't get the guarantee. They will now have to put that right."

Has the guarantee got any strings attached?

Yes. It only applies if you take out a single life annuity. That means that your spouse will not continue to enjoy benefits after you die.

I'm one of the policyholders without a guarantee. Am I now worse off?

Equitable says you will take a hit, but (as explained above) the portion of the sale proceeds of the company put into the long-term fund should prevent a decline in bonuses. Bonuses already attached to policies cannot be withdrawn, and Equitable says policy valuations made at the end of last year will not be affected.

Where do the figures for £4,000 windfalls come from?

It's anybody's guess what the windfalls will be. The City is expecting a sale price of £4bn, but £1.5bn will immediately go into bolstering the long-term fund to provide for guaranteed annuities. The rest will be split between anybody who has a with profits policy. £2.5bn divided between 600,000 members works out at just over £4,000 each.

Will I receive shares in Equitable?

Almost certainly not. It will not be a demutualisation and floatation on the stock exchange in the style of Norwich Union, but a takeover in the same way as Lloyds TSB bought Scottish Widows.

Can I carpetbag Equitable?

No. Equitable says: "Members joining the society from and including July 20, 2000, will not participate in any benefits derived from the sale of the business."

fields.headline: US shifts on Cuban embargo
fields.trailText: Opponents of the US embargo on Cuba claimed an important tactical victory yesterday after the US House of Representatives voted to lift the sanctions on food and medicine and relax the ban on Americans travelling to the island.
fields.body:
Opponents of the US embargo on Cuba claimed an important tactical victory yesterday after the US House of Representatives voted to lift the sanctions on food and medicine and relax the ban on Americans travelling to the island.

But the vote late on Thursday night does not necessarily mean that the sanctions will be dropped.

The proposal was part of a treasury spending bill, and would stop the US treasury enforcing the sanctions.

But the Senate version of the bill contains no clauses on Cuba, and the Republican Senate leader, Trent Lott, has refused to let them be added.

The 232-186 vote in the house clearly reflected a fundamental shift of opinion in Congress. Sixty Republicans, many from farm states desperate for new export markets, defied their leaders and voted for change.

The vote will increase pressure on the Republican leadership to let a compromise bill on Cuba, which was agreed upon last month, go to the Senate for a vote.

The compromise bill would allow US exports of food and medicine to Cuba, but not two-way trade. Cuba would only be able to buy US goods with cash or foreign credit.

The ban on US tourism in Cuba would stay in place and could no longer be adjusted by presidential decree.

For that reason, the compromise bill was opposed by the White House, which claimed it abrogated presidential powers; the legislation appeared to be stuck in limbo.

Congressional officials said yesterday that, even after the house vote, it was unclear whether Senator Lott could be persuaded to allow a vote on Cuban sanctions before the end of the year.

But Mark Sanford, the South Carolina Republican who proposed the house measures, said the vote was a sign that legislators were increasingly prepared to engage the government of Cuba, just as they had sought to end the isolation of the governments of China and Vietnam.

"This marks the beginning of the an end for an outdated policy towards Cuba," Mr Sanford said. "We've tried 40 years of isolation; it has not worked. The will of the house is that we take this incremental step."

Republican opponents of the embargo argued that US tourism and exchange programmes with communist countries in the Soviet bloc had contributed to the collapse of the iron curtain, and the same strategy of engagement should be tried with Cuba.

But Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat who has been a staunch supporter of sanctions, pointed out that even if the house bill became law it would only prevent the US treasury enforcing the ban on travel to Cuba. It would not make it legal.

"It has little practical effect, because the law hasn't changed," the Cuban-American Mr Menendez said. "What you've done in this act is to create lawlessness."

Any relaxation of the food and medicine embargo, argued Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, another of the three Cuban-American members of Congress, would provide revenue for "the worst violator of human rights in all of the western hemisphere".

The shift of opinion against the Cuban sanctions has mirrored the diminishing influence of the Cuban exiles concentrated in Florida and New Jersey. Their defiance of Washington during the struggle for the future of Elian Gonzalez has hurt their standing in national public opinion.

Farm and business lobbies have also been pressing for a change in the law, arguing that US interests are being left behind in the race for a share of the untapped Cuban market.

They also question why Cuba should be treated so differently from China, another communist state with a dubious human rights record, which has been been given permanent trade relations with the US.

webTitle: Leaders: But US policy needs a thorough overhaul.

fields.headline: Easing off on Cuba
fields.standfirst: But US policy needs a thorough overhaul
fields.trailText: But US policy needs a thorough overhaul.
fields.body:
The decision by the US house of representatives to ease the sanctions regime imposed on Cuba 38 years ago is remarkable in several respects. But it is also a half-measure that can be no substitute for a much-needed, long-awaited overhaul of Washington's antagonistic and self-defeating policy towards the government of Fidel Castro.

The vote to relax restrictions on travel to Cuba by American citizens is partly a recognition of the difficulty of enforcing the present federal curbs. The treasury department estimates that tens of thousands of Americans travelled to the island via third countries last year, while there were about 135,000 officially approved visits. The house's agreement to allow the unrestricted export of food and medicine is also not quite the unalloyed, conciliatory gesture it may seem. US agro-businesses and pharmaceutical companies have watched with growing agitation as Canadian and European exporters have moved into a market which, by reason of geography if not politics, they regard as part of their patch.

The fact that 60 Republican congressmen defied their own leadership and voted with the minority Democrats on the sanctions bill is testimony not to a sudden, high-minded desire to do the right and decent thing, but rather a reflection of the power of farming and business lobbyists on Capitol Hill. A more ambitious bill, that would have ended virtually all trade sanctions, was voted down earlier in the same house debate. Nor are even these modest measures, which must be reconciled with a Senate bill and agreed by the White House, likely to be enacted this year.

All the same, the overall pressure for a more enlightened US relationship with Cuba is gathering strength. The vote was a significant defeat for the fiercely anti-Castro Cuban-American community which, with powerful voting blocs in Florida and New Jersey, has exercised a virtual veto over US policy for too long. The exploitation by Cuban-Americans of the case of the shipwrecked Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez (who has, thankfully, finally gone home), produced a nationwide backlash. How foolish vice-president Al Gore now looks for jumping on the "save Elian" bandwagon. The dawning reality is that the American right, at a time when even North Korea is coming in from the cold, can find less and less justification for pursuing this last of many senseless cold war proxy conflicts.
