The house's agreement to allow the unrestricted export of food and medicine is also not quite the unalloyed, conciliatory gesture it may seem. US agro-businesses and pharmaceutical companies have watched with growing agitation as Canadian and European exporters have moved into a market which, by reason of geography if not politics, they regard as part of their patch. The fact that 60 Republican congressmen defied their own leadership and voted with the minority Democrats on the sanctions bill is testimony not to a sudden, high-minded desire to do the right and decent thing, but rather a reflection of the power of farming and business lobbyists on Capitol Hill. A more ambitious bill, that would have ended virtually all trade sanctions, was voted down earlier in the same house debate. Nor are even these modest measures, which must be reconciled with a Senate bill and agreed by the White House, likely to be enacted this year. All the same, the overall pressure for a more enlightened US relationship with Cuba is gathering strength. The vote was a significant defeat for the fiercely anti-Castro Cuban-American community which, with powerful voting blocs in Florida and New Jersey, has exercised a virtual veto over US policy for too long. The exploitation by Cuban-Americans of the case of the shipwrecked Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez (who has, thankfully, finally gone home), produced a nationwide backlash. How foolish vice-president Al Gore now looks for jumping on the "save Elian" bandwagon. The dawning reality is that the American right, at a time when even North Korea is coming in from the cold, can find less and less justification for pursuing this last of many senseless cold war proxy conflicts.

fields.headline: Winning the toss so crucial
fields.standfirst: This week and next we will be carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Find out how the First XI and the Under-12s get on by reading regular updates from James Schneider, captain of cricket, on wisden.com
fields.trailText: Day 8
fields.body:
Day 8

The first XI go back to St Catherine's to play their first XI colts team, known as St Philip's. Again, many of the players are younger than we are, and some double up to play in both the first and seconds, due in part to limited numbers of boys in each year. (Possibly limited also by the weekly commitment to train which Bajan clubs require.) The U12s are at Windward, where we played last Friday.

I win the toss and put them in. In these parts, the wicket tends to be wet first thing and the ball will stop and seam for about an hour. Bowling first is a significant advantage and, arguably, my most useful function as captain is to win the toss. St Philip's are too weak for us and we rapidly bowl them out for 88 and knock the runs off in 13 overs or so. As I am still not quite fit, I do not bring myself on to bowl and don't bat either. Our opponents have gone overboard on hospitality and we all eat far too much - I do not know what Nancy Doyle would have made of Bajan food, but it is delicious. Because the game ends early we have time to play with their side informally, which is a lot of fun.

Timothy recruits four of our host players to bowl at him. He points out that my season may end on Friday, but he has a Gubby Allen final at Lord's on August 6 and a number of county matches. St Philip's are hoping to go on tour and buy some kit; they plan to finance these activities with a sponsored event. All the parents and the school contribute. Once Mackie, Team Schneider's driver and general homme d'affaires, arrives we have sufficient transport to get everyone home without waiting the extra hour or so for the team bus. On getting back to the team hotel, I learn that the U12s tied.

Day 9

The first XI is playing the National Sports Council combined side at a club called "Yorkshire". Any resemblance was impossible to find. This was a good side with two excellent batsmen in Philips and Steel (who is only 11). Oddly, I think I have met him before. We were to play a 30-over match. They made 148-6 with Philips making 73. At 52-1 we looked in good shape when we lost the first wicket, as we did at 93-2, when I was run out. We then contrived to make very heavy weather of things and got to the last over on 147-9. We ended on 148 all out.

As there was no arrangement relating to the loss of fewer wickets, I believe the result was a tie. JC generously concedes defeat. One gentleman tells my father that one-day matches can never end in a tie. Dad points out that he was at the most famous tie of all, the semi-final of last year's World Cup and that a one-day match will end in a tie unless there is agreement to the contrary, as the Laws state that the winner is the side which scores most runs. Vigorous argument ensues over a few beers.

RAK wins the dunce of the day for directing three sets of people to the wrong ground to watch the U12s. Worse, one set is the Headmaster and his wife, who have just arrived. He wears the red Ascot hat with aplomb at the evening barbeque.

Day 10

We have a day off. Most of the team go to Harrison's Caves and on a submarine trip to see the reef. JC, Rupert Haddon and I play golf at Royal Westmoreland. The round takes forever largely due to my completely inept play. Haddon (aged 13) goes round in 81, pars on the last six holes.

I have a chance to reflect on the tour so far. It has been a great success. The bat we have presented to each side we have played has been much appreciated. We have given each player a miniature ball from Lord's and a tour brochure. Kit is expensive and is hard to come by for lots of the kids we play. It occurs to me that MCC allegedly have 10,000 new balls that are branded "Made in England" but aren't. They cannot be sold in England and are supposed to be a bit hard, but they would make a magnificent gift to youth cricket in the Caribbean and other developing countries.

Interestingly, I realise I have never been so upset at getting out than I was yesterday. Perhaps I am learning to take this game sufficiently seriously. It may be only a game, but there is no point playing if you don't play hard.

Lastly, whilst our catching has (with certain honourable exceptions) been erratic our ground fielding has been outstanding and much commented upon. On the other hand the ground fielding of all our opponents has been, frankly, poor. Perhaps we do not take the bumpy surfaces for granted. For whatever reason, it is nice to be able to write that an English side has outfielded the opposition.

Day 11

The first XI is playing at Wanderers. This is the second oldest club in the Caribbean and has a wonderful wooden two-storey pavilion. Our nemesis, Simon Steel, is playing for Wanderers. His father, Malcolm and my mother realise we had all met at the Bridgetown Test in March 1999. Again, I win the toss. At 15-3 and 49-5 it looks a good toss to have won. Unhappily, Steel is not back in the pavilion and he makes a wonderful 65. Eventually he was run out; there was no other way we would have got him. Wanderers reach 143 all out off the full 35 overs. I am not sure we would have held it together so well.

Whilst in the field, I notice Timothy in the nets being bowled at by fathers and Wanderers players. His regime seems to be 15-minute net, half-hour rest and then on go the pads and helmet for another net. He tells me at lunch that the break is for the benefit of the bowlers. I enquire about the helmet. He tells me severely that nets have to be as near as being in the middle to be of any use and that he therefore wears his helmet, even for throw downs, and has imaginary fielders in place! When we bat, despite a little wobble, we get home with half a dozen overs in hand, thanks to a rapid fifty from Tom Turney.

Day 12

Before we go to our respective matches, the entire party is taken to have its photo taken at Kensington Oval, a very nice touch. The square at the Oval is only four pitches wide. It is wonderful to see how much use they get out of a wicket, but hardly surprising. Grounds are lovingly and immaculately maintained, with wickets being rolled between innings and immediately after play even for our schoolboy events. Smaller clubs in outlying areas may supplement ground staff with a complement of native goats, tethered in areas of the outfield in rotation.

The first XI is playing the National Sports Council side again at Dover. The ground is actually a football field with two strips in the middle, bounded on three sides by busy local streets. Eight of their side from the other day, including Philips, are playing, but not Steel. A passer-by tells me that the selectors are mad or venal or both for omitting Karim, the quick bowler we met at Windward. If interest in cricket is declining in these parts, it hasn't affected our audience, who spectate noisily from beyond the boundary or atop their hastily parked cars. I lose the toss, but it is of no consequence. We set off at a tremendous rate, keep going and reach 246 all out off exactly 35 overs. Whilst a couple of players make fifties, it has to be recorded that 45 runs were gifted by letting ones become fours. The boundaries are very short, so alert and accurate fielding is essential. Nonetheless, we lunch with quiet confidence.

Early on, they are three wickets down. Philips is run out when there was never a run. The non-striker goes past him when Philips is standing six inches outside his crease, sending him back to no avail. Having waited for them to cross, we break the bowlers end stumps. I am delighted by this display of cricketing brains. I bowl a player around his legs with my first ball. Haddon and Turney both take two wickets with successive balls. At 139-9 off about 30 overs, I bring myself back on and conclude the day's entertainment with my first ball.

At the presentation we hand over another bat and can see Tuesday's bat already getting good use!

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya becomes a feminist icon.
fields.body:
It's not always easy to find one's way, but the other evening I was taking a good look at myself in one of the mirrors in my loft when I had a moment of revelation. I'm gorgeous, and yet I take pride in my celibacy; I combine the lusciousness of Naomi Wolf with the brimstone austerity of Andrea Dworkin. Yes, at last I have become a feminist icon!

Giddy with excitement, I opened my laptop and, with trembling fingers, entered 'Feminism': 160,000 pages, while 'David Beckham' appears in only 62,000, a triumph for sisters everywhere (mind you, 'Diet' gets 1.5 million; 'Sex', 7.5 million; 'Money', 10.3 million; and 'Power,' 14 million, which makes you wonder).

There really is something for everybody, from anarcho-feminist texts at www.spunk.org to all manner of self-defence tricks, which I downloaded from www.safetyforwomen.com.

I found the Internet Primer for Feminists most informative, but I fell for Amazonian Warrior Chicks for Nicaraguan Feminism. Unfortunately, the site does not explain how to become an Amazon Warrior Chick, a role I think would suit my personality really well. If you have any suggestions on how to achieve this, please email them to me.

For old-fashioned people who need a sense of balance in every argument, you can try Sympathy For The Male. I discovered in the Primer For Feminists that a health centre in Connecticut pays $5,000 for a good egg from a healthy donor. If you are interested in a simpler way of earning a bit of money, you can register with www.ciao.com, a consumer site covering a number of fields, and including reviews from the public. They'll pay up to £100 for your views on any relevant product.

 tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk

 www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk

webTitle: When Egg isn't all that it's cracked up to be

fields.headline: When Egg isn't all that it's cracked up to be
fields.trailText: Internet bank Egg is expanding left, right and centre, with share-dealing starting tomorrow and a range of other services planned, but almost two years after its launch, it still seems to be getting complaints about problems with its basic banking service.
fields.body:
Internet bank Egg is expanding left, right and centre, with share-dealing starting tomorrow and a range of other services planned, but almost two years after its launch, it still seems to be getting complaints about problems with its basic banking service.

Ann Broome opened an Egg savings account almost a year ago and says she now plans to take all her money out after a catalogue of problems.

Ms Broome, of St Andrews, Fife, opened a standard savings account with Egg, and shortly afterwards took up the internet-only option in order to take advantage of the higher interest rate. "That's when the problems started. We've had endless difficulties since then," she says.

Her main gripes concern Egg "losing" £3,000 and failing to transfer two other sums totalling £2,700 into her account. According to her Royal Bank of Scotland statement, the £3,000 had been collected by Egg on April 6, but her Egg statement made no mention of it being paid into her account. "To all intents and purposes the money had vanished into thin air," she says.

The £2,700, although appearing on the Egg statement as payments into the account on April 14 and 17, had, in fact, never been collected by Egg from her nominated NatWest account, where it was still sitting nearly two months later. She is still waiting for the interest on the £2,700, she says.

"Egg should provide its customers with more information and be more helpful and reliable when they encounter problems. In order to get to speak to someone who knows anything about anything it involves a major battle every time."

Egg admits that the £2,700 wasn't collected from the NatWest account, and says: "It was an admin error." As for the £3,000, a spokeswoman says it did not have all the details necessary to allocate this money to the right account, so it was put into a suspense account.

Egg has offered Ms Broome compensation to cover the interest she would have lost. It initially offered £20 but says she was "unhappy" with that so it has offered her a further £10. Ms Broome's experiences were not representative of its normal service, says the spokeswoman.

webTitle: India's summer kicks off at the Cottage

fields.headline: India's summer kicks off at the Cottage
fields.standfirst: They're ranked 115 in the world and they're on a mission, writes  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.trailText: For a country that has failed to register a blip never mind make a mark in international football, India's contribution to the world game is more significant than many might think. During the 1952 Olympics India, playing as was their wont in bare feet, were thrashed 10-1 by Yugoslavia and their team suffered from frostbite and bruising because of the Helsinki weather and terrain.
fields.body:
For a country that has failed to register a blip never mind make a mark in international football, India's contribution to the world game is more significant than many might think. During the 1952 Olympics India, playing as was their wont in bare feet, were thrashed 10-1 by Yugoslavia and their team suffered from frostbite and bruising because of the Helsinki weather and terrain.

For the watching Fifa officials it became apparent that bare feet are no match for boots and, soon after, world football's governing body introduced a rule making footwear compulsory in competitive matches.

At Craven Cottage this afternoon the weather should be milder than Helsinki's was in 1952 and, after lacing their boots, India's national team will take to the field against Fulham.

It is India's first serious tour of England since football was introduced there at the turn of the 20th century by British soldiers. They then play West Bromwich on Wednesday followed by a crunch encounter with Bangladesh next Saturday at Leicester City's Filbert Street.

The tour promises to be an intriguing one and is designed to raise the profile of India's football. It also aims to highlight the lack of British Asians within the game here and address concerns that, despite an obvious passion, they are still failing to make a breakthrough.

There is not a single player of Asian extraction in an English Premiership first team, although some are playing in the reserves while others have been signed by academies. India's captain Baichung Bhutia plays for Bury but overall the country's football, both in Britain and in large areas of India itself, remains an unknown quantity.

Bhutia feels that the tour will be a learning experience for the team. "I think the players will find the pace of the game a bit difficult to deal with. Don't expect too much of us but we have some quality and could surprise a few people," he says.

India are ranked 115th in the world and, despite the popularity of the game in some parts of the country, the standard remains poor. Many concede that the team would just about hold their own in the lower reaches of the Nationwide League.

A national league was only formed in 1997 and floodlights introduced last season. Prior to that, many matches had to be postponed because of the heat, or spread over several hours to allow players to cool off. There is only one full-time professional club, FC Kochin, in the southwestern state of Kerala, and there has been concern at how the game is run, with the authorities plagued by infighting.

This tour was preceded by a conference highlighting issues that have been raised by their presence. Paul Dimeo, who has conducted research into the Indian game, says: "Many people were genuinely surprised at the interest there is in India. Some clubs have massive crowds and more people watch club football in India than they do club cricket.

"We also discussed developing links, how we in Britain can help football in India. There were some practical ideas about translating coaching manuals and videos into Indian languages. Football is developing in India and there are some very good players coming through. It is now a global game, it's difficult to maintain stereotypes. Twenty years ago nobody took African football seriously and look where they are now."

Football is popular in three states - Kerala, Goa and west Bengal. What the game lacks in facilities and know-how, however, it makes up for in passion. The most established clubs, Mohammadan Sporting, East Bengal and Mohun Bagan, are based in Calcutta and regularly draw crowds in excess of 100,000 when they face each other. Average league attendances for the city's main clubs are around 50,000. FC Kochin often draw crowds of more than 60,000.

Chima Okorie, a striker who who left his native Nigeria to study in India where he was spotted playing for his university and later appeared for all three Calcutta clubs, says: "The atmosphere is absolutely electric during derby matches or for any important game. In my first match for Mohammadan we played East Bengal and there was a crowd of 150,000.

"For the people football is like life and death; their team means everything to them. If a team beats another in a derby then they will have a massive party that carries on for days."

Given the Indian team's limited abilities there are fears that the tour could have a negative impact and reinforce stereotypes. However it has been aggressively promoted within British-Asian communities and large crowds are expected.

The organisers are confident that gains will be made. Jas Baines, who is involved in the promotion of Asian football, says: "There are serious concerns about the lack of British Asians within football. The onus has to be on the community and also on the football authorities, who could be doing a lot more.

"But the fact that the Indian team is here is sending out an important message. It is breaking a stereotype and hopefully we will get people who do not normally watch live football to come to stadiums. It's good for the clubs and their community work and it's good for football."

British Asians with Premier prospects

Harpal Singh Leeds United

The 18-year-old left-winger has been tipped to be the first Asian to play for England at any level. He was recently voted the most promising player by his academy team-mates. Already established in the reserves, he is close to a first-team call-up. Born in Pudsey, he was spotted playing for a local league club and signed during George Graham's reign.

Anwar Uddin West Ham United

Also 18, this traditional English-style centre-half established himself in the reserves at Upton Park last season and has excellent first-team prospects. He recently won praise for his performances in a youth tournament in America. Born in Stepney Green, he was spotted playing for an east London boys' club. He is in the final year of a YTS contract.

There is not a single player of Asian extraction in an English Premiership first team, although some are playing in the reserves while others have been signed by academies. India's captain Baichung Bhutia plays for Bury but overall the country's football, both in Britain and in large areas of India itself, remains an unknown quantity. Bhutia feels that the tour will be a learning experience for the team. "I think the players will find the pace of the game a bit difficult to deal with. Don't expect too much of us but we have some quality and could surprise a few people," he says. India are ranked 115th in the world and, despite the popularity of the game in some parts of the country, the standard remains poor. Many concede that the team would just about hold their own in the lower reaches of the Nationwide League. A national league was only formed in 1997 and floodlights introduced last season. Prior to that, many matches had to be postponed because of the heat, or spread over several hours to allow players to cool off. There is only one full-time professional club, FC Kochin, in the southwestern state of Kerala, and there has been concern at how the game is run, with the authorities plagued by infighting. This tour was preceded by a conference highlighting issues that have been raised by their presence. Paul Dimeo, who has conducted research into the Indian game, says: "Many people were genuinely surprised at the interest there is in India. Some clubs have massive crowds and more people watch club football in India than they do club cricket. "We also discussed developing links, how we in Britain can help football in India. There were some practical ideas about translating coaching manuals and videos into Indian languages. Football is developing in India and there are some very good players coming through. It is now a global game, it's difficult to maintain stereotypes. Twenty years ago nobody took African football seriously and look where they are now." Football is popular in three states - Kerala, Goa and west Bengal. What the game lacks in facilities and know-how, however, it makes up for in passion. The most established clubs, Mohammadan Sporting, East Bengal and Mohun Bagan, are based in Calcutta and regularly draw crowds in excess of 100,000 when they face each other. Average league attendances for the city's main clubs are around 50,000. FC Kochin often draw crowds of more than 60,000. Chima Okorie, a striker who who left his native Nigeria to study in India where he was spotted playing for his university and later appeared for all three Calcutta clubs, says: "The atmosphere is absolutely electric during derby matches or for any important game. In my first match for Mohammadan we played East Bengal and there was a crowd of 150,000. "For the people football is like life and death; their team means everything to them. If a team beats another in a derby then they will have a massive party that carries on for days." Given the Indian team's limited abilities there are fears that the tour could have a negative impact and reinforce stereotypes. However it has been aggressively promoted within British-Asian communities and large crowds are expected. The organisers are confident that gains will be made. Jas Baines, who is involved in the promotion of Asian football, says: "There are serious concerns about the lack of British Asians within football. The onus has to be on the community and also on the football authorities, who could be doing a lot more. "But the fact that the Indian team is here is sending out an important message. It is breaking a stereotype and hopefully we will get people who do not normally watch live football to come to stadiums. It's good for the clubs and their community work and it's good for football." British Asians with Premier prospects Harpal Singh Leeds United The 18-year-old left-winger has been tipped to be the first Asian to play for England at any level. He was recently voted the most promising player by his academy team-mates. Already established in the reserves, he is close to a first-team call-up. Born in Pudsey, he was spotted playing for a local league club and signed during George Graham's reign. Anwar Uddin West Ham United Also 18, this traditional English-style centre-half established himself in the reserves at Upton Park last season and has excellent first-team prospects. He recently won praise for his performances in a youth tournament in America. Born in Stepney Green, he was spotted playing for an east London boys' club. He is in the final year of a YTS contract.

webTitle: Spain's would-be presidents promise the moon and Figo

fields.headline: Spain's would-be presidents promise the moon and Figo
fields.trailText: No doubt luckily for them, Chelsea's Ken Bates, Tottenham's Alan Sugar and Aston Villa's Doug Ellis are not required to put themselves up for re-election by supporters like some of their counterparts abroad. But if the marvellously wacky elections for club president at Real Madrid and Barcelona are anything to go by, English fans are being cheated of some rollicking good off-season entertainment.
fields.body:
No doubt luckily for them, Chelsea's Ken Bates, Tottenham's Alan Sugar and Aston Villa's Doug Ellis are not required to put themselves up for re-election by supporters like some of their counterparts abroad. But if the marvellously wacky elections for club president at Real Madrid and Barcelona are anything to go by, English fans are being cheated of some rollicking good off-season entertainment.

Even Tony Blair's spin doctors would blanch at some of the outrageous election pledges made by the would-be presidents at the Spanish giants in campaigns which have been played out as a daily soap opera this past fortnight.

Presidents of countries have rarely outlined plans as grandiose as those which won a surprise victory for Florentino Perez as Real Madrid's president. With his nose apparently showing no sign of lengthening as he spoke, he promised to sign David Beckham, Zinedine Zidane and Barcelona's Luis Figo, while also wiping out the club's reported £100m debts.

As Barcelona's 100,000 members prepare to cast their votes tomorrow, the favourite Joan Gaspart is attempting to woo them with equally outlandish claims. Gaspart says that, if successful, he will board a plane to London first thing Monday morning to sign Arsenal's Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars. And, after accusing Real Madrid of illegally approaching Figo, he said: "I have a strategy that I am not going to reveal that will keep him at Barcelona."

Lluis Bassat, his rival for the presidency, also promises to keep Figo: "No way are we going to let him leave Barcelona."

So, though Figo is under contract until 2003, it seems he is definitely going to Real Madrid if, by some chance, he does not stay at Barcelona. Right? Wrong, according to his agent, Jose Viega, who says his client is 80% certain to leave, not to Spain but to the Italian champions Lazio.

And Figo himself? He says he wants to stay at Barcelona.

In an effort to close the gap on his rival, Bassat also claims to have a pre-contract agreement with Zidane, who currently plays for Juventus. The fee, says Bassat, would be £37.2m though, strangely, there are some doubting Tomases who question whether a deal has really been done.

Real Madrid and Barcelona hold presidential elections every five years and this year, to the delight of the Spanish media, a unique set of circumstances has meant the campaigns running simultaneously.

Real's now ousted president Lorenzo Sanz called a snap election months before it was due in the hope of capitalising on the club's European Cup triumph. And Barcelona's veteran president Josep Lluis Nunez, who had been in charge for 22 years, surprisingly resigned at the end of last season.

Sanz was expected to be comfortably re-elected but when he realised that Perez's promises were swinging the vote against him, he claimed they were "lies by the master of Cosa Nostra". Try getting that past Madam Speaker.

As soon as the votes from Madrid's 70,000 members were counted last Sunday, however, Perez, a highways engineer, was reluctant to say when Figo, Zidane, Beckham and Uncle Tom Cobleigh would be arriving.

The only signing so far is Alfredo di Stefano, who led Real to five European Cup triumphs in the 50s and 60s, as honorary president.

Perez also had no comment about the situation of Arsenal's former rebel striker, Nicolas Anelka, who was rumoured to be returning to his first club, Paris St-Germain, for about £20m.

Gaspart, owner of a family hotel and longtime deputy of Nunez, is the overwhelming favourite for the Barcelona presidency. But some fans want a complete break from the Nunez ways and are unhappy with Gaspart's links to Opus Dei, a secretive, conservative Catholic organisation.

Bassat, his challenger, is a sort of Spanish Max Clifford, God help him, and has the backing of Jordi Pujol, leader of the Catalonia government.

The elections have thrown Barcelona's close-season rebuilding plans into chaos, with the transfer of Dutch winger Boudewijn Zenden to Lazio put on ice until after tomorrow's vote. "It will depend on whether Figo goes," said Nunez, putting a final oar into the muddy waters.

The election is taken so seriously by Barcelona fans that it would be no surprise to see a plume of white smoke emerging from the Nou Camp after the votes have been counted. But most supporters would reject it as just more hot air.

webTitle: Jury clears officer in Hillsborough trial

fields.headline: Jury clears officer in Hillsborough trial
fields.standfirst: More about Hillsborough
fields.trailText: A former police officer was yesterday cleared of responsibility for the deaths of 96 Liverpool football fans who died in the Hillsborough disaster.
fields.body:
A former police officer was yesterday cleared of responsibility for the deaths of 96 Liverpool football fans who died in the Hillsborough disaster.

Bernard Murray, 58, a former superintendent, was cleared by the jury after more than 21 hours of deliberation at Leeds crown court.

He had pleaded not guilty to the manslaughter of John Alfred Anderson, 62, and James Gary Aspinall, 18, who died in what the prosecution called "a hideous crush" on the terraces.

Mr Murray, of Doncaster, south Yorkshire, was ground commander at Sheffield Wednesday's stadium in April 1989 when Liverpool were to play Nottingham Forest.

Mr Murray's superior and match commander, former chief superintendent David Duckenfield, was also charged with manslaughter. The jury has yet to return a verdict on him.

The private prosecution was brought by the Hillsborough family support group. Anderson and Aspinall were chosen to represent all the victims.

The court heard that Mr Murray had been in control of the closed circuit television control box at the ground and that, as a crush of fans built up at the turnstiles at the Leppings Lane end, Mr Duckenfield gave the order for an exit gate to be opened.

Alun Jones QC, prosecuting, claimed that the two men should have blocked off a tunnel leading to central pens of the terrace and so divert fans to uncrowded pens. Instead fans surged into the tunnel.

Mr Murray said: "I am very much aware that there was a course of action which, if I had thought about it and realised I could have taken, might have prevented people going down the tunnel."

fields.headline: Leeds given tough German hurdle
fields.trailText: Leeds United's return to Europe's elite competition may be shortlived after they were drawn against TSV 1860 Munich in the Champions League third qualifying round next month in another Anglo-German confrontation spicing this year.
fields.body:
Leeds United's return to Europe's elite competition may be shortlived after they were drawn against TSV 1860 Munich in the Champions League third qualifying round next month in another Anglo-German confrontation spicing this year.

The Yorkshire club's relief at avoiding a trip to Turkey or another long haul was tempered by the knowledge that the Bavarian club, who finished fourth in the Bundesliga last season, have the means to block their progress to the first group phase, especially with the second leg in Munich.

David O'Leary's emerging team, bolstered by Olivier Dacourt and Mark Viduka, must start against TSV at Elland Road more than a week before the Premiership season opens, another reason why Leeds's chairman Peter Ridsdale greeted the tie apprehensively.

"It's one of the toughest ties we could have had," he said. "If you look at last year when we drew tough ties every time, it seems like we're having the same bad luck this time around.

"There will be a lot of focus on the match, as there always is when English teams play German teams." Mindful of Kevin Keegan's team's next meeting with the Germans, at Wembley on October 7, he added that "the two countries seem to have developed a special relationship".

On his club's match, he said: "Last year we had tough ties in the Uefa Cup but progressed to the semi-finals. Sometimes it's easier to lift your players when they know it's a tough game."

TSV's president Karl-Heinz Wildmoser took a different view. "Leeds is the favourite, the absolute favourite without any doubt," he said. "It's a young, dynamic team for which we have a great deal of respect."

His club have little European pedigree, having only once contested the Champions Cup, in 1964. But in England TSV will be better remembered as the victims of West Ham in the Cup Winners' Cup final at Wembley in 1965.

Ridsdale immediately discussed arrangements with TSV officials at Uefa's Lake Geneva headquarters. The first leg will be on August 8 or 9 with the return a fortnight later.

The chairman is confident there will be no repeat of the ugly clashes last month in Charleroi between English and German fans.

Relieved that Leeds avoided a tie with Besiktas and a return to Istanbul, where two Leeds fans were stabbed to death before the Galatasaray game last season, he said: "I have no concerns that we have been drawn against a German team. When you look at some of the countries we could have visited and the teams we could have played, I don't see any problems with this one."

He added: "We went to many parts of Europe in the Uefa Cup last season and the behaviour of our fans was excellent."

As seeds Leeds also avoided the Uefa Cup winners Galatasaray, who face St Gallen of Switzerland, the two Milan clubs, the Champions League runners-up Valencia and Rangers.

The Ibrox club face little-known opponents in Herfoelge of Denmark, whose national championship last season was their first major honour. But the club coached by the former Arsenal midfielder John Jensen will only start planning for an opening home leg with Rangers if the Scottish champions overcome Kaunus of Lithuania in the second qualifying round starting at Ibrox on Wednesday.

Shelbourne will be away to Hajduk Split or Hungary's Dunaferr but only if the Republic of Ireland champions knock out Rosenborg in the second qualifying round.

In the InterToto Cup Belgium's veteran striker Luc Nilis is set to make his debut for Aston Villa in their third-round return with the Czechs of Dukla Pribram today at West Bromwich, being used because of Villa Park redevelopment.

Bradford City's winger Jamie Lawrence hopes to convince the manager Chris Hutchings that he is mentally ready, after the recent death of his father, to play in the return against RKC Waalwijk in Holland today. Bradford lead 2-0.

fields.headline: Scally fined record £10,000 for betting
fields.trailText: Gillingham's maverick chairman Paul Scally has been fined £10,000 plus costs for a breach of the Football Association's betting rules, the biggest fine the ruling body has ever imposed for infringement of its guidelines on gambling.
fields.body:
Gillingham's maverick chairman Paul Scally has been fined £10,000 plus costs for a breach of the Football Association's betting rules, the biggest fine the ruling body has ever imposed for infringement of its guidelines on gambling.

It transpired that Scally, who chose not to appear before the three-man commission when it sat yesterday, had three separate bets - understood to run into five figures - on his then Second Division side during the 1998-99 season, which ended with a defeat on penalties by Manchester City in the play-off final.

Scally, who revealed his misdemeanours during a lecture he gave to the Medway council in February, put two of the bets on the play-off final itself, having gambled that Gillingham would reach the final and lose 2-1 to Manchester City before the season began. He had also backed Gills to win promotion.

Scally reacted in forthright fashion, threatening to appeal and claiming that he had asked the FA to postpone the hearing until after a High Court case against the club by a former Gills manager Tony Pulis, who was sacked for alleged gross misconduct.

"The FA has shown its total disregard for basic justice," Scally said, "and I can think of no authority or court in the land that would proceed and hear a case without a defence being considered. I am rapidly losing all respect for them. I will be definitely appealing against this fine."

An FA spokesman said: "Our rules on betting should be well known by those who work in football. We strongly believe that people betting on a game in which they are directly involved sends out the wrong message and creates a culture that does not reflect well on the game."

Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger yesterday said he was "disgusted" at the collapse of the club's £6m deal to sign Edu. The club's attempts to sign the Brazilian and his countryman Edmilson were thwarted after immigration authorities at Heathrow denied Edu entry when he was found to be carrying a forged passport.

"Both deals are dead," Wenger said. "It doesn't mean they cannot be reactivated but we only agreed to take Edu if he had the right passport. I am disgusted and we feel cheated as a club. I still believe the player, who was given the passport by his agent, was honest and did not know it was a fake."

Sunderland hope to complete the £3m transfer of the 19-year-old Argentine defender Julio Arca today, after agreeing personal terms with the player. The Argentinos Juniors defender, who operates as a left-back, will sign subject to receiving the Italian passport for which he qualifies through grandparents.

Leeds's £6m Australian striker Mark Viduka has received clearance for an international work permit after having his first application turned down by the Department for Education and Employment.

Southampton's Latvian striker Marian Pahars has signed a £2m-plus extension to his contract which will keep him at the Dell for the next five years.

Watford's Northern Ireland defender Mark Williams, aged 29, has moved to Wimbledon for an undisclosed fee.

Keith Harris, a 47-year-old financier, has been appointed the new independent chairman of the Football League, replacing Peter Middleton who retired in June.

webTitle: Wizard of spin puts Sri Lanka in charge

fields.headline: Wizard of spin puts Sri Lanka in charge
fields.standfirst:
Sri Lanka 522
South Africa 81-2
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka are still in charge of the first test against the South Africans in Galle.
fields.body:
Muttiah Muralitharan struck two early blows to follow up a century by Mahela Jayawardene as Sri Lanka stayed in charge of the first test against South Africa in Galle yesterday. Jayawardene stroked 167 to lift Sri Lanka's first-innings total to 522 all out, with South Africa 81 for two in reply at the close of the second day.

Muralitharan first sent back the debutant opener Neil McKenzie for 11, bowled off his pads, then had Gary Kirsten (12) edge a catch to the wicketkeeper Kumar Sangakkara to end the day with two for 29.

webTitle: Cricket: Surrey beat Leicestershire by 10 wickets

fields.headline: Bicknell writes name in the record books
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 318 and 87
Surrey 288 & 119-0
Surrey win by 10 wickets
fields.trailText:
Leicestershire 318 and 87
Surrey 288 & 119-0
Surrey win by 10 wickets
fields.body:
Inappropriate as they were amid the simmering heat and shimmering sunshine, anoraks were the garb of preference yesterday as the Martin Bicknell Show continued to knock them dead.

In claiming nine for 47 to set up the championship leaders' fifth win on the trot with a day and a half to spare, on the ground he so fondly calls home, Surrey's evergreen opening bowler recorded the summer's best figures to date while beating Glenn McGrath to the honour of being first to 50 wickets.

Of appreciably more enduring value was his match bag of 16 for 119: the most destructive analysis on English soil since Jim Laker's immortal 19. Muralitharan? Pah. Massie? Who he?

For once, the significance of it all did not elude the perpetrator. "That was 44 years ago," Bicknell stressed, referring to Laker's milestone with a suitable measure of disbelief, not to mention an historical exactitude all too rare among contemporary cricketers, the vast majority of whom cannot tell their Lindwalls from their Millers. "A lot of cricket has been played since then and I'm a firm believer in the traditions of the game, so I'm thrilled."

Reflections, typically, were the last word in understatement. "This is a funny ground. The ball does swing, I bowled in the right area and they nicked it."

The host club ought to consider changing the name of this ground to Bicknell Towers. Martin's second-innings haul, a championship peak, is the most penetrative ever achieved on the premises, and the 228 made in 1995 by Darren, his elder brother and erstwhile Oval confrere, ranks as the highest individual score. By a quirk of fate, the latter returns with Nottinghamshire tomorrow for the meeting between the leading promotion contenders in the National League.

Optimism recharged by half a decade away from the circuit, Neil Burns, the Leicestershire wicketkeeper, reasoned before play resumed that his side, 33 for six overnight, required a further 60 runs to make matters interesting.

In the event they mustered 54, including 47 off 46 balls in the opening half-hour as Phil DeFreitas and Vince Wells, who had the temerity to flat-bat Bicknell for six, swapped caution for rusticity. Predictably the two perished as they had prospered, launching expansive drives and edging to slip in the same over as the man of the hour wound up proceedings with four strikes in 16 balls.

Even so, Burns's forecast proved somewhat fanciful. Though occasionally offering variable bounce, the pitch could have taught quite a few high court judges a thing or two about even-handedness. A point duly reinforced by Ian Ward and Mark Butcher as the openers knocked off the requisite 118 runs inside 40 overs with an aplomb that mocked what had gone before.

Accustomed as he has become to selectorial peccadillos and prejudices, Bicknell, who claimed his 800th first-class victim last week, was reluctant to countenance the possibility that his heroics could lead to a Test recall seven years after his two previous caps, a sin of omission with few parallels.

"To be honest, I'm sick of the whole thing. I'm only 31, the same age bracket as Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Alan Mullally, and I've only missed four championship games in four seasons, a record of which I'm very proud. It makes a mockery of those who say I'm injury-prone.

"But it's water off a duck's back. I do my job day in, day out and I'm appreciated by Surrey. That'll do me."

Unfashionable as it may seem, a county stalwart is still something to be.

webTitle: Cricket: Kent well placed against Hampshire

fields.headline: Patel in form as real Kent stands up
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 320 & 136
Kent 252 & 117-1
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 320 & 136
Kent 252 & 117-1
fields.body:
This was the day after the day before. And a bit of an anti-climax really. After the Dravid and Warne show we had a comedy of errors as Hampshire contrived to get themselves out for 136 and then let the notoriously fragile Kent batsmen reply with 117 for the loss of only one wicket.

The slightly sleepy mood was caused by the Hampshire scorer, Vic Isaacs, who was doubling as the Tannoy announcer. Dimitri Mascarenhas was caught at silly point by a tallish man in a helmet.

Isaacs announced the dismissal: "Mascarenhas was caught by a player we haven't yet recognised. If that player would like to identify himself by putting his hand up . . ."

As the Kent players raised their hands en masse the crowd chortled, applauded and started to unpack their lunchtime sandwiches - it was the most entertaining moment of the day.

Hampshire had started badly when Will Kendall was run out in the third over, a direct hit from Matthew Fleming at extra cover. That precipitated the Kent huddle (which Kent inherited when they bought the conspicuously supple Paul Nixon) which in turn induced nausea in some members of the press box and panic in Hampshire's batsmen.

Giles White was the exception. He faced over half the balls in the innings (181), scored well over half the runs and in doing so carried his bat for the second time this season, and unleashing some classy drives.

Meanwhile, Min Patel was quietly and undemonstratively weaving his way to five for 46, his second five-wicket haul of the season. Eight wickets in the previous match, nine in this, and it can't just be the sunshine - it was freezing at Derby last week. The heat doesn't seem to be changing Robin Smith's fortunes either. Here he played on to Patel having scored only four.

Kent needed 205 to win only their second championship match of the year. Peter Hartley and Simon Francis charged in for nine overs, Hartley inducing the odd edge. But the crowd, sitting in an amazing array of hats on deck chairs around the boundary, dozed a little - lulled by a gentle breeze and the regular trains that passed by just to the back of the pavilion. That is, until 4.35pm, when Warne wound up again.

But Dravid's masterpiece on Thursday seems to have broken Warne's spell a little. Neither David Fulton, in a wide brimmed sunhat, nor Robert Key looked quite as scared as they might have done.

When Fulton was leg before for 42, Shaun Udal punched the air. You waited for a collapse. Warne tried his luck from the other end for 10 overs, then returned to the pavilion end for a final three. Key and Dravid scored only 32 runs off him but - and on a turning pitch - they stayed there. The final day of championship cricket at this ground should be worth watching.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Matthew Hoggard did the bulk of the damage as Yorkshire kept pace with the county championship leaders Surrey with a maximum-points innings victory over Somerset in Scarborough.
fields.body:
Matthew Hoggard did the bulk of the damage as Yorkshire kept pace with the county championship leaders Surrey with a maximum-points innings victory over Somerset in Scarborough.

The England bowler finished with season-best figures of five for 50, as Somerset, resuming on 12 for two in their second innings still 206 runs adrift, were bowled out before tea for 212 to leave Yorkshire victors by an innings and six runs.

Somerset's troubles started as early as the fourth ball of the day when Hoggard knocked out Piran Holloway's off stump. Peter Bowler then reached 15 before being caught by Gary Fellows when Hoggard switched ends.

The visitors lost two more wickets before lunch, Michael Burns lasting only three balls before edging the same bowler to third slip, and Keith Parsons falling lbw to Paul Hutchison's swing after hitting nine boundaries in a bright and breezy 38. Ian Blackwell (24) also got established but failed to move on as he edged a drive off the bowling of Chris Silverwood to Anthony McGrath, who then held a fine catch to dismiss Rob Turner (20).

Steffan Jones delayed the inevitable to top-score with an unbeaten 56 from 50 balls, sharing in a last-wicket stand of 73 with Graham Rose (20). But Simon Widdup finally did for Rose to take his maiden first-class wicket.

The victory put Yorkshire, temporarily at least, above their Roses rivals Lancashire , but they look set to see off Durham after a late rally gave them control at Old Trafford.

The hosts earned a 75-run first-innings advantage as they totalled 445 in their first innings, having resumed on 299 for four. Graham Lloyd (86) and Warren Hegg (38) added to the earlier good work of John Crawley, Sourav Ganguly and Mike Atherton.

Michael Gough and John Wood both picked up four wickets for Durham, who were in good shape at 86 for one but closed on 123 for six - three wickets apiece from Gary Keedy and Gary Yates restricting the visitors to a 48-run lead to take into the final day.

Stuart Law's third county championship century of the summer saw Essex to a four-wicket win over Worcestershire at Chelmsford. The Australian powered his way to an unbeaten 133 as Essex reached their target of 286 to register their third Division Two success of the summer.

It was a victory which crowned a superb recovery by Law and his team-mates after they had finished 109 runs adrift on first innings. The off-spinner Peter Such inspired the comeback, taking two of the remaining wickets in the morning to finish with five for 39 from 22.3 overs as Worcestershire were bowled out for 176 in their second innings.

There are changes in the way bonus points are earned in the millennial revision of the County Championship.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

Bonus points are now reckoned on the score in the first 130 overs, not 120 overs as in recent seasons.

Batting: now 5 pts can be earned (4 last year)

200 -249 runs (1pt);

300-349 (3);

400 or over (5)

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4)

three-five wickets (1);

six-eight wickets (2);

nine-ten (3).

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

*Note: in a draw where the scores finish level , the side batting in the fourth innings earn 6 points their opponents 4, plus bonus points.

fields.headline: Hussain at sixes and threes for England
fields.standfirst: England's one-day record v Zimbabwe   :    How they qualified for the final
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain will lead England to their first trophy for three years today if they can overcome Zimbabwe here in the final of the NatWest series. Triangular one-day tournaments might still be regarded with suspicion in these shores, but victory would at least banish the assumption that when an England captain holds his arms aloft it is in a motion of surrender.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain will lead England to their first trophy for three years today if they can overcome Zimbabwe here in the final of the NatWest series. Triangular one-day tournaments might still be regarded with suspicion in these shores, but victory would at least banish the assumption that when an England captain holds his arms aloft it is in a motion of surrender.

A capacity crowd, the weather set fair and the chance for Hussain to impress upon a country uplifted by victory in the Lord's Test that tangible improvements have been made: on the face of it, the opportunity could hardly be more appealing.

But it is complicated by Hussain's dilemma over his own role in the side. While the captain's cracked thumb healed, a vibrant new opening partnership of Alec Stewart and Marcus Trescothick was born. Hussain is a successful, highly regarded leader searching frantically for a role.

The rational decision would not be for Hussain to remain at No6, where he made an inconspicuous return this week, but for him to replace Andrew Flintoff at No3. If he fails to do so, it will be partly because he fears the move would smack of selfishness. But even given his lack of form, it is the best option both for himself and the side.

Hussain was not telling yesterday and the likelihood is that a definite decision will not be taken until the last minute. He made much of the need to be flexible, and to take account of conditions and the position of the match. That's settled then: Freddie can bat at three if England are 180 for one on a blazing hot day; otherwise, Hussain should strap on his pads from the outset.

"The openers have taken their chances brilliantly," Hussain said, "and where I bat depends on what is best for the team. We erred towards sending Freddie in at No3 this week because I didn't want to disrupt things too much, and we might just do it again, but you have to be flexible." He did say "erred" too, which was a slip of the tongue, but might have given a thing or two away.

Flintoff prospered in his first venture up the order, aroused by the denunciation of his fitness levels and nourished by a partisan Old Trafford crowd. His last two dismissals, however, have turned the attention on to his technique as he has twice been defeated playing forward to balls of extra bounce. A habitual front-foot bully, he would have benefited more than any other young batsman from a season on bouncy Australian pitches.

Few will question Hussain's analysis that Trescothick has taken to international cricket more naturally than any English batsman since Graham Thorpe, so much so that even a failure today would be unlikely to prevent a Test debut at Old Trafford on August 3 for the Somerset left-hander.

"People ask whether his one-day performances are valid when considering him with regard to Test cricket, and in this case I think they are very valid. He has something about him," said Hussain.

Paul Franks did not prosper so readily. His assertive approach has even won respect at Surrey, where they value physical and verbal aggression, but he went wicketless on his one-day debut at Trent Bridge and Andrew Caddick will return today.

England's last one-day trophy seems a long time ago. When Adam Hollioake's side won the Singer-Akai Trophy in Sharjah, more than 2 years ago, it was heralded as a new era: Adam Hollioake and Michael Atherton operating as distinct one-day and Test captains leading two very different teams.

Hollioake's stock fell as quickly as it had risen, and Alec Stewart's appointment brought to an end the split-captaincy experiment. By the time the match-rigging furore had cast doubts over the merits of England's Sharjah victory, by intimating that some Pakistan players might have thrown the game against them, a tournament that had encouraged so much hope had turned into a misleadingly enjoyable jaunt up a blind alley.

Only four players survive from England's Sharjah victory: Stewart, Thorpe, Graeme Hick and Mark Ealham, with only the latter a fixture in the one-day side over the past year. Continuity remains a distant objective.

Much will be made by some gazing upon a Lord's full house today about the fact that the NatWest series reaches its climax free from blare and glare: no contemporary music, no floodlights. Even with the coloured clothing, it will all seem strangely traditional.

There have been enough positive signs, though, to justify the decision to continue the experiment next season. If there has been a fault it has been a creeping financial caution, illustrated by the reliance on temporary, under-powered floodlights. Permanent floodlights on Test grounds are imperative. They would even look the business at Lord's.

webTitle: Zimbabwe watch talent slip away as Goodwin and Johnson bow out

fields.headline: Zimbabwe watch talent slip away as Goodwin and Johnson bow out
fields.standfirst: For the lowest ranked Test side to lose two top players looks careless, writes  Paul Weaver
fields.trailText: To lose one player is a misfortune; to lose two sounds almost as careless as using too many Oscar Wilde quotations. Today Murray Goodwin, who has only just established himself as a batsman of international class, and Neil Johnson, one of the game's leading all-rounders, will play for Zimbabwe for the last time. The final of the NatWest series, against England at what may be a sunny and packed Lord's, should provide a memorable, even poignant valediction.
fields.body:
To lose one player is a misfortune; to lose two sounds almost as careless as using too many Oscar Wilde quotations. Today Murray Goodwin, who has only just established himself as a batsman of international class, and Neil Johnson, one of the game's leading all-rounders, will play for Zimbabwe for the last time. The final of the NatWest series, against England at what may be a sunny and packed Lord's, should provide a memorable, even poignant valediction.

At the end of the game Zimbabwe, already struggling to keep up in Test cricket, will be about a third less than they are this morning. Goodwin and Johnson are that important.

In a sense it feels as though two ringers have been exposed and sent back where they came from. For some time Johnson in particular has regarded himself as the "overseas pro", according to the captain Andy Flower. His disaffection with the Zimbabwe Cricket Union is well known. The relationship has been difficult since, in 1998, he was persuaded to leave Natal and return to his native Zimbabwe.

Goodwin's position is more complex, and until recently the ZCU were hopeful of talking him out of returning to Perth to resume his career with Western Australia. But they did not try hard enough.

"To be honest, they didn't think I'd go," he says. "Last month, about the time we played at Arundel, I gave the ZCU 10 days to make me an offer before I committed myself to Western Australia. But they never came back to me.

"It's a huge decision. But I've made it. The ZCU have talked to me since but now it's too late. The time to talk was when my wife was over here, when she and I could have sat down and had a good discussion." His wife, an Australian, is back in Perth and not keen on Zimbabwe, which is a bigger factor than that country's instability.

For most of the past year the Zimbabwe players have been fighting the ZCU for more money. Even the senior players in the team were offered only £3,000 for the England tour.

"Since those contracts were negotiated things have improved. When we sign the new contracts in September the terms will be a lot better. But I won't be one of those signing."

Goodwin, who was born in Harare 27 years ago but whose family moved to Australia when he was 13, is also worried about the cricketing future of his native land. "There aren't many first-class teams there and there has not been a great deal of investment. There is not the quality of coaching to pull the younger players up through the grades. There are plenty of Australians who could do the job."

Goodwin's cricket is, essentially, Australian. This is a back-foot player, a cutter and hooker who has thrived on the hard pitches of Perth since his debut for WA in 1994-95 and scored 91 and 77 against the England tourists.

He is a product of the vaunted academy and represented Australia at Under-19 level. "I was coached by some of the great names there, Rod Marsh, Ian Chappell, Dennis Lillee, Barry Richards . . .

"There is a hardness about the cricket there that toughens you up mentally and physically. It's something you just don't get growing up in Zimbabwe."

He will remember, above all, his 113 against West Indies in Kingston. "To score a hundred at the home of Courtney Walsh, with the crowd and the entire island willing him on to break the world record, felt pretty special. It was frighteningly loud at times.

"But winning a Test series in Pakistan also has to come pretty high up when I look back on the highlights. And there was that big stand with Andy Flower . . ." For a moment he is lost in reverie. It was against Pakistan in 1998 that he scored his maiden Test hundred, an unbeaten 166. With Flower he added 277.

This summer he scored his third Test hundred, against England at Trent Bridge. Another came in the NatWest series. But now he will never know how good he might have been. "I still haven't totally given up on the idea on playing for Zimbabwe again. Next year they will tour in May and June, after the end of the Australian season. But I think the ZCU will say no to the idea.

"Tomorrow I expect to play my last innings. I will try to go out there and enjoy a game with some of the best mates I have. But I suppose some sadness will come into it too. But I hope I will play in England again. I would love to play county cricket and would be happy to have a go in the leagues.

"We have a great chance tomorrow. I think we have played the smartest cricket in the tournament. We regrouped well after the Tests and really focused on this competition. England have bowled better than the other two sides. But their batting looks vulnerable."

Johnson, meanwhile, is also quitting international cricket to concentrate on the provincial game. After today's match the 30-year-old will fly to South Africa, where he will play for Western Province next winter. Like Goodwin, he would like to play county cricket; he has had a brief and successful go at it with Leicestershire.

Last year he was one of the major players in the World Cup, scoring 367 runs and taking 12 wickets. Zimbabwe, with their shallow resources, will be depleted beyond easy repair after today.

webTitle: Cricket: Gloucestershire versus Warwickshire finely balanced

fields.headline: Harvey's little local miracle
fields.standfirst:
Warwickshire 260 & 316
Gloucestershire 254
fields.trailText:
Warwickshire 260 & 316
Gloucestershire 254
fields.body:
Cotswold country abounds with legend, myth and, in Wally Hammond's case it would appear, miracle.

This is the evocative terrain of Hetty Pegler's Tump and the Devil's Chimney while on this very ground, we are unreliably assured, the Gloucestershire and England prince of batsmen once hit a golf ball in a post-match challenge from the shadow of the chapel to the distant college lawn. At the present rate of anecdotal licence, the ball will in time have landed to disturb the wildlife amid the blue haze of Cleeve Hill.

It looked at one point as if Gloucestershire might need something equally miraculous today to produce that elusive Championship win. Warwickshire were all out for 316 at the close, for a lead of 323, but it could easily have been more.

Cheltenham's regulars take the same vantage point for every visit. They cannot resist repeating what they suspect Goddard would have done with those big twisting fingers of his. They recount with relish the details of Cliff Monks's 40-yard sprint here to take Gloucestershire's most famous catch, against Middlesex in 1947 - though the distance has inevitably grown to 60 yards.

Warwickshire batted watch fully against an attack which often seemed a bowler short but was shuffled thoughtfully by Mark Alleyne. The battle was devoid of too much incident, thought not of sustained interest. This kind of devotion among the faithful mystifies only those who don't warm to the game's age-old subtleties.

It took some time for Gloucestershire to claim the day's first wicket, Michael Powell, but the nightwatchman Keith Piper carried on: with a risk or two, a cheeky reverse sweep or two and enough positive batting among his 10 boundaries to show that his natural ebullience - lacking in recent seasons - has returned.

Dominic Ostler has also re suscitated his career and moved to a half-century before falling, like Piper, to Jon Lewis, who has discernibly acquired more pace this season. Trevor Penney was not far short of his 50 when caught at the wicket off the seamer Ben Gannon.

Gloucestershire's persistence limited Warwickshire's runs on a fast outfield and Ian Harvey offered a memorable finale, holding on to a difficult return catch from Ashley Giles and then producing a superb delivery to bowl Dougie Brown. He subsequently dismissed Neil Smith and Ed Giddins with successive balls to complete the innings and bring him the last four wickets in eye-blinking rapidity.
